Authors: Abtew AA, Pretzsch J, Secco L, Mohamod TE
Title: Contribution of Small-Scale Gum and Resin Commercialization to Local Livelihood and Rural Economic Development in the Drylands of Eastern Africa
Author_affil: Institute of International Forestry and Forest Products, Technische Universit’ÛÎ_t Dresden
Funding: Erasmus Mundus (EMJDP) within the framework of Forest and Nature for Society (FONASO) programme; German Research Foundation and the Open Access Publication Funds of the TU Dresden
Stated_int: NTFP commercialization
Desired_out: Gum arabic, frankincense, myrrh, and oppopanex are economically viable commercial NTFPs and represent important sources of livelihoods of local community, employment, & foreign exchange earnings. Consumed locally as traditional medicines, foods, and beverages, and are used in religious and cultural rituals.
Study_goal: The study was motivated by the following research questions: (i) To what extent does the economic gain derived from the small-scale production of natural gum and resins impact rural livelihood improvement and poverty alleviation? (ii) What factors explain the inter-household and regional (inter-case) variations in the level of income and dependence on gum and resin incomes? (iii) What lessons and recommendations can be drawn to promote rural economic development based on commercialization of high value NTFPs in the dryland regions of Ethiopia and Sudan?
Study_location: Central Sudan, North Kordofan 12’äÎç27’¢ŠäŒÎ_’¢ŠäŒŠ—“13’äÎç15’¢ŠäŒÎ_ N 28’äÎç15’¢ŠäŒÎ_’¢ŠäŒŠ—“29’äÎç55’¢ŠäŒÎ_ E, Villages of Direra, Helet Ismeal in Elnehud; Central Sudan, North Kordofan 12’äÎç30'’¢ŠäŒŠ—“14’äÎç15' N 30’äÎç20'’¢ŠäŒŠ—“32’äÎç30' E, villages of Amanallah, Elmerhabiba in Ummrawaba; North Ethiopia, Tigray Region 13’äÎç10'’¢ŠäŒŠ—“13’äÎç35' N 38’äÎç35'’¢ŠäŒŠ—“39’äÎç05' E, villages of Tseykeme, Tarma in Abergelle; South Ethiopia, Oromya Region 4’äÎç05'’¢ŠäŒŠ—“4’äÎç25' N 38’äÎç39'’¢ŠäŒŠ—“38’äÎç56' E, villages of Dhass, Wolensu in Borena
Forest_type: Other non-forest environment with planted trees, trees on farms, or tree farms
Sample_size: 4 case study districts, 60 producer households per district
Comps_notes: Also separated by access to and management of resource (private/public managed locally & open access)
Stated_outcomes: Contribution of gum & resin income to household economy, level of engagement & experience with gum/resin production, absolute & relative gum & resin income across income quartiles, expenditure of income from gum & resin, seasonality of income, role of income in poverty mitigation and reducing income inequality, determinants of income
Portion_livelihood_amount: Gum and resin production and collection represent an integral part of households’¢ŠäŒŠÜ¢ livelihood sources in the study areas. These NTFPs generate considerable cash income contributing to 21%, 14%, 20% and 23% of the total household income in Ummrawaba, Elnehud, Abergelle and Borena, respectively (Figure 2). The income variation basically corresponds to the gradient of the resource management, increasing from open-access wild resource (in Borena) to regulated access natural woodland (Abergelle) and to intensively managed gum gardens on private lands (Ummrawaba and Elnehud).
Indicators: absolute and relative contribution of gum and resin income to the total household income in different income quartiles
Outcome.direction_notes: The absolute income earned from gum and resin increases with the total household income in Ummrawaba, Elnehud and Abergelle (Figure 4a’¢ŠäŒŠ—“c). On the other hand, a different pattern was observed in Borena, where households in the lower income quartile groups generated higher income from gum and resin than better-off households. In this case, the total gum and resin income decreases as one moves from the lower to higher income quartile groups (Figure 4d).

Authors: Adhikari B
Title: Poverty, property rights and collective action: understanding the distributive aspects of common property resource management
Author_affil: Environment Department, The University of York, Heslington, York YO10 5DD, United Kingdom
Funding: The research received generous financial support from the South Asian Network for Development and Environmental Economics (SANDEE).
Stated_int: Common property resource management - community forestry
Desired_out: Economic development, sustainable resource use, improved livelihoods
Int_dur: The last two decades (from publication time)
Study_goal: This paper examines this broad concern by investigating whether recent policy shifts (institutional change) towards community forest (CF) resource management in Nepal have increased access of poorer households to the resources.The working hypotheses of the paper are: (1) the poor are, in absolute terms, less dependent, but, in relative terms, more dependent than the •less poorê on forest resources; (2) there are differential impacts of CF management and the poor benefits less than the rich or •less poorê; and (3) ability to use the CF resources is directly linked to heterogeneity in private resource endowments of households.
Study_location: Kavre Palanchok and Sindhu Palanchowk districts in the mid-hills of Nepal.
Study_duration: The Survey was conducted for a period of four months from September to December 2000. The main fieldwork was supplemented by two short visits, September_October 2001 (by two research assistants) and February 2002 (PI), to clarify various concerns raised during the main survey..
Portion_livelihood_amount: See Tables 4 and 7 of paper.
Indicators: Annual average gross and net income per household from CF

Authors: Adhikari B, Di Falco S, Lovett J
Title: Household characteristics and forest dependency: evidence from common property forest management in Nepal
Author_affil: Center for Ecology, Law and Policy, Environment Department, University of York, Heslington, York YO10 5DD, UK
Funding: The first author gratefully acknowledges financial assistance from the South Asian Network for Development and Environmental Economics (SANDEE), the South Asian Network for Economic Research Institutes (SANEI) and Economic and Social Research Council (ESRC).
Stated_int: Common property resource management (community forestry)
Desired_out: Common property resource management has been considered as one of the most viable options for combining poverty reduction, enhancement of local level economic development and biodiversity conservation
Study_goal: In this paper, we aim to provide an answer to the following question: What are the local level socio-economic consequences of the CF program, particularly the equity aspects of existing institutional set-ups? To answer this question we will ask whether (1) the ability to use CPR depends on heterogeneity and inequalities of communities created by private resource endowments of households; and (2) there are different levels of access to, and control over, common property resources by households with different socio-economic status.
Study_location: Two districts in the mid-hills of Nepal: Kabhre Palanchok and Sindhu Palchowk
Stated_outcomes: Annual average quantity of forest products collected by households in bhari* or head load across income groups (poor/middle/rich), by caste and by gender
Indicators: Annual average quantity of forest products collected by households in bhari* or head load, by income group, gender and caste
Outcome.direction_notes: See tables 3, 4 and 5 in paper.

Authors: Adhikari B, Lovett J
Title: Transaction costs and community-based natural resource management in Nepal
Author_affil: Centre for Ecology, Law and Policy, Environment Department, The University of York, Heslington, York YO10 5DD, UK
Funding: Financial assistance for this research was provided by South Asian Network for Development and Environmental Economics (SANDEE).
Stated_int: Community based resource management - community forestry
Desired_out: Economic development, improved livelihoods, sustainable resource use
Int_dur: This paper doesn't say but we know from the other papers that it has been since the mid-1980s
Study_goal: The study presented here is an attempt to quantify the extent of transaction costs incurred by households in the context of community forestry management in Nepal. We do this by asking the following research questions. What are the elements of transaction costs of CF incurred by households? How are these costs distributed across households with different socio-economic status? And how significant are these costs as a percentage of total resource appropriating costs?
Study_location: Kavre Palanchok and Sindhu Palanchowk districts of the middle hills of Nepal.
Stated_outcomes: Transaction costs incurred by households by income group and by FUG
Indicators: Transaction costs incurred by households by income groups

Authors: Adhikari J ; Ojha H ; Bhattarai
Title: Edible forest? Rethinking Nepal's forest governance in the era of food insecurity
Author_affil: Curtin University of Technology, Perth, Australia
Funding: Australian Centre for International Agricultural Research (ACIAR) funded EnLIFT research project (FST/2011/076)
Desired_out: Food security
Study_goal: Contribution of forests to food security
Study_location: eight districts of Nepal (Pyuthan, Rolpa, Rupandehi, Kaski, Lamjung, Nawalparasi, Kavre, and Dolakha)
Stated_outcomes: Food security
Portion_livelihood_amount: first co-author in 1990 revealed that forest products had helped to generate 17.6 percent of income to poorer (all low caste) households, who were functionally landless.
Indicators: Availability of food, consumption
Stated_mech: At a practical level, forest can not only directly help in enhancing the availability of food, especially uncultivated food of diverse types during the critical food shortage periods, but also help enhance the access of the poor and disadvantaged groups to food through generating income and employment opportunities.

Authors: Adhikari S ; Kingi T ; Ganesh S ;
Title: Incentives and Community Participation in the Governance of Community Forests in Nepal
Author_affil: Institute of Natural Resources, Private Bag 11 222, Massey University, Palmerston North 4442, New Zealand
Funding: thankMassey University
Desired_out: Enhanced community participation
Study_goal: To explore what incentives are most likely to enhance the effective participation of local users in the governance and management of common property resources.
Study_location: Tanahun and Lamjung districts
Stated_outcomes: Index of participation
Indicators: Participation index
Outcome.direction_notes: There have been few initiatives to increase the number of women and poor and lower caste in decision-making positions and community forestry interventions.
Stated_mech: The community forestry institutions, both at national and local levels, have failed to recognise the distribution and operation of power amongst different types of resource userswithin CFUGs,who have different socio-economic status, knowledge and understanding, perspectives and values, motives and objectives.

Authors: Agrawal A ; Chhatre A ; Gerber ER
Title: Motivational Crowding in Sustainable Development Interventions
Author_affil: University of Michigan, Ann Arbor, MI
Funding: National Science Foundation (SES-0961868 and SES-0418024) and the Center for Local, State and Urban Policy at the University of Michiganês Ford School of Public Policy.
Desired_out: To reverse the process of degradation of the natural resource base and improve the productive potential of natural resources and incomes of the rural households in the project area”
Study_goal: To examine how changes in institutions and incentives, associated with a government program aimed at improving environmental and development outcomes, influence the motivations of individuals affected by the program
Study_location: Himachal Pradesh
Stated_outcomes: Motivations of individuals
Indicators: Motivational change
Outcome.direction_notes: Villagerswho received private economic benefits were more likely to change from an environmental to an economic motivation for forest protection, whereas those who engaged in communal activities related to the project were less likely to change from an environmental to an economic motivation

Authors: Agrawal A ; Chhatre A ; Gerber ER
Title: Motivational Crowding in Sustainable Development Interventions
Author_affil: University of Michigan, Ann Arbor, MI
Funding: National Science Foundation (SES-0961868 and SES-0418024) and the Center for Local, State and Urban Policy at the University of Michiganês Ford School of Public Policy.
Desired_out: To reverse the process of degradation of the natural resource base and improve the productive potential of natural resources and incomes of the rural households in the project area”
Study_goal: To examine how changes in institutions and incentives, associated with a government program aimed at improving environmental and development outcomes, influence the motivations of individuals affected by the program
Study_location: Himachal Pradesh
Stated_outcomes: Motivations of individuals
Indicators: Motivational change
Outcome.direction_notes: Villagerswho received private economic benefits were more likely to change from an environmental to an economic motivation for forest protection, whereas those who engaged in communal activities related to the project were less likely to change from an environmental to an economic motivation

Authors: Agrawal A, Gupta K
Title: Decentralization and Participation: The Governance of Common Pool Resources in Nepalês Terai
Author_affil: University of Michigan, Ann Arbor, USA
Funding: UNDPãKathmandu for providing the funds necessary for the field research; Revisions of the paper were supported by grants from the National Science Foundation (# SBR 9905443) and the Ford Foundation (# 950-1160-2).
Stated_int: Decentralization of environmental management: Community Forestry in Nepal, specifically the Parks and Peoplesê Program (PPP), launched in 1994 in Nepalês Terai region.
Desired_out: Increase participation of rural households in decision making and benefits related to environmental resources. The Parks and Peoplesê Program (PPP), attempted to enhance local participation by employing both economic and social incentives.
Study_goal: Our paper attempts to examine who participates in the governance of CPRs, using a specific study to focus directly on factors that shape the extent of participation in government-sponsored decentralization initiatives. More specifically, we address the following research question: ••In CPR settings in Nepalês Terai region, what are the major factors influencing participation in government-sponsored programs?êê
Study_location: Five protected areas in the Nepal Terai: Royal Suklaphanta Wildlife Reserve, Kosi Tappu Wildlife Reserve, Parsa Wildlife Reserve, Royal Bardia National Park, Royal Chitwan National Park
Stated_outcomes: Determinant of participation in the PPP
Indicators: Likelihood of participation in user groups formed through the PPP
Outcome.direction_notes: Results from statistical analysis are presented starting on page 1106. There are a number of statistically significant determinants of participation. Two of the three economic variablesã income and landãare statistically significant. Households with supplementary income in addition to their income from agriculture are more likely to participate in user groups created by the PPP (coefficient = 0.477, significant at the 10% level). Similarly, households that own more land are more likely to participate to a greater extent in the groups created by the program (coefficient = 0.004, significant at the 5% level). Both the social variables are statistically significant. The high statistical significance of the caste variable confirms the hypothesis that lower-caste members participate relatively less in the user groups created by the PPP (coefficient = 0.554, significant at the 1% level). The education variable has a negative sign and is statistically significant (coefficient = -0.012, significant at the 5% level). This indicates that the higher the average number of years of education of the adult members in a household, the lower the likelihood of the household participating in the program.Of the two variables related to benefits from the resource (firewood and fodder), firewood is statistically significant. This means that as anticipated, households that use higher amounts of firewood from the forest are also more likely to try to participate in the program and to influence decision making in local groups through participation (coefficient = 0.1, statistically significant at the 5% level). Other variables are discussed in this section.

Authors: Agarwal B
Title: Does Womenês Proportional Strength Affect their Participation? Governing Local Forests in South Asia
Author_affil: Institute of Economic Growth, Delhi University, India
Funding: The data used here were collected through a grant from the Ford Foundation (Delhi).
Stated_int: Community forestry institutions in India and Nepal (decentralization of forestry management)
Desired_out: Increasing community-level forest management for great participation on the part of community members
Study_goal: This paper empirically examines whether womenês proportional strength in the decision-making body of an institution of local governance has an impact on womenês effective participation.
Study_location: Three districts in Gujurat: Narmada/Bharuch, Panchmahals, and Sabarkantha. The Nepal districts are Baglung, Parbat, and Gorkha, with a small spillover of the sample into Dhading district when replacement CFIs were needed for Gorkha.
Forest_type: Not clear the exact types of forests in the study area.
Stated_outcomes: Factors affecting participation: attending meetings, speaking up in meetings, and office bearing
Indicators: Meeting attendance, speaking up in meetings, office bearing
Outcome.direction_notes: See Tables 3 and 4 in paper.

Authors: Ahenkan A, Boon E
Title: Improving Nutrition and Health through Non-timber Forest Products in Ghana
Author_affil: Human Ecology Department, Vrije Universiteit Brussel, Laarbeeklaan 103, B1090, Jette, Brussels, Belgium
Funding: The authors express their heartfelt gratitude to the Vlaamse Interuniversesitaire Raad (VLIR) for supporting the PhD program of Albert Ahenkan at Vrije Universiteit Brussel (VUB), Belgium.
Stated_int: non-timber forest products (NTFPs)
Desired_out: reduction of poverty, in improving nutrition and health, and sustainable management of forest resources
Int_dur: Variable, this article says "in recent years"
Study_goal: This paper seeks to examine the contribution of NTFPs to household nutrition, health, food security, and poverty reduction in Bibiani-Bekwai district (BBD) and Sefwi Wiawso district (SWD) and to identify the types and uses of NTFPs in the two districts.
Study_location: Bibiani-Bekwai district (BBD) and Sefwi Wiawso district (SWD)
Sample_size: 200 randomly-selected heads of households from 10 communities in the two districts. Ten household heads were randomly selected and interviewed per community.
Stated_outcomes: NTFP-based income as share of total income (%); Pearsonês correlation showing the degree of association between NTFPs and food security, and nutrition
Portion_livelihood_amount: See Table 1; depends on income group; on average is 35% of annual income.
Indicators: Annual income and share of NTFP based income among respondents
Outcome.direction_notes: Yes, as the income groups move from less poor to more poor, the percentage of annual income coming from NTFPs increases.

Authors: Ali, T.; Ahmad, M.; Shahbaz, B.; Suleri, A.
Title: Impact of participatory forest management on vulnerability and livelihood assets of forest-dependent communities in northern Pakistan
Journal: International Journal of Sustainable Development & World Ecology
Desired_out: Forestry Sector Project started as reform process of provincial forest department (North-West Frontier Province) in response to high rate of deforestation and declining livelihood support - restructuring and decentralizing forest department hierarchy and implementing participatory approach to forest management. Goal = eliminate fundamental causes of depletion of forest resources through stakeholder participation. In 2002 - NWFP forest ordinance provides legal cover for participatory approach of Village Land Use Plan (VLUP) and joint forest management.
Study_goal: Identify issues hindering and supporting effectiveness of forest reform process and sustainable livelihoods of rural forest communities. Analyze impact of current participatory forest management system.
Study_location: 4 villages from Mansehra, 4 villages from Swat in the North-West Frontier Province
Sample_size: 8 villages (4 project, 4 non-project) - 50 randomly selected households from each
Stated_outcomes: livelihood assets/capital, forest resource use and origin, social capital (trust, relationships between stakeholders, participation), perceptions of vulnerability
Indicators: Distance of forest from home, Institutional access to forest, density of forest - measured of 5 pt Likert Scale

Authors: Alix-Garcia J, Aronson G, Radeloff V, Ramirez-Reyes C, Shapiro E, Sims K, Ya_ez-Pagans P
Title: Environmental and Socioeconomic Impacts of Mexico's Payments for Ecosystem Services Program
Author_affil: University of Wisconsin
Funding: Funding for this impact evaluation was provided by 3ieês donors, which include UKaid, the Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation, Hewlett Foundation and 12 other 3ie members that provide institutional support. A complete listing is provided on the 3ie website.
Stated_int: Mexicoês National Payments for Hydrological Services from 2003-2010. Mexicoês federal payments for hydrological services program (PSAH) began in 2003 and pays landowners to maintain forest cover under five-year contracts.
Desired_out: Reduced deforestation, improved ecosystem services, poverty alleviation
Study_goal: The evaluation seeks to understand the environmental and socioeconomic impacts of the program, with the goal of extracting lessons learned and identifying room for possible future improvement.
Study_location: Various areas in Mexico: Figure 4.1 shows PSAH eligible zones, 2004-2010
Sample_size: In order to assess the socioeconomic impacts of the PSAH program, we conducted a national-level field survey of a sample of beneficiary and matched nonbeneficiary applicants from the 2008 program cohort that were surveyed in 2011.
Comps_notes: Common property communities (poor) vs. private households
Stated_outcomes: Impacts on wealth (consumption effects, effects on productive and educational investment); participation costs
Portion_livelihood_amount: For private households, the average annual payment they received from the program is 35,777 pesos, which we estimate to be approximately 12% of household income.
Indicators: Average impacts of PSAH on consumption: food, durables, housing; Average impacts of PSAH on productive (agricultural) and educational investment
Outcome.direction_notes: Impacts on wealth: slightly positive in all cases but not statistically significant and not different across private vs. communal households; For productive investment impacts: "In the common properties, we observe a positive and marginally significant increase in the number of cattle (0.9 more per household) and a positive but not significant increase in the 46 number of small animals (2.5 more). We do not see sizeable or significant changes in the likelihood of investing in livestock infrastructure, agricultural inputs or agricultural equipment. However, we do observe a fairly large increase (around 15 percent relative to baseline) in the probability of attending school for children between the ages of 15 and 17 years old. We also see positive but insignificant increases in school attendance for children between 12-14 years old and 18-22 years old. In general, we do not see significant variation between common property ejidatarios and non-ejidatarios, although the marginal increase in cattle is significant and sizeable for beneficiary households (1.2 more, relative to the base mean of 3.5). There are no significant impacts for private households, although the coefficient on schooling implies a 10 percent increase relative to baseline in the probability of attending school for students between 12-22 years."

Authors: Alix-Garcia J, Aronson G, Radeloff V, Ramirez-Reyes C, Shapiro E, Sims K, Ya_ez-Pagans P
Title: Environmental and Socioeconomic Impacts of Mexico's Payments for Ecosystem Services Program
Author_affil: University of Wisconsin
Funding: Funding for this impact evaluation was provided by 3ieês donors, which include UKaid, the Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation, Hewlett Foundation and 12 other 3ie members that provide institutional support. A complete listing is provided on the 3ie website.
Stated_int: Mexicoês National Payments for Hydrological Services from 2003-2010. Mexicoês federal payments for hydrological services program (PSAH) began in 2003 and pays landowners to maintain forest cover under five-year contracts.
Desired_out: Reduced deforestation, improved ecosystem services, poverty alleviation
Study_goal: The evaluation seeks to understand the environmental and socioeconomic impacts of the program, with the goal of extracting lessons learned and identifying room for possible future improvement.
Study_location: Various areas in Mexico: Figure 4.1 shows PSAH eligible zones, 2004-2010
Sample_size: In order to assess the socioeconomic impacts of the PSAH program, we conducted a national-level field survey of a sample of beneficiary and matched nonbeneficiary applicants from the 2008 program cohort that were surveyed in 2011.
Comps_notes: Common property communities (poor) vs. private households
Stated_outcomes: Impacts on wealth (consumption effects, effects on productive and educational investment); participation costs
Indicators: Application, transportation and implementation costs
Outcome.direction_notes: Application costs are relatively small as a fraction of the overall payments across five years, constituting approximately .006 and .016 of total payments to common and private property beneficiaries, respectively. The most important household level costs of the program are related to labor engaged in forest conservation activities. Community leaders in beneficiary common properties report on average a greater number of worker days per year spent in fire prevention (+66 days), pest control (+17 days), and forest patrols (+142 days) compared to nonbeneficiary common properties. Valuing all laborãboth paid and unpaidãat the minimum wage, we estimate that the median ratio of the cost of additional labor in beneficiary communities relative to the amount of the payments is 0.84.

Authors: Almeyda, A.M.; Broadbent, E.N.; Wyman, M.S.; Durham, W.H.
Title: Ecotourism impacts in the Nicoya Peninsula, Costa Rica
Desired_out: Intervention = Punta Islita (PI) eco-lodge that is top-ranked by Certification of Sustainable Tourism in Costa Rica - thorugh art education, micro-enterprise development, local workforce training and promotion, economic equality of women and children through handicraft production and infrastructure improvements - for-profit hotel w/ community-based foundation - attempting to minimize impact on ecosystem while providing livelihood benefits
Study_goal: 1. What have been the main social, economic and environmental impacts ã positive and negativeãof ecotourism at the PI Eco-lodge on the Nicoya Peninsula? 2. Have conservation efforts at the lodge been of sufficient magnitude and duration to reduce deforestation? 3. Has PI had an identifiable impact on local environmental awareness, and specifically has it contributed to the spread of conservation ethics in the area?
Study_location: Punta Islita Hotel and surrounding area, Nicoya Peninsula
Stated_outcomes: Contribution to local livelihoods, changes in forest cover, environmental knowledge, impacts of eco-lodge on societal variables (e.g. alcoholism, drug addiction and prostitution)
Portion_livelihood_amount: 90% for PI employees
Indicators: Increase in numbers of persons employed by eco-lodge

Authors: Almeyda, A.M.; Broadbent, E.N.; Wyman, M.S.; Durham, W.H.
Title: Ecotourism impacts in the Nicoya Peninsula, Costa Rica
Desired_out: Intervention = Punta Islita (PI) eco-lodge that is top-ranked by Certification of Sustainable Tourism in Costa Rica - thorugh art education, micro-enterprise development, local workforce training and promotion, economic equality of women and children through handicraft production and infrastructure improvements - for-profit hotel w/ community-based foundation - attempting to minimize impact on ecosystem while providing livelihood benefits
Study_goal: 1. What have been the main social, economic and environmental impacts ã positive and negativeãof ecotourism at the PI Eco-lodge on the Nicoya Peninsula? 2. Have conservation efforts at the lodge been of sufficient magnitude and duration to reduce deforestation? 3. Has PI had an identifiable impact on local environmental awareness, and specifically has it contributed to the spread of conservation ethics in the area?

Forest_type: Other non-forest environment with planted trees, trees on farms, or tree farms

Authors: Ambrose-Oji B ; Lawrence A ; Stewart A ;
Title: Community based forest enterprises in Britain: Two organising typologies
Author_affil: Forest Research, FC England Office, 620 Coldharbour Lane, Bristol BS16 1EJ, United Kingdom
Funding: Forestry Commission Great Britain
Desired_out: Understanding development of community-based forest  enterprises
Study_goal: Understanding
Study_location: Great Britain
Stated_outcomes: Development of community based forest  enterprises
Indicators: Average traded income, grant income, turnover and surplus
Stated_mech: forest policy, and economic, social and political changes have all combined to provide opportunities for CF to move towards enterprise

Authors: Ambrose-Oji, B.
Title: The contribution of NTFPs to the livelihoods of the 'forest poor': Evidence from the tropical forest zone of south-west Cameroon
Desired_out: NTFP management; Forest conservation Sustained local livelihoods Integrated conservation and development projects
Study_goal: the central questions examined in this paper are the significance of the role of NTFPs in the livelihoods of poor groups of people, the type of forest and land use types NTFPs of importance are sourced from, and the patterns of NTFP collection in relation to species of conservation interest
Stated_outcomes: Income, Vegetation sources for goods, participatory wealth ranks
Portion_livelihood_amount: Env goods (~15% for rich, ~22% for upper middle, ~20% for middle, ~10% for poor, ~4% for very poor); NTFPs out of env. outcome and total - 2% for rich, 11% for upper middle, 14% for middle, 5% for poor, 6% for very poor
Indicators: fraction of income from NTFPs

Authors: Ambrose-Oji, B.
Title: The contribution of NTFPs to the livelihoods of the 'forest poor': Evidence from the tropical forest zone of south-west Cameroon
Desired_out: NTFP management; Forest conservation Sustained local livelihoods Integrated conservation and development projects
Study_goal: the central questions examined in this paper are the significance of the role of NTFPs in the livelihoods of poor groups of people, the type of forest and land use types NTFPs of importance are sourced from, and the patterns of NTFP collection in relation to species of conservation interest
Stated_outcomes: Income, Vegetation sources for goods, participatory wealth ranks
Indicators: Perceived access to forest resources
Outcome.direction_notes: Poor groups perceived that access to forest resources was difficult and under the control of richer groups

Authors: Ameha A ; Nielsen O J; Larsen H O;
Title: Impacts of access and benefit sharing on livelihoods and forest: Case of participatory forest management in Ethiopia
Author_affil: Department of Food and Resource Economics, University of Copenhagen
Funding: University of Copenhagen.
Desired_out: The effects of decentralised forest management on forest users' livelihoods
Study_goal: The aimof the present studywas thus to evaluate the impacts of PFM on three important facets of livelihoods in Ethiopia: (1) households' total income and forest income, (2) expenditure (consumption), and (3) livestock assets.
Study_location: two districts, Dendi and Dodola, in the Oromia Regional State of Ethiopia
Stated_outcomes: (1) households' total income and forest income, (2) expenditure (consumption), and (3) livestock assets.
Indicators: Income and assets
Stated_mech: The commercialisation of timber seems to be a viable pathway for sustainable forest management, provided sufficient resources are made available to a limited number of local forest users.

Authors: Amin V, Yok M
Title: Thematic Interpretation Approach in Environmental Adult Education
Author_affil: Sarawak Forestry Corporation, Sarawak, Malaysia
Stated_int: Environmental education: a generic course on the ecology and ecosystem of the tropical forest embedded in the syllabus of the Certificate in Park Guiding in Sarawakês National Parks and Nature Reserves conducted by Universiti Teknologi MARA, Sarawak, the approved training provider appointed by Sarawak Forestry.
Desired_out: To enhance their professionalism by improving their awareness, sensitize them to environmental issues, and care about the places.
Study_goal: Taking recognizance of environmental education and interpretation has been recognized as an important tool in creating enjoyable learning experiences, the purpose of this study is to elucidate the effectiveness of learning Ecology using thematic interpretation approach and integrating TEK, LEK and conventional science from the park guide perspective as adult learner.
Study_location: Sarawak state
Stated_outcomes: Test scores (performance of participants); pretest and posttest evaluation of the effectiveness; Thematic interpretative activity assessment
Indicators: Test scores (performance of participants=average scores); pretest and posttest evaluation of the effectiveness (reliability statistics: Cronbachês Alpha Coefficients); Thematic interpretative activity assessment (Reliability Statistics Cronbach's Alpha)

Authors: Andam KS, Ferraro PJ, Sims KRE, Healy A, Holland MB
Title: Protected areas reduced poverty in Costa Rica and Thailand
Linked_refs: Healy A, Jitsuchon S. 2007. Finding the poor in Thailand. Journal of Asian Economics 18(5): 739-759
Desired_out: Protected areas (15+ years old)
Study_goal: Examine long-term system-wide impacts of protected areas on poverty
Stated_outcomes: Poverty measures
Indicators: Poverty index (Costa Rica, Cavatassi et al. 2004), Poverty headcount (Thailand)-as indicated by monthly consumption under poverty line
Outcome.direction_notes: With matching of socio-economic characteristics and baseline information, protection seems to alleviate poverty in communities affected by protection.

Authors: Arriagada R, Sills E, Ferraro P, Pattanayak S
Title: Do Payments Pay Off? Evidence from Participation in Costa Ricaês PES Program
Author_affil: Millennium Nucleus Center for Socioeconomic Impact of Environmental Policies (CESIEP), Center of Applied Ecology and Sustainability (CAPES), Department of Agricultural Economics, Pontificia Universidad Cat„lica de Chile, Avenida Vicu_a Mackenna 4860, Macul, Santiago, Chile
Funding: This work was supported by the National Science Foundation (SES-0519194) (EOS), and Fondo Nacional de Financiamiento Forestal (FONAFIFO-Costa Rica) (EOS).
Stated_int: Costa Ricaês PES program
Desired_out: PES is a way to simultaneously improve conservation outcomes and the wellbeing of rural households who receive the payments
Study_goal: We add to the growing literature on conservation program impacts by using primary household survey data to evaluate the socioeconomic impacts of participation in Costa Ricaês PES program.
Study_location: 3 cantons in the region of SarapiquÍ located in northeastern Costa Rica: SarapiquÍ, Guacimo, and PococÍ.
Stated_outcomes: Estimated impacts of PSA on changes in welfare; Estimated impacts of PSA on changes in residence and farm investments
Indicators: Estimated impacts of PSA on changes in welfare; Estimated impacts of PSA on changes in residence and farm investments

Authors: Arriagada R, Sills E, Pattanayak S, Ferraro P
Title: Combining Qualitative and Quantitative Methods to Evaluate Participation in Costa Rica's Program of Payments for Environmental Services
Author_affil: School of Life Sciences, Arizona State University, Tempe, Arizona, USA
Stated_int: Payment for Environmental Services (PES): in this paper, the first nationwide and long-term program of payments for environmental services from tropical forests
Desired_out: Ecosystem services preservation, reduction in deforestation
Study_goal: Specifically, we describe the main driving forces of enrollment in the Costa Rican PES program using an iterative qualitative approach.
Study_location: SarapiquÍ Region
Sample_size: 50 program participants and 150 nonparticipants in the cantons of SarapiquÍ, Guacimo, and PococÍ
Study_duration: The survey elicited information on socio-economics and property characteristics (e.g., soil quality and slope), including land cover, in 1996 and 2005.
Stated_outcomes: Participation: Estimated Marginal Effects on the Propensity of a Property to have a PSA Contract
Indicators: Estimated Marginal Effects on the Propensity of a Property to have a PSA Contract
Outcome.direction_notes: PES forest protection contracts are most likely on large properties with absentee landowners originally from the Central Valley

Authors: Atela J, Minang P, Quinn C, Duguma L
Title: Implementing REDD_ at the local level: Assessing the key enablers for credible mitigation and sustainable livelihood outcomes
Author_affil: Sustainability Research Institute, School of Earth and Environment, University of Leeds, LS2 9JT, Leeds, UK
Funding: This research was funded by a University of Leeds International Research Scholarship and the ASB-Partnership (3109 6332 NORD- 886.01 GBL008) for the Tropical Forest Margin of the World Agroforestry Centre. The scoping study for this work was funded through fieldwork bursaries from the University of Leeds' Sustainability Research Institute.
Stated_int: Reducing emissions from avoided deforestation and forest degradation (REDD_) has gained both institutional legitimacy and critique on its ability to link carbon management to human development in practice
Desired_out: The global REDD_ design rules recognize emissions reductions and livelihoods as key outcomes expected from implementing REDD_
Study_goal: This paper aims to identify and discuss the set of local livelihood assets necessary for effective implementation of REDD_ at the local level drawing on evidence from the ongoing implementation of the Kasigau REDD_ project in Kenya. The specific objectives of the study are: (1) to evaluate how a globally linked REDD_ project engages the local community in its activities; (2) to identify the livelihood assets that significantly influence the project's ability to protect forests; (3) to analyse project impacts on livelihood assets and forest conservation; (4) to analyse the role of the State in the project's implementation. The next section unpacks policy implementation as this study's conceptual framework.
Study_location: Kasigau Corridor REDD+ project in Kenya's Coastal region
Stated_outcomes: Wilcoxon matched pairs signed test for differences between project impacts (intervention) and expected (control).
Indicators: Wilcoxon matched pairs signed test for differences between project impacts (intervention) and expected (control)
Outcome.direction_notes: Yes, see Table 4.

Authors: Bacon CM, Mendex VE, Gomez MEF, Stuart D, Flores SRD
Title: Are Sustainable Coffee Certifications Enough to Secure Farmer Livelihoods? The Millenium Development Goals and Nicaraguaês Fair Trade Cooperatives
Author_affil: University of California, Santa Cruz
Funding: Not indicated
Linked_refs: Part of the State of the Small-scale Farmer series which is a participatory action research (PAR) collaboration led by the University of Vermontês Agroecology and Rural Livelihoods research group, Oxfam America Community Agroecology Network, and other interested organizations Bacon, C. (2005) Confronting the coffee crisis: Can Fair Trade, organic and specialty coffees reduce small-scale farmer vulnerability in northern Nicaragua?, World Development, 33(3), pp. 497_511.
Stated_int: CECOCAFEN cooperative union (Fair Trade certified coffee)
Desired_out: Participation of small-scale farmers in Fair Trade certification program (CECOCAFEN cooperative union) in Nicaragua - ostensibly for economic development and stabilization following conflict (interpreted from text, unclear)
Study_goal: "This study contributes to a growing body of interdisciplinary research assessing household- and community-level effects of participation in sustainable coffee certification programs. It also uses long-term empirical research to raise critical questions about the ability of voluntary certification programs to deliver on their noble goals, and questions power asymmetries in value chain governance."
Stated_outcomes: Household level findings based on MDGs: Goal 1 (eradicate extreme poverty and hunger), Goal 2 (Achieve universal primary school education), Goal 3 (Promote gender quality and women's empowerment), Goal 7 (Support Environmental sustainability), Goal 8 (promote global partnership for development)
Indicators: Attendance to primary and secondary school, completed education
Outcome.direction_notes: Higher for households participating in cooperative

Authors: Bahuguna V
Title: Forests in the Economy of the Rural Poor: An Estimation of the Dependency Level
Author_affil: Deputy Inspector General of Forests, Ministry of Environment and Forests, India
Stated_int: contribution of the forests in the lives of the people in rural area
Desired_out: livelihood support and opportunities
Study_goal: To determine the contribution of forests to the rural economy
Study_location: 26 villages of M.P., Orissa, and Gujarat
Sample_size: 26 villages. Each family in these villages was interviewed.
Stated_outcomes: People's dependency on forests
Portion_livelihood_amount: Benefits derived by the people were reflected as a percentage of the total income of the household. The dependency on forests varies from 37% to 76% in these villages.
Indicators: Forestry income as a percentage of total household income
Outcome.direction_notes: See Figures 1-3 and Table 2: income from forests varies by village/state.
Stated_mech: Forests are, therefore, the source of life-support systems for millions of rural people and livestock populations. The management of India's forest resources is the key to progress in the field of agriculture and allied sectors, infrastructure, rural health and hygiene, water conservation and to overall socioeconomic development.

Authors: Bandyopadhyay S, Humavindu M, Shyamsundar P, Wang L
Title: Benefits to local communities from community conservancies in Namibia: an assessment
Author_affil: Senior Environmental Economist, Environment Department, World Bank, Washington, DC, USA
Funding: Donors from the Trust Fund for Environmental and Socially Sustainable Development; the Swedish Government for funding through Sida; and the UK Government for funding through the DFID
Stated_int: Community-oriented conservation in Namibia
Desired_out: economic development, empowerment, and conservation
Int_dur: Communal conservancies in Namibia established in 1995
Study_goal: This article evaluates the benefits of community-based activities in wildlife conservancies in Namibia by asking three questions: Do community conservancies contribute to an increase in household welfare? Are such programmes pro-poor; that is, do they improve welfare more for poorer households than for the less poor? Does participation in conservancy increase household welfare more for participants than non-participants?
Study_location: Two regions of Namibia, Kunene to the northwest and Caprivi in the northeast
Sample_size: Data from a Socio-Economic Household Survey (SEHS) of 1192 households in seven conservancies in the two regions, conducted by the WILD project and the Environmental Economics Unit of the Directorate of Environmental Affairs, MET
Stated_outcomes: Impact of established conservancy programmes on household welfare (measured by household income, per-capita income, household expenditure and per-capita expenditure) relative to comparator conservancies; Determinants and impacts of participation in the established conservancies
Portion_livelihood_amount: Table 3 shows average income from conservancies in each of the study areas
Indicators: household income, per-capita income, household expenditure and per-capita expenditure
Outcome.direction_notes: Yes, see Table 5

Title: A comparative study of two community-based conservation models in Nepal
Desired_out: Compare and contrast two models of successful community-based conservation mechanisms (Conservation Area Management Committees and Community Forest User Committees) in Nepal in terms of: * improved status of natural resources over past decade * improved management of natural resources

Authors: Barbier E
Title: Mangrove Dependency and the Livelihoods of Coastal Communities in Thailand
Journal: Book: CAB International 2006. Environment and Livelihoods in Tropical Coastal Zones (eds C.T. Hoanh, T.P. Tuong, J.W. Gowing and B. Hardy)
Author_affil: Department of Economics and Finance, University of Wyoming, Laramie, Wyoming, USA
Stated_int: The expansion of intensive shrimp farming in the coastal areas of southern Thailand has led to rapid conversion of mangroves (deforestation of mangrove forests)
Desired_out: Increase annual shrimp production through aquaculture
Int_dur: Mangrove conversion for aquaculture began in Thailand as early as 1974, but the boom in intensive shrimp farming through mangrove clearing took off in 1985 when the increasing demand for shrimp in Japan pushed up the border-equivalent price to $100/kg.
Study_goal: A case study of the labour allocation decisions of rural households from four representative villages illustrates the importance of mangroves to the livelihoods of coastal communities in Thailand. Study assesses the impacts of mangrove loss on labour allocation decisions.
Study_location: The four case study villages are Ban Khlong Khut and Ban Gong Khong in Nakhon Si Thammarat Province on the Gulf of Thailand, and Ban Sam Chong Tai and Ban Bang Pat in Phangnga Province on the Andaman Sea.
Sample_size: In total, 201 households were surveyed, although two households reported no direct or indirect income-producing activities that depended on mangroves and were excluded from the sample, leaving a total of 199 households.
Study_duration: A randomly stratified survey at the four village study sites was conducted during April and July 2000.
Stated_outcomes: Mangrove Loss and Labour Allocation in the Case Study Villages; Mangrove Dependency and Participation in Conservation Efforts
Portion_livelihood_amount: Mangrove-dependent income share of total income varies by outside employment by household type groups, and by village, and ranges from 66%-95%.
Indicators: Labor allocation changes as a result of mangrove forest loss
Outcome.direction_notes: The total effect of a loss in mangrove area is to reduce the supply of male labour to outside employment but to increase the supply of female members. Across the 199 surveyed households, a 1% decline in the local mangrove forests will cause the number of hours that males work in outside employment to decline by 0.7% while increasing the number of hours worked by females by 1.88%.

Authors: Barbier E
Title: Mangrove Dependency and the Livelihoods of Coastal Communities in Thailand
Journal: Book: CAB International 2006. Environment and Livelihoods in Tropical Coastal Zones (eds C.T. Hoanh, T.P. Tuong, J.W. Gowing and B. Hardy)
Author_affil: Department of Economics and Finance, University of Wyoming, Laramie, Wyoming, USA
Stated_int: The expansion of intensive shrimp farming in the coastal areas of southern Thailand has led to rapid conversion of mangroves (deforestation of mangrove forests)
Desired_out: Increase annual shrimp production through aquaculture
Int_dur: Mangrove conversion for aquaculture began in Thailand as early as 1974, but the boom in intensive shrimp farming through mangrove clearing took off in 1985 when the increasing demand for shrimp in Japan pushed up the border-equivalent price to $100/kg.
Study_goal: A case study of the labour allocation decisions of rural households from four representative villages illustrates the importance of mangroves to the livelihoods of coastal communities in Thailand. Study assesses the impacts of mangrove loss on labour allocation decisions.
Study_location: The four case study villages are Ban Khlong Khut and Ban Gong Khong in Nakhon Si Thammarat Province on the Gulf of Thailand, and Ban Sam Chong Tai and Ban Bang Pat in Phangnga Province on the Andaman Sea.
Sample_size: In total, 201 households were surveyed, although two households reported no direct or indirect income-producing activities that depended on mangroves and were excluded from the sample, leaving a total of 199 households.
Study_duration: A randomly stratified survey at the four village study sites was conducted during April and July 2000.
Stated_outcomes: Mangrove Loss and Labour Allocation in the Case Study Villages; Mangrove Dependency and Participation in Conservation Efforts
Indicators: Participation in conservation efforts of mangrove-dependent households
Outcome.direction_notes: The results show that the male decision to participate is mostly influenced by household awareness of community conservation efforts and use rules, as shown by the positive coefficient and highest marginal probability. The degree of mangrove-dependent income is the second-most important positive influence, with a marginal probability of 0.28. The householdês awareness of the environmental impact of shrimp farming is the other significant variable in the male equation. The positive coefficient value and marginal probability of 0.13 suggest that males from households that are aware of the negative environmental impact of shrimp farms are more likely to participate in replanting. For females, the degree of dependence of the household on mangrove-based income is significant at the 10% level and is the most important variable influencing its participation. Distance to the mangroves from the household is the next most important influence.

Authors: Barbier E
Title: In the wake of tsunami: Lessons learned from the household decision to replant mangroves in Thailand
Author_affil: Department of Economics and Finance, University of Wyoming, Laramie, WY 82071-3985, USA
Stated_int: Voluntary mangrove replanting schemes subsequent to the 2004 tsunami
Desired_out: Rehabilitate mangrove ecosystems as ••natural barriersêê to future tsunamis and other tropical storms
Study_goal: The analysis focuses on how various factors influence the willingness of mangrove dependent households to participate in local replanting efforts in four case study villages in Thailand.
Study_location: Two study sites, one in Nakhon Si Thammarat Province on the east coast, or Gulf of Thailand, and one in Phang-nga Province on the west coast, or the Indian Ocean (Andaman Sea), At each site households in two different villages were surveyed, Ban Sam Chong Tai and Ban Bang Pat in Phang-nga and Ban Khong Khut and Ban Gong Khong in Nakhon Si Thammarat.
Sample_size: 199 households from the four coastal Thai villages
Comps_notes: Sample split by the type of mangrove activities the household was predominately involved in (fish only; collect only; fish & collect)
Stated_outcomes: Participation in mangrove replanting
Portion_livelihood_amount: Table 2 shows Mangrove-dependent income share of total income (%), which varies by study site, varying from 66% to 95% depending on study site.
Indicators: Bivariate probit model for participation in mangrove replanting
Outcome.direction_notes: Yes, results on factors that either increase or decrease the probability of voluntary participation in mangrove replanting differ by gender: see Table 5.

Authors: Barli O, Baskent E, Turker M, Gedik T
Title: Analytical approach for analyzing and providing solutions for the conflicts among forest stakeholders across Turkey
Author_affil: Department of Social Science, Ataturk University, Erzurum/Turkey
Stated_int: Governance of forest resources in Turkey
Int_dur: Study says community forestry has been in place for 20 years, but the focus of the paper is not specifically on community forestry but rather on conflict around forest management in general, including with the state forest department.
Study_goal: This study primarily focuses on the recognition, analysis and resolution of forestry conflicts between forest villages and state forest organizations in Turkey.
Study_location: The three research areas include Aegean_Mediterranean region (Mersin, Antalya, Izmir, Mugla, Denizli provinces), Western Black Sea region (Zonguldak, Karabuk, Bartin provinces) and Eastern Black Sea region (Trabzon province).
Sample_size: 1065 individuals were statistically determined; 950 questionnaires collected.
Stated_outcomes: Conflicts between different groups (among individuals, between person and groups, among groups, between villagers and the State Forest Organization)
Indicators: Level and existence of conflict in each conflict category
Outcome.direction_notes: Yes, see Tables 2 & 3 in paper.

Indicators: Revenues and returns from timber

Authors: Beitl CM
Title: Cockles in custody: The role of common property arrangements in the ecological sustainability of mangrove fisheries on the Ecuadorian coast
Author_affil: Department of Anthropology, University of Georgia, Georgia, USA
Funding: National Science Foundation DDIG_BCS_0819376, the Wenner Gren Foundation, and the Fulbright program
Stated_int: Common property resource management
Desired_out: Custodia management plan has two main objectives: 1) mangrove conservation and restoration; 2) specific guidelines for the sustainable management of the cockle fishery
Study_goal: "...illustrate the relationship between the institutional arrangements of the custodia in Isla Costa Rica and their effects on the resource through a comparative analysis of three types of management regimes: 1) Custodia Managed Fishery, areas tightly managed by rotation and fishery closures in Isla Costa Rica; 2) Custodia Open Fishery, areas of the concession in which the  fishery is not tightly managed because of limited resources (human capital, lack of boats and money for gas); 3) Absence of Custodias, areas outside the concession frequented by collectors from Isla Costa Rica, neighboring communities, and the Port of Hualtaco and where access is de ned by a first-come, first-serve basis."
Study_location: Isla Costa Rica and Puerto Hualtaco
Stated_outcomes: Number of shells collected per hour (CPUE/hr), perception of benefits from custodias
Indicators: CPUE/hr
Outcome.direction_notes: Custodias collect more than non-custodias

Study_location: Isla Costa Rica and Puerto Hualtaco

Authors: Buchenrieder G, Balgah RA
Title: Sustaining livelihoods around community forests. What is the potential contribution of wildlife domestication?*
Author_affil: Martin-Luther-University Halle-Wittenberg (IAEW), _____, Halle (Saale), Germany
Funding: Foundation fiat panis in Ulm, Germany for the research project •Bridging the food and nutrition gap for hunger and poverty reduction. Understanding the dynamics and institutional framework for bushmeat in Cameroonê (no. 30/2010)
Stated_int: Kilum-Ijim Mountain Forest Project and community forests (1994 Forestry Law)
Desired_out: "The aim was to conserve the remaining forest and stop the depletion of the associated resources in collaboration with traditional authorities and the govern- ment. Long-term income-generating activities include bushmeat hunting, medicinal plant gathering, eco-tourism." "1994 Forestry Law allowed for communities to legally establish community forests based on management plans approved by appropriate government service"
Study_goal: "This paper focuses on the impact of community-based forest management on livelihoods and wildlife conservation around the Kilum-Ijim Mountain Forest in Cameroon."
Study_location: Elak, Jikijem villages (Bui Division); Mbessa, Ajung, Mbi, Anyajua (Boyo Division)

Authors: Buffum B, Lawrence A, Temphel KJ
Title: Equity in Community Forests in Bhutan
Author_affil: University of Rhode Island, Dept. of Natural Resources Science, 1 Greenhouse Road, Kingston, Rl 02881, USA
Funding: Swiss Agency for Development and Cooperation (SDC) and Helvetas
Stated_int: Community forestry
Desired_out: Initiated to increase community participation in management of national forests. Community forest legislation enables traditional users of national forest to apply or legal rights to manage block of national forest through formation of community forestry management group (CFMG) who liaise with Department of Forests on management plans.
Study_goal: Two main research questions addressed: 1). Does the initial experience with community forestry in Bhutan indicate emerging problems with political and economic equity as documented in neighbouring countries? 2). How do Bhutan's cultural, political and geographic conditions affect the equity of its community forestry program?
Study_location: Yakpugang CF (7 15'N, 91 16'E),  Masangdaza CF (7 15'N, 91 10'E), Shambayung CF (27 36'N, 90 53'E)
Stated_outcomes: Economic equity (number of timber trees allocated, firewood collection, number of livestock grazing, NWFP collection), political equity (participation in decision-making, perception of equitable benefit sharing)
Indicators: Number of timber trees allocated per household
Outcome.direction_notes: Poorest households and female-headed households receive larger timber allocations

Authors: Buffum B, Lawrence A, Temphel KJ
Title: Equity in Community Forests in Bhutan
Author_affil: University of Rhode Island, Dept. of Natural Resources Science, 1 Greenhouse Road, Kingston, Rl 02881, USA
Funding: Swiss Agency for Development and Cooperation (SDC) and Helvetas
Stated_int: Community forestry
Desired_out: Initiated to increase community participation in management of national forests. Community forest legislation enables traditional users of national forest to apply or legal rights to manage block of national forest through formation of community forestry management group (CFMG) who liaise with Department of Forests on management plans.
Study_goal: Two main research questions addressed: 1). Does the initial experience with community forestry in Bhutan indicate emerging problems with political and economic equity as documented in neighbouring countries? 2). How do Bhutan's cultural, political and geographic conditions affect the equity of its community forestry program?
Study_location: Yakpugang CF (7 15'N, 91 16'E),  Masangdaza CF (7 15'N, 91 10'E), Shambayung CF (27 36'N, 90 53'E)
Stated_outcomes: Economic equity (number of timber trees allocated, firewood collection, number of livestock grazing, NWFP collection), political equity (participation in decision-making, perception of equitable benefit sharing)
Indicators: Amount of dry firewood collection from CF
Outcome.direction_notes: Does not seem to differ significantly between socio-economic groups, women collect more than men

Authors: Buffum B, Lawrence A, Temphel KJ
Title: Equity in Community Forests in Bhutan
Author_affil: University of Rhode Island, Dept. of Natural Resources Science, 1 Greenhouse Road, Kingston, Rl 02881, USA
Funding: Swiss Agency for Development and Cooperation (SDC) and Helvetas
Stated_int: Community forestry
Desired_out: Initiated to increase community participation in management of national forests. Community forest legislation enables traditional users of national forest to apply or legal rights to manage block of national forest through formation of community forestry management group (CFMG) who liaise with Department of Forests on management plans.
Study_goal: Two main research questions addressed: 1). Does the initial experience with community forestry in Bhutan indicate emerging problems with political and economic equity as documented in neighbouring countries? 2). How do Bhutan's cultural, political and geographic conditions affect the equity of its community forestry program?
Study_location: Yakpugang CF (7 15'N, 91 16'E),  Masangdaza CF (7 15'N, 91 10'E), Shambayung CF (27 36'N, 90 53'E)
Stated_outcomes: Economic equity (number of timber trees allocated, firewood collection, number of livestock grazing, NWFP collection), political equity (participation in decision-making, perception of equitable benefit sharing)
Indicators: Number of grazing livestock owned
Outcome.direction_notes: Number of livestock owned decreased overall before and after implementation of CF, but establishment of CF did not seem to alter location or percentage of households using CF for grazing. Wealthier households tended to have more livestock

Authors: Buffum B, Lawrence A, Temphel KJ
Title: Equity in Community Forests in Bhutan
Author_affil: University of Rhode Island, Dept. of Natural Resources Science, 1 Greenhouse Road, Kingston, Rl 02881, USA
Funding: Swiss Agency for Development and Cooperation (SDC) and Helvetas
Stated_int: Community forestry
Desired_out: Initiated to increase community participation in management of national forests. Community forest legislation enables traditional users of national forest to apply or legal rights to manage block of national forest through formation of community forestry management group (CFMG) who liaise with Department of Forests on management plans.
Study_goal: Two main research questions addressed: 1). Does the initial experience with community forestry in Bhutan indicate emerging problems with political and economic equity as documented in neighbouring countries? 2). How do Bhutan's cultural, political and geographic conditions affect the equity of its community forestry program?
Study_location: Yakpugang CF (7 15'N, 91 16'E),  Masangdaza CF (7 15'N, 91 10'E), Shambayung CF (27 36'N, 90 53'E)
Stated_outcomes: Economic equity (number of timber trees allocated, firewood collection, number of livestock grazing, NWFP collection), political equity (participation in decision-making, perception of equitable benefit sharing)
Indicators: Collection and sale of NWFPs
Outcome.direction_notes: Only 12% of households actually sold NWFPs while many gathered for personal consumption. No difference between socio-economic or gender groups

Authors: Buffum B, Lawrence A, Temphel KJ
Title: Equity in Community Forests in Bhutan
Author_affil: University of Rhode Island, Dept. of Natural Resources Science, 1 Greenhouse Road, Kingston, Rl 02881, USA
Funding: Swiss Agency for Development and Cooperation (SDC) and Helvetas
Stated_int: Community forestry
Desired_out: Initiated to increase community participation in management of national forests. Community forest legislation enables traditional users of national forest to apply or legal rights to manage block of national forest through formation of community forestry management group (CFMG) who liaise with Department of Forests on management plans.
Study_goal: Two main research questions addressed: 1). Does the initial experience with community forestry in Bhutan indicate emerging problems with political and economic equity as documented in neighbouring countries? 2). How do Bhutan's cultural, political and geographic conditions affect the equity of its community forestry program?
Study_location: Yakpugang CF (7 15'N, 91 16'E),  Masangdaza CF (7 15'N, 91 10'E), Shambayung CF (27 36'N, 90 53'E)
Stated_outcomes: Economic equity (number of timber trees allocated, firewood collection, number of livestock grazing, NWFP collection), political equity (participation in decision-making, perception of equitable benefit sharing)
Indicators: Participation in decision-making and perception of equitable benefit sharing
Outcome.direction_notes: Most communities members felt open to participation, many positions held by women. Most responded that benefit sharing was equitable, but 31% did not feel they had received benefits yet.

Authors: Bukenya M, Johnsen FH, Gombya-Ssembajjwe WS
Title: ENVIRONMENTAL AND EXCHANGE ENTITLEMENTS FROM EUCALYPTUS WOODLOTS: THE CASE OF MUKONO DISTRICT IN UGANDA
Author_affil: Makerere University, Faculty of Forestry and Nature Conservation, P.O. Box 7062, Kampala, Uganda
Funding: Norwegian Agency for Development Cooperation (Norad)
Stated_int: Cultivation of Eucalyptus through taungya techniques
Desired_out: "Taungya is a form of land rent in kind where the taungya farmers don't directly pay the tree farmers but provide free labour for certain tasks such as clearing the land, weeding and biomass waste management to tree farmers who in tum allow them to grow their crops under trees. Under taungya arrangement, there is normally no written agreement between the tree farmer and taungya practitioner. The latter party according to the unwritten agreement must clear or prepare the land and grow annual crops. Taungya farmers must weed trees and are not allowed to kill, destroy or vandalise any young plant or undertake any tree tending operations."
Study_goal: "How and when do different resource claimants gain access to the benefits from woodlots? How are these entitlements appropriated?"
Study_location: Mukono district
Forest_type: Other non-forest environment with planted trees, trees on farms, or tree farms
Stated_outcomes: Employment from taungya practices, collection of firewood
Indicators: Percent respondents employed in wage labor maintaining woodlots
Outcome.direction_notes: Women more employed than men

Authors: Campos P, Daly-Hassen H, Oviedo JL, Ovando P, Chebil A
Title: Accounting for single and aggregated forest incomes: Application to public cork oak forests in Jerez (Spain) and Iteimia (Tunisia)
Author_affil: Institute of Economics and Geography, Spanish Council for Scientific Research (CSIC), Pinar 25, 28006 Madrid, Spain
Funding: Spanish Agency for International Cooperation (AECI), the European Commission, and the Tunisian Ministry of Research
Linked_refs: Sustainable silvopastoral management models in Mediterranean forests: Application to cork oak forests in Spain (Cadiz) and Tunisia (Ain Draham); and Conservation and Restoration of European cork oak woodlands: a unique ecosystem in the balance (CREOAK)
Stated_int: Cork agroforestry/silvopastoral system ownership system
Desired_out: "In the case of Jerez, the public landowner has a right to exclude others from using the forest resources; community employment and natural resource conservation criteria determine Jerez's management. In the Iteimia case, the public landowner has regulated free-use rights for livestock grazing, firewood and crops so that local households can meet their needs and improve their income. Households operate by maximizing their income from the full employment of their own family workforce"
Study_goal: "The major objective of this paper is to improve the application of AAS methodology to two public Mediterranean cork oak forest case studies (Jerez in Spain and Iteimia in Tunisia). To carry out this approach, we compare land ownership, labour market and local economy similarities and dissimilarities in each case study and the differences in the cork oak forest management objectives. Our aim is not to carry out a statistical inference but to perform a comparative income measurement analysis of two cork oak forest with the advantage that there is detailed microeconomic data that enables us to make an in-depth analysis of the natural resource conservation and total commercial income measure- ment from the perspectives of Spain's developed economy and Tunisia's developing economy"
Study_location: Jerez estate (Alcornocales Natural Park, Andalusia), Iteimia estate (Ain Snoussi region)
Stated_outcomes: Labour income, capital income
Indicators: Capital income from aggregate national microeconomic statistics
Outcome.direction_notes: Negative capital income in Jerez under developed economic context with natural area protection, positive capital income in Iteimia in subsistence economy

Authors: Campos P, Daly-Hassen H, Oviedo JL, Ovando P, Chebil A
Title: Accounting for single and aggregated forest incomes: Application to public cork oak forests in Jerez (Spain) and Iteimia (Tunisia)
Author_affil: Institute of Economics and Geography, Spanish Council for Scientific Research (CSIC), Pinar 25, 28006 Madrid, Spain

Title: Accounting for single and aggregated forest incomes: Application to public cork oak forests in Jerez (Spain) and Iteimia (Tunisia)
Author_affil: Institute of Economics and Geography, Spanish Council for Scientific Research (CSIC), Pinar 25, 28006 Madrid, Spain
Funding: Spanish Agency for International Cooperation (AECI), the European Commission, and the Tunisian Ministry of Research
Linked_refs: Sustainable silvopastoral management models in Mediterranean forests: Application to cork oak forests in Spain (Cadiz) and Tunisia (Ain Draham); and Conservation and Restoration of European cork oak woodlands: a unique ecosystem in the balance (CREOAK)
Stated_int: Cork agroforestry/silvopastoral system ownership system
Desired_out: "In the case of Jerez, the public landowner has a right to exclude others from using the forest resources; community employment and natural resource conservation criteria determine Jerez's management. In the Iteimia case, the public landowner has regulated free-use rights for livestock grazing, firewood and crops so that local households can meet their needs and improve their income. Households operate by maximizing their income from the full employment of their own family workforce"
Study_goal: "The major objective of this paper is to improve the application of AAS methodology to two public Mediterranean cork oak forest case studies (Jerez in Spain and Iteimia in Tunisia). To carry out this approach, we compare land ownership, labour market and local economy similarities and dissimilarities in each case study and the differences in the cork oak forest management objectives. Our aim is not to carry out a statistical inference but to perform a comparative income measurement analysis of two cork oak forest with the advantage that there is detailed microeconomic data that enables us to make an in-depth analysis of the natural resource conservation and total commercial income measure- ment from the perspectives of Spain's developed economy and Tunisia's developing economy"
Study_location: Jerez estate (Alcornocales Natural Park, Andalusia), Iteimia estate (Ain Snoussi region)
Forest_type: Other non-forest environment with planted trees, trees on farms, or tree farms
Stated_outcomes: Labour income, capital income
Indicators: Capital income from aggregate national microeconomic statistics
Outcome.direction_notes: Negative capital income in Jerez under developed economic context with natural area protection, positive capital income in Iteimia in subsistence economy

Authors: Campos P, Daly-Hassen H, Oviedo JL, Ovando P, Chebil A

Authors: Cao S, Wang X, Song Y, Chen L, Feng Q
Title: Impacts of the Natural Forest Conservation Program on the livelihoods of residents of Northwestern China: Perceptions of residents affected by the program
Author_affil: College of Water and Soil Conservation, Beijing Forestry University, Beijing, 100083, PR China
Funding: Excellent Youth Project of the National Natural Foundation of China (40501012)
Stated_int: Forest restoration/regeneration
Desired_out: Natural Forest Conservation Program (NCFP) implemented by government as a conservation set-aside program - banning further logging of natural forests in watersheds of major rivers, reduce timber harvests, conserve natural forests, afforest/revegetate forests, and run Grain for Green Project
Study_goal: "Our study aimed to highlight how the attitudes of those affected by the government's policies (NFCP) will interact with the policies to enable or constrain rural environmental restoration and how this interaction will affect livelihoods based on the affected resources"
Study_location: Ziwuling Mountains, Yan'an City, Shaanzi Province
Stated_outcomes: Has the ban on grazing and logging affected your income? Your livelihood?
Indicators: Perception of impact on income
Outcome.direction_notes: increase in cost for livestock workers, negative impact on income more often perceived by lower income, more women felt adversely affected

Authors: Cao S, Wang X, Song Y, Chen L, Feng Q
Title: Impacts of the Natural Forest Conservation Program on the livelihoods of residents of Northwestern China: Perceptions of residents affected by the program

Stated_outcomes: Has the ban on grazing and logging affected your income? Your livelihood?
Indicators: Unemployment rate
Outcome.direction_notes: unemployment increased for forest workers

Authors: Cao S, Zhong B, Yue H, Zeng H, Zeng J
Title: Development and testing of a sustainable environmental restoration policy on eradicating the poverty trap in Chinaês Changting County
Author_affil: College of Water and Soil Conservation, Beijing Forestry University, Beijing, 100083, China
Stated_int: Property rights reform, payments for ecosystem services
Desired_out: Reformed property rights for forested land, allocating 90% of lands to individual farmers. As this did not protect trees as expected, county government initiated a new development policy in 2000 to promote both environmental conservation and poverty reduction. "The policy provided annual compensation of RMB 10 million (US$1 equaled approximately RMB 8.27 in 2000) from the provinceês budget in areas that were experiencing the heaviest soil erosion." Compensation was for soil and water conservation practices.
Study_goal: "In the present paper, our goals were to evaluate the potential links between environmental policy and environmental and social sustainability by presenting an approach that combines the need to protect both nature and society. This approach provides a good example of how to improve the benefits of environmental restoration while simultaneously protecting the livelihoods of those who are most directly affected by the program. Our study had the major objective of comparing the effectiveness of subsidy programs that promote environmental restoration with and without additional measures taken to ensure the livelihoods of the residents will be protected when the subsidies end."
Study_location: 5 villages in each of 4 towns (Cewu, Hetian, Sanzhou, Zhuotian) in Changting County. 5 towns in 14 villages outside of the project area
Stated_outcomes: Economic improvements (methane generation facilities added, number of workers employed in soil and water conservation, income from alternative livelihoods - pigs, fruit trees, aquaculture)
Indicators: Methane generation facilities added

Authors: Cao S, Zhong B, Yue H, Zeng H, Zeng J
Title: Development and testing of a sustainable environmental restoration policy on eradicating the poverty trap in Chinaês Changting County
Author_affil: College of Water and Soil Conservation, Beijing Forestry University, Beijing, 100083, China

Stated_outcomes: Economic improvements (methane generation facilities added, number of workers employed in soil and water conservation, income from alternative livelihoods - pigs, fruit trees, aquaculture)
Indicators: Employment in soil and water conservation jobs
Outcome.direction_notes: 12.4% increase in workforce over time (2000-2007)

Authors: Chand N, Kerr GN, Bigsby H
Title: Production efficiency of community forest management in Nepal
Author_affil: REDD-Forestry & Climate Change Cell, Babar Mahal, Kathmandu, Nepal
Stated_int: Community forest management
Desired_out: "The Forest Act 1993 and the Forest Regulation 1995 have guaranteed local communities rights to use forest resources. The Nepalese government intends to hand over all accessible forest to local communities for sustainable management and utilisation"
Study_goal: "This article analyses the production performance of CFs in terms of benefits deriving from forest products at the community level and investigates the relationship between forest production and various social, economic and environmental factors"
Study_location: Makawanpur and Kavre palanchok districts
Stated_outcomes: Relationship between production of forest and economic, social benefits
Indicators: Monetary forest income - direct sale of goods, Monetary forest income - wage labor, Monetary forest income - value addition/entrepreneurship, Physical forest income - consumption
Outcome.direction_notes: Socio-economic factors impact direct benefits - e.g. negative (distance to the government office, CF size, and group heterogeneity) and positive (links to the market, forest products dependency, and the number of households in the community)

Authors: Chen H, Ting Z, Krott M, Calvo JF, Ganesh SP, Makoto I
Title: Measurement and evaluation of livelihood assets in sustainable forest commons governance
Author_affil: Institute of Forest and Nature Conservation Policy, Faculty of Forest Science and Forest Ecology, Georg-August-University Goettingen, Busgenweg 3, D-37077 Goettingen, Germany
Funding: Unclear
Linked_refs: Chen et al. 2013 - Community forestry management and livelihood development in northwest China: integration of governance, project design, and community participation, Chen et al. 2012 - Livelihood sustainability and community based co-management of forest resources in China: Changes and improvement
Stated_int: Community-based co-management of forest. Baishuijiang National Nature Reserve.
Desired_out: Baishuijiang National Nature Reserve was established in 1978 to conserve forest ecosystems and biodiversity
Study_goal: Answer two hypotheses: "Hypothesis A. Community Based Co-Management (CBCM) has changed the livelihood assets of local community residents in the study area. Hypothesis B. The changes in livelihood assets are different between participators in CBCM and non-participators."
Study_location: Baishuijiang National Nature Reserve, which is located in Wenxian County, Gansu Province
Stated_outcomes: 5 capitals (physical, natural, human, financial, social)
Indicators: Household fixed assets, household durable goods, household energy structure
Outcome.direction_notes: Participators seem to have higher indicator weight than non-participators
