Authors: Chen HY, Zhu T, Krott M, Maddox D
Title: Community forestry management and livelihood development in northwest China: integration of governance, project design, and community participation
Author_affil: Chair of Forest and Nature Conservation Policy, Georg-August-University Goettingen, Buesgenweg 3, 37077 Goettingen, Germany
Funding: Unclear
Stated_int: Community-based co-management of forest resources
Desired_out: "Key characteristics of CBCM projects are as follows. (1) CBCM projects provide non-agricultural work and employment information from outside the community to help participants improve their livelihood condition. (2) They facilitate the positive participation of local community residents in the management of natural resources. (3) Most CBCM projects aim to communicate to participants a stronger awareness of forest resource protection. Increased consciousness typically results in reduced or more conservative collection of forest products. (4) They provide training on agricultural techniques to enable farmers to improve crop production, optimize cultivation practices, and increase agricultural production outcomes"
Study_goal: "...analyze the changes in livelihood development and community forestry management under the influence of CBCM projects. Analyses focused on four groups of attributes: social correlates of current and future participation; fair- ness and CBCM performance; forest health; and economic benefits from CBCM participation"
Study_location: Gansu Baishuijiang National Nature Reserve, located in Wenxian County, Gansu Province, China
Stated_outcomes: Perceptions of economic benefits of CBCM participation
Outcome.direction_notes: Those who participated had greater family assets, income, and property

Authors: Chhetri BBK, Larsen HO, Smith-Hall C
Title: Law Enforcement in Community Forestry: Consequences for the Poor
Author_affil: Institute of Forestry, Pokhara Campus, P.O Box: 43, Hariyokharka, Pokhara, Nepal
Funding: University of Copenhagen and the Consultative Research Committee (FFU) at the Danish Ministry of Foreign Affairs, Grant No. 104.Dan.8.L.716
Stated_int: Community Forestry program
Desired_out: Community-based forest management implemented as part of effort to decentralize forest management. Runs as a binding agreement between each community forest user group (CFUG) and Nepalese government with approved 5 year work plans that specific management objectives and activities, with methods of forest protection.
Study_goal: The study attempts to "(1) documents officially recorded forest crimes, (2) explores perceptions of the nature, severity and causes of forest crimes in community forests held by main stakeholders at local and central levels, and (3) investigates current forest crimes and penalties in 14 case CFUGs."
Study_location: Simjung and Gyachchok CFUGs of Gorkha District
Stated_outcomes: Impact of forest law enforcement on economic equity, impact of forest law enforcement on social equity
Indicators: Amount of fines for violating forest rules
Outcome.direction_notes: In total, poor were fined 9% of total value of illegally extracted products while wealthy fined 33% of total value of illegally extracted products

Authors: Chhetri BBK, Larsen HO, Smith-Hall C
Title: Law Enforcement in Community Forestry: Consequences for the Poor
Author_affil: Institute of Forestry, Pokhara Campus, P.O Box: 43, Hariyokharka, Pokhara, Nepal
Funding: University of Copenhagen and the Consultative Research Committee (FFU) at the Danish Ministry of Foreign Affairs, Grant No. 104.Dan.8.L.716
Stated_int: Community Forestry program
Desired_out: Community-based forest management implemented as part of effort to decentralize forest management. Runs as a binding agreement between each community forest user group (CFUG) and Nepalese government with approved 5 year work plans that specific management objectives and activities, with methods of forest protection.
Study_goal: The study attempts to "(1) documents officially recorded forest crimes, (2) explores perceptions of the nature, severity and causes of forest crimes in community forests held by main stakeholders at local and central levels, and (3) investigates current forest crimes and penalties in 14 case CFUGs."
Study_location: Simjung and Gyachchok CFUGs of Gorkha District
Stated_outcomes: Impact of forest law enforcement on economic equity, impact of forest law enforcement on social equity
Indicators: Stakeholder perception of forest crimes and crime patterns
Outcome.direction_notes: Poor perceived to more often by caught for illegal collection of firewood and thatching grass, and not paying fees - implies rules have greater impact on physical consumption of poor

Authors: Chowdury MSH, Kolke M, Rana P, Muhammed N
Title: Community development through collaborative management of protected areas: Evidence from Bangladesh with a case of Rema-Kalenga Wildlife Sanctuary
Journal: International Journal of Sustainable Development & World Ecology
Author_affil: Forest Policy Laboratory, Department of Forest Science, Faculty of Agriculture, Shinshu University, 8304 Minamiminowa-Mura, Nagano-Ken 399-4598, Japan
Funding: Japanês Ministry of Science & Education and Japan Society for the Promotion of Science (JSPS)
Stated_int: Protection of forested areas
Desired_out: Using co-management in conjunction with protected areas
Study_goal: The present study was conducted in Rema-Kalenga Wildlife Sanctuary (RKWS), one of the five pilot sites of the project, to assess the impact of co-management on the socio-economic condition of the local communities.
Study_location: Rema-Kalenga Wildlife Sanctuary - 24_ 06__24_ 14_ N latitude and 91_ 34__91_ 41_ E longitude
Stated_outcomes: Allocation of agricultural land from forest department, collection of NWFP, consumption of fuel wood, annual income, social cohesion
Indicators: Land holdings of agricultural land
Outcome.direction_notes: Respondents in forest, w/ major stakes to sanctuary and belonging to tribal community and male were allotted higher amounts of land.

Authors: Chowdury MSH, Kolke M, Rana P, Muhammed N
Title: Community development through collaborative management of protected areas: Evidence from Bangladesh with a case of Rema-Kalenga Wildlife Sanctuary
Journal: International Journal of Sustainable Development & World Ecology

Authors: Clements T, John A, Nielsen K, An D, Tan S, Milner-Gulland EJ
Title: Payments for biodiversity conservation in the context of weak institutions: Comparison of three programs from Cambodia
Author_affil: Wildlife Conservation Society, 2300 Southern Boulevard, Bronx, NY 10460, USA; Department of Zoology, University of Cambridge, Downing Street, Cambridge, CB2 3EJ, UK
Funding: United States Agency for International Development (USAID), under the terms of the TransLinks Cooperative Agreement No. EPP-A-00-06-00014-00 to WCS, the University of Cambridge and a Royal Society Wolfson Research Merit award to E.J.M.G., as well as support from WCS, Edith McBean, the Global Environment Facility, United Nations Development Program, the Danish International Cooperation Agency, the UK Department for International Development (DfID), IUCN Netherlands and the Jeniam Foundation
Stated_int: Payments for ecosystem services, community-based ecotourism initiated as a complement to existing protected areas
Desired_out: Payments for ecosystems services established to complement protected area management - payments for participatory land-use planning process for forest management and establishment of community-based ecotourism
Study_goal: The comparison focuses on the institutional effectiveness of the programs: the institutional arrangements, the distribution of costs and benefits, and the conservation results observed
Study_location: Tmatboey (Kulen Promtep Wildlife Sanctuary), Preah Vihear Protected Forest
Stated_outcomes: Distribution of costs and benefits - degree of benefit-sharing, decrease in administrative costs
Indicators: Level of communal development funds and mechanisms for benefit sharing
Outcome.direction_notes: Bird program benefits least amount of people, while agri-environment benefits the most

Authors: Clements T, John A, Nielsen K, An D, Tan S, Milner-Gulland EJ
Title: Payments for biodiversity conservation in the context of weak institutions: Comparison of three programs from Cambodia
Author_affil: Wildlife Conservation Society, 2300 Southern Boulevard, Bronx, NY 10460, USA; Department of Zoology, University of Cambridge, Downing Street, Cambridge, CB2 3EJ, UK
Funding: United States Agency for International Development (USAID), under the terms of the TransLinks Cooperative Agreement No. EPP-A-00-06-00014-00 to WCS, the University of Cambridge and a Royal Society Wolfson Research Merit award to E.J.M.G., as well as support from WCS, Edith McBean, the Global Environment Facility, United Nations Development Program, the Danish International Cooperation Agency, the UK Department for International Development (DfID), IUCN Netherlands and the Jeniam Foundation
Stated_int: Payments for ecosystem services, community-based ecotourism initiated as a complement to existing protected areas
Desired_out: Payments for ecosystems services established to complement protected area management - payments for participatory land-use planning process for forest management and establishment of community-based ecotourism
Study_goal: The comparison focuses on the institutional effectiveness of the programs: the institutional arrangements, the distribution of costs and benefits, and the conservation results observed
Study_location: Tmatboey (Kulen Promtep Wildlife Sanctuary), Preah Vihear Protected Forest
Stated_outcomes: Distribution of costs and benefits - degree of benefit-sharing, decrease in administrative costs
Indicators: Administrative costs
Outcome.direction_notes: Administrative costs were generally lower for the bird nest program (simple institutional arrangement) versus higher for the complex ecotourism and agri-environmental program

Authors: Danesh Miah M, Abubokor Siddik M, Yong Shin M
Title: Socio-economic and environmental impacts of casuarina shelterbelt in the Chittagong coast of Bangladesh
Author_affil: Institute of Forestry & Environmental Sciences, University of Chittagong, Chittagong 4331, Bangladesh
Stated_int: Causarina shelterbelt - coastal plantation
Desired_out: Planting of Casuarina shelterbelts to protect coastal human communities from cyclone and tidal surge and serve as a carbon sink
Study_goal: Understanding public perceptions of the impacts of the casuarina shelterbelt in the Parki beach, Chittagong as well as climatic effect (carbon stock measurement).
Study_location: Parki beach, Anowara Upazila, Chittagong District (22 070 and 22 160 north and 91 490 and 91 580 east)
Stated_outcomes: Perceptions of: environmental impacts (protection from winds, storm surge, cyclonic storms), economic impacts (growth of crops, timber value, supply of fuelwood), social impacts (aesthetic value, tourism, social crimes), carbon density
Indicators: Perception of protection from storm surge, cyclonic storms and wind

Authors: Danesh Miah M, Abubokor Siddik M, Yong Shin M
Title: Socio-economic and environmental impacts of casuarina shelterbelt in the Chittagong coast of Bangladesh
Author_affil: Institute of Forestry & Environmental Sciences, University of Chittagong, Chittagong 4331, Bangladesh

Indicators: Supply of fuelwood

Authors: Danesh Miah M, Abubokor Siddik M, Yong Shin M

Indicators: Level of perceived social crime

Authors: Das N
Title: Impact of participatory forestry program on sustainable rural livelihoods: Lessons from an Indian province
Author_affil: Centre for Studies in Social Sciences, Calcutta (CSSSC), India
Stated_int: Joint Forest Management (JFM) and female forest protection committees (FPC)
Desired_out: Participatory approach to community forestry - institutionalization of forest protection with involvement of stakeholders. Specifically, devolution of decision-maker power and responsibility to local communications under community titling property rights approach to manage forest lands. Specifically within the JFM program, West Bengal establishment of female forest protection committees (FPC) to empower women in decision-making sphere.
Study_goal: Assess the impact of participatory forestry initiatives on livelihoods sustainability across the socioeconomic groups of rural poor in forest fringe areas at the micro level
Study_location: Agua, Malibona, Brindabanpur, Belboni, Baragari, Katul-II, Kustara, Majdiha villages in Bankura district, West Bengal
Stated_outcomes: Natural capital, physical capital, financial capital, human capital, social capital
Portion_livelihood_amount: Varies, see Table 5 in paper
Indicators: Stream of forest products before/after, steam of subsidiary benefits before/after
Outcome.direction_notes: Wage labor and collection of forest products increased after implementation of JFM for all participant communities. However, level of increased varied by socio-economic level with lower land-based groups and female FPC groups being moderately more successful.

Authors: Das N
Title: Impact of participatory forestry program on sustainable rural livelihoods: Lessons from an Indian province
Author_affil: Centre for Studies in Social Sciences, Calcutta (CSSSC), India
Stated_int: Joint Forest Management (JFM) and female forest protection committees (FPC)
Desired_out: Participatory approach to community forestry - institutionalization of forest protection with involvement of stakeholders. Specifically, devolution of decision-maker power and responsibility to local communications under community titling property rights approach to manage forest lands. Specifically within the JFM program, West Bengal establishment of female forest protection committees (FPC) to empower women in decision-making sphere.
Study_goal: Assess the impact of participatory forestry initiatives on livelihoods sustainability across the socioeconomic groups of rural poor in forest fringe areas at the micro level
Study_location: Agua, Malibona, Brindabanpur, Belboni, Baragari, Katul-II, Kustara, Majdiha villages in Bankura district, West Bengal
Stated_outcomes: Natural capital, physical capital, financial capital, human capital, social capital
Indicators: Specific and durable assets (e.g. livestock) and farm assets (land, implements)
Outcome.direction_notes: Generally, JFM households had more assets than non-JFM across all income groups

Authors: Das N
Title: Impact of participatory forestry program on sustainable rural livelihoods: Lessons from an Indian province
Author_affil: Centre for Studies in Social Sciences, Calcutta (CSSSC), India
Stated_int: Joint Forest Management (JFM) and female forest protection committees (FPC)
Desired_out: Participatory approach to community forestry - institutionalization of forest protection with involvement of stakeholders. Specifically, devolution of decision-maker power and responsibility to local communications under community titling property rights approach to manage forest lands. Specifically within the JFM program, West Bengal establishment of female forest protection committees (FPC) to empower women in decision-making sphere.
Study_goal: Assess the impact of participatory forestry initiatives on livelihoods sustainability across the socioeconomic groups of rural poor in forest fringe areas at the micro level
Study_location: Agua, Malibona, Brindabanpur, Belboni, Baragari, Katul-II, Kustara, Majdiha villages in Bankura district, West Bengal
Stated_outcomes: Natural capital, physical capital, financial capital, human capital, social capital
Indicators: Income potential as proxy for savings
Outcome.direction_notes: Income from forest sources contributes significantly more to potential savings of landless and marginal landholders than small landholders for JFM villages. JFM villagers tend to rely heavily on forest for income (61% to 80-85% after implementation)

Authors: Das N
Title: Impact of participatory forestry program on sustainable rural livelihoods: Lessons from an Indian province
Author_affil: Centre for Studies in Social Sciences, Calcutta (CSSSC), India
Stated_int: Joint Forest Management (JFM) and female forest protection committees (FPC)
Desired_out: Participatory approach to community forestry - institutionalization of forest protection with involvement of stakeholders. Specifically, devolution of decision-maker power and responsibility to local communications under community titling property rights approach to manage forest lands. Specifically within the JFM program, West Bengal establishment of female forest protection committees (FPC) to empower women in decision-making sphere.

Study_location: Agua, Malibona, Brindabanpur, Belboni, Baragari, Katul-II, Kustara, Majdiha villages in Bankura district, West Bengal
Stated_outcomes: Natural capital, physical capital, financial capital, human capital, social capital
Indicators: Expenditure on education and healthcare
Outcome.direction_notes: JFM households, particular landless and marginal landholders saw increase in expenditure after implementation of JFM compared to non-JFM.

Authors: Das N
Title: Impact of participatory forestry program on sustainable rural livelihoods: Lessons from an Indian province
Author_affil: Centre for Studies in Social Sciences, Calcutta (CSSSC), India
Stated_int: Joint Forest Management (JFM) and female forest protection committees (FPC)
Desired_out: Participatory approach to community forestry - institutionalization of forest protection with involvement of stakeholders. Stated_outcomes: Natural capital, physical capital, financial capital, human capital, social capital
Indicators: Groups & network, trust & solidarity, collective action & participation, information & communication, social cohesion & inclusion, empowerment & political action
Outcome.direction_notes: In general, social capital was higher for JFM villages over non-JFM villages. Within JFM villages, FPC villages had consistently higher levels of social capital. Landless and marginal landholders indicated higher levels of social capital than small landholders

Study_location: Agua, Malibona, Brindabanpur, Belboni, Baragari, Katul-II, Kustara, Majdiha villages in Bankura district, West Bengal
Stated_outcomes: Natural capital, physical capital, financial capital, human capital, social capital
Indicators: Income potential as proxy for savings
Outcome.direction_notes: Income from forest sources contributes significantly more to potential savings of landless and marginal landholders than small landholders for JFM villages. JFM villagers tend to rely heavily on forest for income (61% to 80-85% after implementation)

Authors: Das N
Title: Impact of participatory forestry program on sustainable rural livelihoods: Lessons from an Indian province
Author_affil: Centre for Studies in Social Sciences, Calcutta (CSSSC), India
Stated_int: Joint Forest Management (JFM) and female forest protection committees (FPC)
Desired_out: Participatory approach to community forestry - institutionalization of forest protection with involvement of stakeholders. Specifically, devolution of decision-maker power and responsibility to local communications under community titling property rights approach to manage forest lands. Specifically within the JFM program, West Bengal establishment of female forest protection committees (FPC) to empower women in decision-making sphere.
Study_goal: Assess the impact of participatory forestry initiatives on livelihoods sustainability across the socioeconomic groups of rural poor in forest fringe areas at the micro level
Study_location: Agua, Malibona, Brindabanpur, Belboni, Baragari, Katul-II, Kustara, Majdiha villages in Bankura district, West Bengal
Stated_outcomes: Natural capital, physical capital, financial capital, human capital, social capital
Indicators: Expenditure on education and healthcare
Outcome.direction_notes: JFM households, particular landless and marginal landholders saw increase in expenditure after implementation of JFM compared to non-JFM.

Authors: Das N
Title: Impact of participatory forestry program on sustainable rural livelihoods: Lessons from an Indian province
Author_affil: Centre for Studies in Social Sciences, Calcutta (CSSSC), India
Stated_int: Joint Forest Management (JFM) and female forest protection committees (FPC)
Desired_out: Participatory approach to community forestry - institutionalization of forest protection with involvement of stakeholders. Stated_outcomes: Natural capital, physical capital, financial capital, human capital, social capital
Indicators: Groups & network, trust & solidarity, collective action & participation, information & communication, social cohesion & inclusion, empowerment & political action

Authors: Das N

Stated_int: Joint forest management (JFM), forest protection committee (FPC) - male and female headed
Desired_out: "the state forest department made a novel initiative to provide a separate provision for women's participation in the JFM by establishing female FPC, exclusively for women"

Outcome.direction_notes: JFM villages tend to have higher income changes

Authors: Das N, Sarker D
Title: Impact of a moral hazard problem in the Joint Forest Management Programme: A study from forest-dependent households in West Bengal
Author_affil: RBI Unit , Centre for Studies in Social Sciences , Calcutta, India
Stated_int: Forest Protection Committees under Joint Forest Management villages (female-led, joint-led)
Desired_out: Devolve responsibility for managing forest resources and regenerating degraded forests to communities under forest departments. Thought to lead to shared benefits from timber and NTFPs.
Study_goal: This study seeks to explore the impact of a moral hazard problem in the Joint Forest Management (JFM) programme between the government and forest fringe communities of a province in West Bengal, India
Study_location: Bankura District
Stated_outcomes: Legal vs. illegal timber and NTFP income, Forestry wage income
Indicators: Legal and illegal timber and NTFP income compared between JFM/non-JFM communities, socio-economic groups, female-led/joint FPCs
Outcome.direction_notes: Generally, legal income increased for poorer groups in JFM villages and illegal income decreased

Authors: Das N, Sarker D
Title: Impact of a moral hazard problem in the Joint Forest Management Programme: A study from forest-dependent households in West Bengal
Author_affil: RBI Unit , Centre for Studies in Social Sciences , Calcutta, India
Stated_int: Forest Protection Committees under Joint Forest Management villages (female-led, joint-led)
Desired_out: Devolve responsibility for managing forest resources and regenerating degraded forests to communities under forest departments. Thought to lead to shared benefits from timber and NTFPs.
Study_goal: This study seeks to explore the impact of a moral hazard problem in the Joint Forest Management (JFM) programme between the government and forest fringe communities of a province in West Bengal, India
Study_location: Bankura District
Stated_outcomes: Legal vs. illegal timber and NTFP income, Forestry wage income
Indicators: Forestry wage income
Outcome.direction_notes: Increase in forestry wage income for JFM and female-FPC villages versus non-JFM villages

Authors: Datta D, Chatterjee D
Title: Assessment of community-based initiatives in sustainable management of Indian dry deciduous forests
Journal: International Journal of Sustainable Development & World Ecology
Author_affil: Department of Agricultural and Food Engineering , Indian Institute of Technology;  Department of Geography, Taki Government College.
Stated_int: Forest protection committees (FPC) as implemented in Joint Forest Management at local forest management unit (FMU) level
Desired_out: Program focused on creation of FPCs to initiate partnerships between village communities and the state forest department for monitoring JFM, drafting plans, protecting forests from grazing and illegal harvesting, while the forests continued to be owned by the Forest Department. Joint management of forest lands and shared responsibility for regenerating degraded land would lead to sharing of benefits from timber and NTFPs.
Study_goal: "In this study, a previously developed C&I framework was applied for assessment of functioning of forest protection committees (FPCs) in the dry deciduous forests of India through a 5-year monitoring programme"
Study_location: Nayagram Forest Range
Stated_outcomes: Social capital of forest protection committees, income, governance structure
Indicators: Cohesiveness of community
Outcome.direction_notes: FPCs reported generally increased cohesiveness over time

Authors: Debnath D, Dasgupta S
Title: Livelihoods Generation and Poverty Reduction Attempts in Joint Forest Management Activities in Madhya Pradesh
Author_affil: Indian Institute of Forest Management, Mehru Nagar, Bhopal, India
Funding: None listed
Stated_int: Madhya Pradesh Forestry Project. Two phase project. Phase I funded by World Bank with IDA credit intended to fulfill Joint Forest Management objectives
Desired_out: "The project was designed to meet this felt need for investment in the forestry sector. The project was designed after a prolonged dialogue within the forest department and with the various other stakeholder groups of the state. The project provided funds not only for investment in the upgrading of the forestry technology and forest floor management; it also mandated the upgrading of the skills and knowledge of the staff, both in traditional forestry and modern concepts. Above all, it put high emphasis on the participation of the forest dwellers in the management of the nearby forests and sharing the benefits...."
Study_goal: Report on project outcomes
Study_location: Madhya Pradesh
Stated_outcomes: Involvement of forest-users in decision-making, women involvement in decision making, livelihood generation, poverty reduction
Indicators: Employment as measured in million man days

Authors: Derkyi M, Ros-Tonen MAF, Kyereh B, Dietz T
Title: Emerging forest regimes and livelihoods in the Tano Offin Forest Reserve, Ghana: Implications for Social Safeguards
Author_affil: Tropenbos International Ghana and University of Amsterdam
Funding: Tropenbos International Ghana
Linked_refs: Derkyi, M.A.A., 2012. Fighting over Forest: Interactive Governance of Conflicts over Forest and Tree Resources in Ghana's High Forest Zone. (PhD Thesis) University of Amsterdam, African Studies Collection 41. African Studies Centre, Leiden.
Stated_int: Tano Offin Globally Significant Biodiversity Area
Desired_out: 45% of Tano Offin Forestry Reserve set aside as a GBSA to comply with commitments to CBD (2000s). Limited forest access and use to preserve biodiversity
Study_goal: 1. What governing system and structures influence access to forest resources for the inhabitants of the Tano Offin GSBA? 2. What are the implications of these governing systems for inhabi- tants' livelihoods? 3. What are the implications of the findings for the governability of GSBAs, particularly in terms of social safeguards?
Study_location: Tano Offin GSBA which forms part of the larger Tano Offin forest reserve that is located between latitudes 6ç54_ and 6ç35_ North and longitudes 1ç57' and 2ç17' West in the high forest zone of southern Ghana
Stated_outcomes: Access to forest resources, conflicting claims to resources
Indicators: qualitative examination of governance provisions
Stated_mech: Interactive governance theory (Kooiman 2008, Kooiman et al. 2005)

Authors: Dhakal M, Masuda M
Title: Local pricing system of forest products and its relations to equitable benefit sharing and livelihood improvement in the lowland community forestry program in Nepal
Author_affil: Graduate School of Life and Environmental Sciences, University of Tsukuba, Tennodai 1-1-1, Tsukuba, Ibaraki, 305-8572, Japan
Funding: International Tropical Timber Organization (ITTO) Fellowship Programme (Ref. 150/06S)
Stated_int: Community forest user groups, community forestry
Desired_out: Management of forest resources through community forest user groups (CFUGs). "Overall, the CFUGs manage the forests based on collective efforts and share the forest benefits among the user households on equitable basis." "The program simultaneously aims to conserve the forest resources and livelihood improvement of local people on a sustainable basis."
Study_goal: "In this study, we focused on local pricing system and its effects on equitable benefit sharing and livelihood improvement of user house- holds which are the common objectives of lowland community forestry program of Nepal"
Study_location: Rupandehi, Nawalparasi, Chitwan districts
Stated_outcomes: Price of timber, collection and distribution of timber, use of community development funds
Indicators: Share of timber per household according to wealth ranking

Authors: Dolisca F, McDaniel JM, Teeter LD
Title: Farmers' perceptions towards forests: A case study from Haiti
Author_affil: School of Forestry and Wildlife Sciences, Auburn University, Auburn, AL 36849, United States
Funding: Forest Policy Center
Stated_int: Foret des Pins Reserve
Desired_out: Foret des Pins Reserve created to protect ecosystem and water source. Opportunities for ecotourism and soil protection
Study_goal: "The purpose of this paper is to investigate farmers' perceptions on the impact of the Fore_t des Pins Reserve on the economic, social, and environmental status of local people. Specifically, this study has two objectives: (1) to describe farmers' perceptions about protected areas; and (2) to determine if gender, age, education level, place of birth, group membership, land tenure, and income level in the community influence farmers' perceptions of forests"
Study_location: Forest des Pins Reserve
Stated_outcomes: Perceptions of economic, social and environmental benefits from Foret des Pins Reserve for farmers
Indicators: Perceptions of socio-economic benefits

Authors: Dongol CM, Hughey KFD, Bigsby HR
Title: Capital formation and sustainable community forestry in Nepal
Author_affil: District Forest Office, Chandranighapur, Rauthat, Nepal.
Funding: New Zealand Overseas Development Agency
Stated_int: Forest Act of 1992, Forest Bylaw of 1995, Community forestry
Desired_out: Increase participation of communities in forest conservation and management by establishing forest user groups in community forests through the establishment of the Forest Act of 1992 and the Forest Bylaw of 1995
Study_goal: "This article investigates the role of capital formation in contributing to the sustainability of community forestry in Nepal"
Study_location: Kabhre Palanchok, Sindhu Palanchok, Dhankuta, Palpa, and Dang districts
Stated_outcomes: Perceptions of success of forest user group in capital formation
Indicators: Perceptions on social cohesion, improvement in harvest methods

Authors: Duchelle AE, Kainer KA, Wadt LHO
Title: Is Certification Associated with Better Forest Management and Socioeconomic Benefits? A Comparative Analysis of Three Certification Schemes Applied to Brazil Nuts in Western Amazonia
Author_affil: Center for International Forestry Research (CIFOR) , Rio de Janeiro , Brazil
Funding: University of Floridaês NSF-IGERT ••Working Forests in the Tropicsêê Program, Rainforest Alliance Kleinhans Fellowship Program, William J. Fulbright Program, and Center for International Forestry Research Poverty and Environment Network (CIFOR PEN)
Stated_int: Brazil nut certification - Forest Stewardship Council (FSC), organic, and Fair Trade
Desired_out: Organic - health and safetry standards for NTFPs. Fairtrade - socially oriented and aims to ensure benefit sharing and better working conditions for small producers. FSC - ensure sustainable ecological aspects of harvest and social and economic standards.
Study_goal: What are the environmental and socioeconomic benefits associated with different Brazil nut certification schemes? Specific research objectives were: (1) to analyze differences in ••best management practicesêê between certified and noncertified producers; (2) to identify socioeconomic benefits associated with supplying or marketing certified nuts; and (3) to explore producer perceptions of nut certification.
Study_location: Pando (Bolivia), Acre (Brazil), Madre de Dios (Peru)
Stated_outcomes: Income from certification, Debt
Indicators: Price received when selling nuts
Outcome.direction_notes: Higher price when selling to certified cooperatives

Authors: Ferraro PJ, Hanaeur MM
Title: Protecting Ecosystems and Alleviating Poverty with Parks and Reserves: •Win-Winê or Tradeoffs?
Author_affil: Department of Economics, Andrew Young School of Policy Studies, Georgia State University
Linked_refs: Andam KS, Ferraro PJ, Pfaff A, Sanchez-Azofeifa G, Robalino JA (2008) Measuring the effectiveness of protected area networks in reducing deforestation. Proc Natl Acad Sci USA 105(42):16089_16094 Andam K, Ferraro P, Sims K, Healy A, Holland M (2010) Protected areas reduced poverty in Costa Rica and Thailand. Proc Natl Acad Sci USA 107(22):9996
Stated_int: Protected areas
Desired_out: Establish protected areas to reduce deforestation while also aiming for poverty alleviation
Study_goal: Jointly examine environmental and social outcomes of protected areas in Costa Rica to elucidate how different subgroups are affected and under which conditions win-win outcomes can be achieved.
Study_location: Costa Rica
Stated_outcomes: Socio-economic impact by subgroup (land use capacity, slope, distance to major city, % agricultural workers, initial poverty)
Indicators: Poverty index as calculated by methods in Cavatassi et al. 2004
Outcome.direction_notes: Poverty reduction varied based on high vs. low baseline levels for each subgroup examined. See Figure 1.

Title: Estimating the impacts of conservation on ecosystem services and poverty by integrating modeling and evaluation

Author_affil: Department of Economics, Andrew Young School of Policy Studies, Georgia State University, Atlanta, GA 30319
Linked_refs: Andam KS, Ferraro PJ, Pfaff A, Sanchez-Azofeifa GA, Robalino JA (2008) Measuring the effectiveness of protected area networks in reducing deforestation. Proc Natl Acad Sci USA 105(42):16089_16094. Nolte C, Agrawal A, Silvius KM, Soares-Filho BS (2013) Governance regime and loca- tion influence avoided deforestation success of protected areas in the Brazilian Amazon. Proc Natl Acad Sci USA 110(13):4956_4961. Andam KS, Ferraro PJ, Hanauer MM (2013) The effects of protected area systems on ecosystem restoration: A quasi-experimental design to estimate the impact of Costa Ricaês protected area system on forest regrowth. Authors: Ferraro PJ, Hanauer MM, Sims KRE
Title: Conditions associated with protected area success in conservation and poverty reduction
Journal: Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences
Author_affil: Department of Economics, Andrew Young School of Policy Studies, Georgia State University, Atlanta, GA 30302-3992
Linked_refs: Andam KS, Ferraro PJ, Sims KRE, Healy A, Holland MB (2010) Protected areas reduced poverty in Costa Rica and Thailand. Proc Natl Acad Sci USA 107:9996_10001. Sims KRE (2010) Conservation and development: Evidence from Thai Protected Areas. J Environ Econ Manage 60:94_114. Andam KS, Ferraro PJ, Pfaff A, Sanchez-Azofeifa GA, Robalino JA (2008) Measuring the effectiveness of protected area networks in reducing deforestation. Proc Natl Acad Sci USA 105:16089_16094.
Stated_int: Protected areas
Desired_out: Protected areas established to reduce deforestation and promote reforestation as well as promote poverty alleviation
Study_goal: Identify covariate ranges that are associated with high conservation and poverty reduction outcomes (win_win), low conservation and poverty exacerbation outcomes (lose_lose), or incongruence, where one outcome is win and the other is lose (win_lose) within protected areas in Costa Rica and Thailand
Study_location: Costa Rica, Thailand
Stated_outcomes: Change in poverty reduction
Indicators: Poverty index based on national census data (per method in Andam et al. 2010)
Outcome.direction_notes: See Fig 1.

Authors: Fu Y, Chen J, Guo H, Chen A, Cui J, Hu H
Title: The role of non-timber forest products during agroecosystem shift in Xishuangbanna, southwestern China
Author_affil: Xishuangbanna Tropical Botanical Garden, Chinese Academy of Sciences, Mengla 666300, Yunnan, China
Funding: United Nations University Project on People, Land Management and Environmental Change
Stated_int: Collection of NTFPs in response to shift from subsistence to market-oriented system (agroecosystem to rubber plantation)
Desired_out: Collection of NTFPs to augment household income (typically from agriculture), recently, rubber plantations have greatly displaced swidden-fallow agroecosystems
Study_goal: "The objective of the study is to understand how the traditional practices of collecting NTFPs respond to the shift of an agroecosystem from subsistence to market-oriented system."
Study_location: Daka village (21 41'N, 101 25'E), Menglun town, Mengla County & Baka village (21 59'N, 101 9'E) , Jinghong City, Xishuangbanna Dai Autonomous Prefecture
Stated_outcomes: Determinants of income generated by NTFPs, relationship between income wealth and dependence on NTFPs
Portion_livelihood_amount: Varies
Indicators: Dependence on NTFPs
Outcome.direction_notes: Depends on income level and on price of rubber

Authors: Fu Y, Chen J, Guo J, Hu H, Chen A, Cui J
Title: Rain forest dwellersê livelihoods: income generation, household wealth and NTFP sales, a case study from Xishuangbanna, SW China
Journal: International Journal of Sustainable Development & World Ecology
Author_affil: Xishuangbanna Tropical Botanical Garden, Chinese Academy of Sciences, Mengla 666300, Yunnan, China
Funding: United Nations University Project on People, Land Management and Environmental Change
Stated_int: NTFP collection and sale
Desired_out: Collection of NTFPs to augment household income (typically from agriculture)
Study_goal: "Here, we explore wealth-related differences and similarities in the use and value of NTFPs between villages to obtain a deeper understanding at household level, as well as to explore the role of NTFPs in local livelihoods."
Study_location: Daka village (21 41'N, 101 25'E), Menglun town, Mengla County & Baka village (21 59'N, 101 9'E) , Jinghong City, Xishuangbanna Dai Autonomous Prefecture
Stated_outcomes: Contribution of NTFPs to cash income, differences in NTFP income between wealth groups, wealth inequality between households that sell NTFPs and those who do not
Indicators: Contribution of NTFPs to income
Outcome.direction_notes: Differs between NTFP type and year

Authors: Fu Y, Chen J, Guo J, Hu H, Chen A, Cui J
Title: Rain forest dwellersê livelihoods: income generation, household wealth and NTFP sales, a case study from Xishuangbanna, SW China
Journal: International Journal of Sustainable Development & World Ecology
Author_affil: Xishuangbanna Tropical Botanical Garden, Chinese Academy of Sciences, Mengla 666300, Yunnan, China
Funding: United Nations University Project on People, Land Management and Environmental Change

Stated_outcomes: Contribution of NTFPs to cash income, differences in NTFP income between wealth groups, wealth inequality between households that sell NTFPs and those who do not
Indicators: Difference in NTFP income contribution between wealth groups, gender
Outcome.direction_notes: Women-headed households tend to depend more on NTFPs for income than men

Authors: Fujita Y, Phanvilay K
Title: Land and forest allocation in Lao People's Democratic Republic: Comparison of case studies from community-based natural resource management research
Author_affil: Upland Agriculture and Research Capacity Development Programme, National Agriculture and Forestry Research Institute (NAFRI), Vientiane, Lao Peopleês Democratic Republic
Stated_int: Land and Forest Allocation (LFA) Policy
Desired_out: "Development of LFA was supported by various international organizations throughout the 1990s as means of supporting sustainable community resource management and preventing open-access problems by defining clear resource boundaries and constructing resource management institutions based on local participation and customary practices. An underlying assumption is that clear and secure property rights brought about through LFA will help improve productive use of land in rural areas. Meanwhile, the government authorities perceived that LFA would halt environmental degradation by controlling the expansion of shifting cultivation, particularly in the upland areas."
Study_goal: "We examine the [LFA] policy from the viewpoint of decentralized resource management and, through three case studies conducted by the National University of Laos, how it works in practice"
Study_location: Namon & Houay Yang villages (Nam Ngum Reservoir), Phonethong & Taothane villages (National Route 13 North), Ang Nhai village (western Vientiane)
Stated_outcomes: LFA impact on private rights to resources, collective rights to resources
Indicators: Perception data
Outcome.direction_notes: Wealthy groups tend to be able to acquire more land during LFA, shifting cultivation practitioners less able to have access to land

Authors: Fujita Y, Phanvilay K
Title: Land and forest allocation in Lao People's Democratic Republic: Comparison of case studies from community-based natural resource management research
Author_affil: Upland Agriculture and Research Capacity Development Programme, National Agriculture and Forestry Research Institute (NAFRI), Vientiane, Lao Peopleês Democratic Republic
Stated_int: Land and Forest Allocation (LFA) Policy
Desired_out: "Development of LFA was supported by various international organizations throughout the 1990s as means of supporting sustainable community resource management and preventing open-access problems by defining clear resource boundaries and constructing resource management institutions based on local participation and customary practices. An underlying assumption is that clear and secure property rights brought about through LFA will help improve productive use of land in rural areas. Meanwhile, the government authorities perceived that LFA would halt environmental degradation by controlling the expansion of shifting cultivation, particularly in the upland areas."
Study_goal: "We examine the [LFA] policy from the viewpoint of decentralized resource management and, through three case studies conducted by the National University of Laos, how it works in practice"
Study_location: Namon & Houay Yang villages (Nam Ngum Reservoir), Phonethong & Taothane villages (National Route 13 North), Ang Nhai village (western Vientiane)
Stated_outcomes: LFA impact on private rights to resources, collective rights to resources
Indicators: Perceptions on collective rights to use and manage resources
Outcome.direction_notes: Resource boundaries delineated without consultation

Authors: Garcia-Amado LR, Perez MR, Dahringer G, Escutia FR, Garcia SB, Mejia EC
Title: From wild harvesting to agroforest cultivation: A Chamaedorea palm case study from Chiapas, Mexico
Author_affil: Department of Ecology, Universidad Auto_noma de Madrid, C/ Darwin 2. 28049, Cantoblanco, Madrid, Spain
Stated_int: Commercialization of Chamaedorea palm (NTFP) in La Sepultura Biosphere Reserve, palm reforestation
Desired_out: Commercialization of NTFPs while supporting community forestry
Study_goal: "In this paper we analyze the adoption and social differentiation dynamics around a NTFP, Chamaedorea palm, in a community placed in La Sepultura Biosphere Reserve, Chiapas, Mexico. The study, conducted over a three-year period, provides an analysis of the livelihood changes, including stakeholders' perception, accrued with the shift from wild ex- traction to cultivation of palm."
Study_location: Sierra Morena, La Sepultura Biosphere Reserve, Chiapas
Stated_outcomes: Change in income over time for different resource types, perceptions on if palm plantations have improved quality of life, contribution of palm to household income per income group
Portion_livelihood_amount: See Figure 3
Indicators: Change in contribution of palm to household income and change in overall income from palm
Outcome.direction_notes: Differs by income group and over time

Outcome.direction_notes: Improving over time

Authors: Garcia-Amado LR, Perez MR, Dahringer G, Escutia FR, Garcia SB, Mejia EC
Title: From wild harvesting to agroforest cultivation: A Chamaedorea palm case study from Chiapas, Mexico
Author_affil: Department of Ecology, Universidad Auto_noma de Madrid, C/ Darwin 2. 28049, Cantoblanco, Madrid, Spain
Stated_int: Commercialization of Chamaedorea palm (NTFP) in La Sepultura Biosphere Reserve, palm reforestation
Desired_out: Commercialization of NTFPs while supporting community forestry
Study_goal: "In this paper we analyze the adoption and social differentiation dynamics around a NTFP, Chamaedorea palm, in a community placed in La Sepultura Biosphere Reserve, Chiapas, Mexico. The study, conducted over a three-year period, provides an analysis of the livelihood changes, including stakeholders' perception, accrued with the shift from wild ex- traction to cultivation of palm."
Study_location: Sierra Morena, La Sepultura Biosphere Reserve, Chiapas
Stated_outcomes: Change in income over time for different resource types, perceptions on if palm plantations have improved quality of life, contribution of palm to household income per income group
Indicators: Perceptions of change in quality of life (labour allocation, stability of job, level of effort)
Outcome.direction_notes: Improving over time

Indicators: Social network relationships within agroforestry industry groups compared between income groups

Authors: Gauli K, Hauser M
Title: Commercial management of non-timber forest products in Nepalês community forest users groups: who benefits?
Author_affil: Centre for Development Research & Department of Sustainable Agricultural Systems, University of Natural Resources and Applied Life Sciences, Gregor Mendel Strasse 33, 1180 Vienna, Austria
Funding: Austrian Agency for International Cooperation in Education and Research (OeAD -GmbH)
Stated_int: Commercial management of NTFPs, Community forest user groups (CFUGs)
Desired_out: CFUGs managing NTFPs based on market enterprise
Study_goal: "The traditional approach refers to situations where CFUGs do not have detailed management plans and exclusively depend on middlemen to sell their NTFPs. On the other hand, the enterprise oriented approach refers to situations where CFUGs have detailed management plans and direct market linkage with enterprises (Subedi 2006). This study compares these two different approaches to understand the influence of socioeconomic variables such as household income, household size and food self-sufficiency on household NTFP income. "
Study_location: Mahadevthan and Suspa, Dolakha district
Stated_outcomes: Contribution of NTFPs to household income
Portion_livelihood_amount: 15%-21% maximum (see Table 3)
Indicators: Cash income from NTFPs
Outcome.direction_notes: Compared between CFUG that has commercial management of NTFPs versus one that does not. Comparison between income groups

Authors: Gbedomon RC, Floquet A, Mongbo R, Salako VK, Fandohan AB, Assogbadjo AE, Kakai RG
Title: Socio-economic and ecological outcomes of community based forest management: A case study from Tob_-Kpobidon forest in Benin, Western Africa
Author_affil: Laboratory of Biomathematics and Forest Estimations, Faculty of Agricultural Sciences, University of Abomey-Calavi, 04 BP 1525, Cotonou, Benin
Funding: The Foundation –Aide š l'Autonomia Tobe"
Stated_int: Community forestry, Tob_-Kpobidon community forest, protected domain
Desired_out: "The TK forest is also known among other community forests in Benin to have an outstanding institutional design strengthening the ability of local stakeholders to design collective rules and restrictions in forest resource use and have them enforced. Local stakeholders have been supported by an external stakeholder ã Foundation –Aide š l'Autonomie Tob_” (a Non-Governmental Organization) over the last thirty years. Activities alternative to logging and conversion such as ecotourism, beekeeping and a small-scale forest enterprise marketing beehive products sold countrywide under the label –Tobe” have been promoted."
Study_goal: "This paper addresses the issue of the local communities' capacity to sustainably manage their own forest resources. It analyzes the institutional arrangements promoted and assesses the efficiency and the sustainability of an approach intending to empower local communities and protect forest resources while providing enough income to reduce the risk of forest conversion."
Study_location: Tob_-Kpobidon (TK) community forest and its three bordering villages (Itchokobo, Issale and Akpaka (8ç18_8ç20_ N and 1ç50_ 149 1ç52_ E)
Stated_outcomes: Economic outcomes, institutional outcomes
Indicators: Contribution to household income
Outcome.direction_notes: Differs between stakeholder groups

Authors: Gelo D, Koch SF
Title: The Impact of Common Property Right Forestry: Evidence from Ethiopian Villages
Author_affil: University of Cape Town, Rondebosch, South Africa
Funding: Volkswagen Foundation/ZIAF, Economic Research Southern Africa, EfD (EDRI/EEPFE) SIDA
Stated_int: Joint Forest Management, Forest User Groups, Forest User Committees, NTFP marketing
Desired_out: "The overriding objectives of these interventions were two-pronged: halting deforestation and improving the livelihood (reducing poverty) of forest-dependent communities, the latter to be achieved through bolstering the economic benefits provided by the forests. "
Study_goal: "this study aims to evaluate the impact of a JFM program augmented by the provision of market-based incentives, through NTFP marketing."
Study_location: Gimbo District
Stated_outcomes: Change in household income
Indicators: Change in household income and per capita consumption
Outcome.direction_notes: Depending on weighting and sample set - participants have greater benefits

Authors: Gelo D, Muchapondwa E, Koch SF
Title: Decentralization, market integration and efficiency-equity trade-offs: Evidence from Joint Forest Management in Ethiopian villages
Author_affil: School of Economics, University of Cape Town, Rondebosch, Cape Town 7701, South Africa
Funding: Volkswagen Foundation and University of Johannesburg, Economic Research Southern Africa, EfD (EDRI/EEPFE) SIDA
Stated_int: Joint Forest Management, community forest enterprises, marketing of NTFPs
Desired_out: "The general objectives of these programs are to arrest deforestation and forest degradation while improving the welfare of those who are heavily dependent on the forest for their livelihoods. In essence, the programs are intended to achieve these twin goals by incentivizing local communities to manage state forests. However, there are pervasive imperfections in forest products markets that constrain the needed incentives; these imperfections arise mainly from limited infrastructure, high transport costs, few buyers, exploitive marketing chains and imperfect price information. One innovative approach to overcome these problems, which has been adopted by the Ethiopian government, is to organize JFM into community forest enterprises (CFE) in the form of forest usersê cooperatives (FUC) for forest products marketing.4 This provides the community with avenues for greater participation in value chains of forest products markets through vertical integration (VI) (Antinori, 2005; Gelo and Koch, 2014; Vega and Keenan, 2014). Vertical integration is expected to raise NTFP prices and hence spurs the required incentives by shortening the marketing chain and increasing bargaining power of farmers along NTFP market value chain."
Study_goal: "It is aimed at evaluating the income and distributive effects of a JFM program augmented by market linkage interventions."
Study_location: Gimbo District
Stated_outcomes: Changes in household welfare
Indicators: Change in household income
Outcome.direction_notes: Raised by 26% for those who participated in program, particularly in FUCs that included marketing incentives to use NTFPs. Wealthier households experienced more benefits

Authors: Ghorbani A, Langenberger G, Liu JX, Wehner S, Sauerborn J
Title: Diversity of Medicinal and Food Plants as Non-timber Forest Products in Naban River Watershed National Nature Reserve (China): Implications for Livelihood Improvement and Biodiversity Conservation
Author_affil: Institute of Plant Production and Agroecology in the Tropics and Subtropics, University of Hohenheim, Garbenstra_e 13, 70599 Stuttgart, Germany
Funding: German Federal Ministry of Education and Research (BMBF) (FN.: 0330797A) and the German Academic Exchange Service (DAAD)
Stated_int: NTFP management around Naban River Watershed National Nature Reserve
Desired_out: "the nature reserve administration office set regulations on access to the resources based on village boundaries and proposed a biannual collection scheme"
Study_goal: "this work aims to introduce NTFPs harvested in NRWNNR, with a focus on medicinal and food plants, and highlights their role in the livelihood of local people."
Study_location: Villages (Na Ban, Pan Bing, Da Nuo You, Xiao Nuo You Shang Zhai, Ben Gan Hani, Mang Xin Long La) around Naban River Watershed National Nature Reserve is located in Xishuangbanna Dai Autonomous Prefecture in the southernmost part of Yunnan province
Stated_outcomes: Contribution of sale of bamboo shoots to income
Portion_livelihood_amount: 0.16-3.8% of per capita income
Indicators: Collection and income from bamboo shoot collection (as proxy for NTFP collection and income)
Outcome.direction_notes: Depends on village

Authors: GOBEZE T, BEKELE M, LEMENIH M, and KASSA H
Title: Participatory forest management and its impacts on livelihoods and forest status: the case of Bonga forest in Ethiopia
Author_affil: Wondo Genet College of Forestry and Natural Resources, Shashamane, 128, Ethiopia
Funding: We acknowledge the financial support of Wondo Genet College of Forestry and Natural Resources of Hawassa University from its Sida funded development oriented action research programme
Stated_int: Participatory Forest Management in Ethiopia
Desired_out: Sustainable forest management; improved livelihoods
Study_goal: The objectives of this study are (i) to examine the contribution of PFM to local livelihoods in terms of incomes of households organized under the program; (ii) to assess the effects of PFM in empowering poor women and minorities in terms of participation, benefit sharing and decision making, and (iii) to determine and quantify the changes in forest status by comparing forests under and outside PFM.
Study_location: Bonga district
Sample_size: 93 households: Three of the six Forest User Cooperatives of the Bonga PFM project were selected randomly. Then among all members of these three cooperatives, the questionnaire was administered on randomly selected 93 households.
Study_duration: 2002-2007: Bonga PFM is initiated and ran by FARM Africa. The project had two phases: the first phase ran for 8 years between 1995 and 2002. The second phase, which was the focus of this study, lasted between 2002 and 2007.
Stated_outcomes: Change in household income before/after PFM introduced
Portion_livelihood_amount: See Figures 1 & 2 in paper
Indicators: Average income from various sources before and after PFM
Outcome.direction_notes: Before and after PFM income sources are different: see Figures 1 & 2 in paper

Authors: Gordon I, Ayiemba W
Title: Harnessing butterfly biodiversity for improving livelihoods and forest conservation: The Kipepeo Project
Author_affil: Environmental Health Division at the International Centre of Insect Physiology and Ecology
Funding: Global Environment Facility Small Grants Programme, the IUCN-Netherlands Tropical Rain Forest Programme, the Biodiversity Support Program, a consortium of World Wildlife Fund, the Nature Conservancy, and the World Resources Insti- tute, with funding by the United States Agency for International Devel- opment, the Chicago Zoological Society and Brookfield Zoo, the National Museums of Kenya, and the EU-funded BirldLife International Arabuko-Sokoke Forest Management and Conservation Project
Stated_int: The Kipepeo Project
Desired_out: "a project administered by the East Africa Natural History Society (EANHS, now Nature Kenya [NK]) in partnership with the National Museums of Kenya (NMK). Kipepeo was started in 1993 with $50,000 from the Global Environment Facility (GEF) Small Grants Programme. Its objective was to change local attitudes by enabling the forest-adjacent community to get cash incomes from rearing forest butterflies for export to the live butterfly exhibit industry in Europe and America"
Study_goal: Self-evaluation of Kipepeo project. How much has it added value to Arabuko-Sokoke Forest? Has it affected local attitudes to the forest? How much has it succeeded in improving community livelihoods? Have there been any unanticipated negative effects? Have the earnings been evenly spread? Have the socially and economically disadvantaged sections of the community benefited from Kipepeo? Have there been any other spin-offs for conservation? Has butterfly harvest- ing for farming operations affected wild butterfly populations in the forest? Is Kipepeo sustainable? Can it be replicated?
Study_location: villages around Arabuko-Sokoke Forest
Stated_outcomes: Added value to forest, contribution to cash incomes, empowerment of community to represent forest
Indicators: Contribution of butterfly sales to cash income and distribution over surveyed community farmers
Outcome.direction_notes: Not all who contribute earn equal benefits

Have the socially and economically disadvantaged sections of the community benefited from Kipepeo? Have there been any other spin-offs for conservation? Has butterfly harvest- ing for farming operations affected wild butterfly populations in the forest? Is Kipepeo sustainable? Can it be replicated?
Study_location: villages around Arabuko-Sokoke Forest
Stated_outcomes: Added value to forest, contribution to cash incomes, empowerment of community to represent forest
Indicators: Contribution of butterfly sales to cash income and distribution over surveyed community farmers
Outcome.direction_notes: Not all who contribute earn equal benefits

Authors: Gordon I, Ayiemba W
Title: Harnessing butterfly biodiversity for improving livelihoods and forest conservation: The Kipepeo Project
Author_affil: Environmental Health Division at the International Centre of Insect Physiology and Ecology
Funding: Global Environment Facility Small Grants Programme, the IUCN-Netherlands Tropical Rain Forest Programme, the Biodiversity Support Program, a consortium of World Wildlife Fund, the Nature Conservancy, and the World Resources Insti- tute, with funding by the United States Agency for International Devel- opment, the Chicago Zoological Society and Brookfield Zoo, the National Museums of Kenya, and the EU-funded BirldLife International Arabuko-Sokoke Forest Management and Conservation Project
Stated_int: The Kipepeo Project
Desired_out: "a project administered by the East Africa Natural History Society (EANHS, now Nature Kenya [NK]) in partnership with the National Museums of Kenya (NMK). Kipepeo was started in 1993 with $50,000 from the Global Environment Facility (GEF) Small Grants Programme. Its objective was to change local attitudes by enabling the forest-adjacent community to get cash incomes from rearing forest butterflies for export to the live butterfly exhibit industry in Europe and America"
Study_goal: Self-evaluation of Kipepeo project. How much has it added value to Arabuko-Sokoke Forest? Has it affected local attitudes to the forest? How much has it succeeded in improving community livelihoods? Have there been any unanticipated negative effects? Have the earnings been evenly spread? Have the socially and economically disadvantaged sections of the community benefited from Kipepeo? Have there been any other spin-offs for conservation? Has butterfly harvest- ing for farming operations affected wild butterfly populations in the forest? Is Kipepeo sustainable? Can it be replicated?
Study_location: villages around Arabuko-Sokoke Forest
Stated_outcomes: Added value to forest, contribution to cash incomes, empowerment of community to represent forest
Indicators: Added revenue before and after project to forest

Authors: Gross-Camp ND, Martin A, McGuire S, Kebede B, Munyarukaza J
Title: Payments for ecosystem services in an African protected area: exploring issues of legitimacy, fairness, equity and effectiveness
Author_affil: International Development UEA, University of East Anglia, Norwich, NR4 7TJ, UK
Funding: EU FP7 European Research Council
Stated_int: Payments for ecosystem services (Reconciling Biodiversity and Development through Direct Payments for Conservation), integrated conservation and development projects, national park
Desired_out: Provide payments to address conservation and development objectives simultaneously
Study_goal: " We examine the ability of PES to achieve conservation and development objectives, through three sub-questions: Is the PES scheme effective? Is it legitimate and fair? Is it equitable?"
Study_location: Gahurizo, Rukore, Shaba, Kagano, Murwa, Kiyabo, Uwumusebeya, Ruyenzi cells - Nyungwe National Park
Stated_outcomes: Change in illicit and illegal behavior, social impact, change in consumption (supporting livelihoods)
Indicators: Household consumption

Authors: Gurung A, Bista R, Karki R, Shrestha S, Uprety D, Oh SE
Title: Community-based forest management and its role in improving forest conditions in Nepal
Author_affil: Department of Biological Environment, Kangwon National University, Hyoja-dong, Gangwon-do, Chuncheon-si 200-701, Republic of Korea
Funding: Research into Use (RIU) program of the Department for International Development (DFID), United Kingdom
Linked_refs: Reducing Poverty through Innovation System in Forestry (RPISF), hosted by ForestAction, Kathmandu, Nepal
Stated_int: Community forestry managed through community forest user groups (CFUGs)
Desired_out: Increased benefits from community-based forestry programs for poor and marginalized groups, improved local governance
Study_goal: What are the forest conditions before and after the introduction of a project for strengthening the management policies and governance in existing community forestry?ê
Study_location: Lalitpur, Baglung, Nawalparasi districts
Stated_outcomes: Community investment in physical infrastructure (e.g. drinking water, erosion control), empowerment of CFUGs to manage forest resources, access and planting of commercially valuable tree species
Indicators: Investment of community funds into physical infrastructure

Authors: Gurung DB, Seeland K
Title: Ecotourism benefits and livelihood improvement for sustainable development in the nature conservation areas of Bhutan
Author_affil: Society, Environment and Culture, Institute for Environmental Decisions, Swiss Federal Institute of Technology (ETH) Zurich, Switzerland
Funding: Swiss Agency for Develop- ment and Cooperation (SDC/DEZA), Berne, and Helvetas, Zurich
Stated_int: Trekking routes through protected land (Chomolhari trekking route though Jigme Dorji National Park, Nabji-Korphu trekking route through Jigme Singye Wangchuck National Park, Shingkhar Valley route in and around Thrumshingla National Park)
Desired_out: Support trekking guides and other industries around national parks
Study_goal: "We explore the livelihoods of three rural farming communities in two protected areas and in one valley nearby _ to find out whether ecotourism could supplement the subsistence agricultural economy of the rural population to improve their living standard"
Study_location: Chomolhari, Nabji-Korphu, Shingkhar regions
Stated_outcomes: Impact of tourism (economic, access)
Indicators: Cash income from trekking tourism (porter-pony services, handicraft sales, cultural entertainments, guides)

Authors: Ha TTP, van Dijk H, Visser L
Title: Impacts of changes in mangrove forest management practices on forest accessibility and livelihood: A case study in mangrove-shrimp farming system in Ca Mau Province, Mekong Delta, Vietnam
Author_affil: Department of Sociology, School of Social Sciences and Humanities, Cantho University, Viet Nam; Rural Development Sociology Group, Wageningen University, The Netherlands
Funding: INREF (Interdisciplinary Research and Education Fund) of Wagenin- gen University, The Netherlands
Linked_refs: RESCOPAR (Rebuilding resilience of coastal population and aquatic resources) project
Stated_int: Decision 10/QD.UB (22/09/2010), mangrove forest management, shrimp aquaculture
Desired_out: "Further devolve forest management to farmers by transferring contract-based forestry to a long-term land use right to households in order to have farmers benefit from both mangrove and shrimp production. Decisions acknowledge farmersê rights and authority over forest products, and provide flexible and feasible aquaculture regimes by reducing the ratio of mangroves to water in small-size farms, accepting machinery for excavation, and providing more equal benefit sharing for farmers from FCs2 mangrove logging."
Study_goal: "This paper documents how the implementation of forest tenure policy affects the decision-making of farmers in mangrove-shrimp farming systems with regard to their access to and management of man- grove forest"
Study_location: Cha La (Nam Can, Ca Mau), Thanh Hai (Dong Hai, Bac Lieu), Kinh 17 (Nam Can, Ca Mau)
Stated_outcomes: Allocation of land, access to mangroves, economic benefit sharing between farmers and Forest Companies (FC), access to mangrove-shrimp aquaculture, average return from aquaculture
Indicators: Allocation of mangrove forest land for settlement under red and green certificate regimes

Authors: Ha TTT, van Dijk H, Bush SR
Title: Mangrove conservation or shrimp farmerês livelihood? The devolution of forest management and benefit sharing in the Mekong Delta, Vietnam
Author_affil: Environmental Policy Group, Wageningen University, Hollandseweg 1, 6706 KN Wageningen, The Netherlands; Department of Economics, Faculty of Economics and Business Management, Vietnam Forestry University, Xuan Mai Town, Ha Noi City, Viet Nam
Stated_int: Song Trem Forest-Fishery Enterprise, decentralized forest management, Red Book certificate program, mangrove-based shrimp aquaculture
Desired_out: "The policies are regarded as an important strategy to encourage local people to participate in forest planting and protection. They have been implemented in all the regions of Vietnam from upland to lowland forest areas. In accordance with forest allocation policies, a national benefit sharing policy in forest protection and development became operational. This policy is based on three principles aiming at ensuring harmony between: the state and the forest usersê interests; economic benefits and the ecological functions of forests; and between short-term and long-term benefits to make sure that forest users can live on forestry"
Study_goal: "Using the case of integrated shrimp mangrove farming system in Ca Mau province, the Mekong Delta the paper aims at investigating how changes in legal rights associated with the devolution of forest management, are related to actual rights and the distribution of benefits out of forest management practices and influence shrimp farmersê decisions with respect to the management of mangroves"
Study_location: Ngoc Hien and Nam Can districts in Ca Mau province
Forest_type: Other non-forest environment with natural vegetation
Stated_outcomes: Income from mangrove cutting vs. shrimp farming, land allocated to households
Indicators: income derived from shrimp vs. integrated mangrove/shrimp areas
Outcome.direction_notes: Integrated farming areas had higher yield and price

Authors: Ha TTT, van Dijk H, Bush SR
Title: Mangrove conservation or shrimp farmerês livelihood? The devolution of forest management and benefit sharing in the Mekong Delta, Vietnam

Authors: Haglund E, Ndkeunga J, Snook L, Pasternak D
Title: Dry land tree management for improved household livelihoods: Farmer managed natural regeneration in Niger
Author_affil: Mickey Leland International Hunger Fellow of the Congressional Hunger Center, 400 North Capitol Street NW Suite G100, Washington, D.C. 20001, USA
Funding: ICRISAT, Bioversity International, and World Vision Australia
Stated_int: Farmer managed natural regeneration
Desired_out: "In 1983 an international aid and missionary organization called Society of International Ministries (SIM, subsequently renamed as Serving in Mission) began promoting FMNR as a component of its Maradi Integrated Development Project (MIDP). When drought and famine struck the region in 1984 and 1988, MIDP included FMNR as part of a Food for Work program. This program was extended to 95 villages in the districts of Dakoro, Guidan Roumdji, and Madar- ounfa, and exposed an estimated 80,000 to 100,000 farmers to FMNR."
Study_goal: "We address three key questions. First, how widespread is adoption of the tree conservation and management practices to which Nigerês re-greening has been attributed? Second, what factors determine a farmerês likelihood of adopting such practices? And third, what are the impacts of adoption of these practices on household livelihood outcomes?"
Study_location: Maradi region
Stated_outcomes: Impact of adoption of FMR on per capita gross income, crop diversity, tree density, tree diversity, migrant per household
Indicators: Per capita gross income

Indicators: Food security (crop diversity, tree density and tree diversity as proxies)

When drought and famine struck the region in 1984 and 1988, MIDP included FMNR as part of a Food for Work program. This program was extended to 95 villages in the districts of Dakoro, Guidan Roumdji, and Madar- ounfa, and exposed an estimated 80,000 to 100,000 farmers to FMNR."
Study_goal: "We address three key questions. First, how widespread is adoption of the tree conservation and management practices to which Nigerês re-greening has been attributed? Second, what factors determine a farmerês likelihood of adopting such practices? And third, what are the impacts of adoption of these practices on household livelihood outcomes?"
Study_location: Maradi region
Stated_outcomes: Impact of adoption of FMR on per capita gross income, crop diversity, tree density, tree diversity, migrant per household
Indicators: Food security (crop diversity, tree density and tree diversity as proxies)

Authors: Harada K, Prabowo D, Aliadi A, Ichihara J, Ma H
Title: How Can Social Safeguards of REDD+ Function Effectively Conserve Forests and Improve Local Livelihoods? A Case from Meru Betiri National Park, East Java, Indonesia
Author_affil: Graduate School of Bioagricultural Sciences, Department of Biosphere Resources Science, Nagoya University, Nagoya 4648601, Japan
Funding: Grant-in-Aid for Scientific Research (A) 22255012, (A) 24248026 and (C) 23510316 by the Japan Society for the Promotion of Science, and Japan Securities Scholarship Foundation in 2009
Stated_int: REDD+, Meru Betiri National Park
Desired_out: "The stated objective is to contribute to tropical forest conservation by enhancing community participation in conservation activities and sustainable park management. The project aims to achieve the following objectives: (1) to improve the livelihoods of local communities living inside and in the area surrounding the park and (2) to develop a credible measuring, reporting, and verifying (MRV) system for monitoring the reduction of emissions caused by deforestation and forest degradation and for enhancing forest carbon stocks in MBNP. The specific outputs from activities are: (1) improved participation of the local community in forest management; (2) developing alternative sources of income to improve the livelihoods of local communities living inside and in the area surrounding MBNP; (3) reduction and reporting of illegal logging and forest encroachment; (4) improving the capacity to conduct an inventory of the resource base and carbon accounting in a measurable, reportable, and verifiable form; (5) preparing a report on comprehensive baseline data and an estimation of the emissions reduction and carbon stock enhancement of the national park; and (6) establishing and validating a system for monitoring emissions reductions and the enhancement of carbon stocks."
Study_goal: "This study investigates whether REDD+ projects could generate sufficient economic incentives and social motivations for local people through participating in protecting forests, and draws implications for developing a national REDD+ strategy suitable for circumstances in the field. The research objectives have been: (1) to assess how the relationships between local people and national park authorities have been established through the REDD+ project; (2) to identify the positive social and economic impacts of the REDD+ project on local people; (3) to make clear local awareness of the national park and REDD+ project; and (4) to make clear motivations for participating in the REDD+ project. "
Study_location: Curahnongko, Sanenrejo villages inside and outside Meru Betiri National Park, Jawa Timur
Stated_outcomes: Difference in income between participants vs. non-participants
Indicators: Income from agriculture and REDD project activities
Outcome.direction_notes: Generally, income of participants smaller than non-participants

Authors: Harada K, Wiyono
Title: Certification of a Community-based Forest Enterprise for Improving Institutional Management and Household Income: A Case from Southeast Sulawesi, Indonesia
Author_affil: School of Human Science and Environment, University of Hyogo, 1-1-12, Shinzaike-honcho, Himeji, Hyogo 670-0092, Japan
Funding: Forest Conservation Project, Institute for Global Environmental Strategies (IGES), Japan, Grant-in-Aid for Scientific Research in 2011 and 2012 [(A) 22255012, (C) 23510316] and in 2012 [(A) 24248026], by the Japan Society for the Promotion of Science
Stated_int: Forest Stewardship Council (FSC) certification
Desired_out: "Activities carried out by TFT (Tropical Forest Trust), JAUH (Forest Network) and KHJL (cooperative for sustainable forests) with local people included: (1) introducing community forest certification programs to communities in 12 villages; (2) registering new members possessing teak forests; (3) organizing forest management training for KHJL staff; (4) creating community forest maps; (5) arranging an inventory of standing teak stocks; and (6) arranging documents necessary for acquiring certification. KHJL prepared for acquiring certification by: (1) making financial regulations for managing certified wood; (2) making standard operation procedures including membership, finance, forest inventory, monitoring, cutting trees and sawmill operation; and (3) preparing the management plan."
Study_goal: "This study investigates how FSC group certification can improve situations of community forest management while using forests in a sustainable manner, in the South Konawe district in Southeast Sulawesi, and draws implications for better community forestry in developing countries. The research objectives have been: (1) to assess how post-certification activities as a whole, including member regulations and producing certified wood, affect local communities; and (2) to analyze specific cases to evaluate how local people have been encouraged to accommodate certification for developing their community forest."
Study_location: South Konawe district, South Sulawesi province (3ç58.660_4ç31.520 S, 121ç58_123ç160 E)
Stated_outcomes: costs of timber extraction and transportation, land area allocated, value of product, overall income
Indicators: Shared costs for timber extraction and transportation
Outcome.direction_notes: Certified households shared less burden of cost

Authors: Hartter J
Title: Resource Use and Ecosystem Services in a Forest Park Landscape
Author_affil: Department of Geography, University of New Hampshire, Durham, New Hampshire, USA
Funding: National Science Foundation (number 0352008), the University of Florida (UF) Center for African Studies David L. Niddrie Memorial Scholarship, and a Working Forests in the Tropics Field Research Grant
Stated_int: Kibale National Park
Desired_out: Protect critical ecosystem
Study_goal: "The objective of this study was to gain a better understanding of local importance and uses of wetlands and forest fragments within the landscape surrounding Kibale, a forest park amidst dense agricultural settlement. I hypothesize that use of these areas depended on location, size for wetland or forest fragment, and demographic characteristics. Two questions are addressed: (1) What ecosystem goods and services are associated with wetlands and forest fragments2 around Kibale? (2) How do these goods and services vary by distance to the park boundary, distance to fragment, size of fragment, gender, wealth, and ethnicity?"
Study_location: Villages to east and west of Kibale National Park
Forest_type: Other non-forest environment with natural vegetation
Stated_outcomes: Perceived benefits from forests and wetlands in Kibale National Park
Indicators: Perception of ecosystem services in form of firewood, medicines, poles, crafts, and water
Outcome.direction_notes: Depends on ethnic group, gender and income group

Authors: Hashiguchi H, Pulhin JM, Dizon JT, Camacho LD
Title: Impacts of Community-Based Forest Management Policies Implemented by a Local Forest Institution: A Case Study from Bayombong, Nueva Vizcaya, Philippines
Author_affil: University of the Philippines Los Ban…os, College, 4031 Laguna, Philippines; Japan Forest Technology Association, 7 Rokuban-cho, Chiyoda-ku, Tokyo 102-0085, Japan
Stated_int: Community-based Forest Management (CBFM),  Federation of Vista Hills, Kalongkong and Kakilingan Upland Farmers, Inc. (Federation), the Vista Hills Upland Farmers Association (VHUFA), Kakilingan Upland Farmers Association (KUFA), and the Kalongkong Upland Farmers Association Inc. (KUFAI)
Desired_out: Forest tenure reforms entailed transferring bundles of rights to local entities through CBFM. CBFM aimed to alleviate poverty and prevent deforestation and forest degradation
Study_goal: "Specifically, the study aimed to: firstly, describe interventions of the Federation by applying LIFE indicators; secondly, elucidate the impact of these interventions on LIFE indicators; thirdly analyze the relations between the interventions and LIFE indicators; and lastly, provide policy implications to promote sustainable and equitable benefit flows from local forest governance."
Study_location: Barangay Buenavista in Bayombong, Nueva Vizcaya (121 2' E and 121 6' E and from 16 26'30"N to 16 29' N)
Stated_outcomes: Perceived changes in livelihood opportunities (land area with access, credit access), household incomes, forest condition (perception), equity (perception of participation, leadership, access to services, and benefit/cost sharing)
Portion_livelihood_amount: Varies, see Table 2
Indicators: Access to credit and savings
