Authors: Hayes T, Murtinho F, Wolff H
Title: An institutional analysis of Payment for Environmental Services on collectively managed lands in Ecuador
Author_affil: Institute of Public Service and Environmental Studies, Seattle University, 901 12th Ave, Seattle, WA 98122, United States; Center for the Study of Population, Institutions and Environmental Change (CIPEC), Indiana University, Bloomington, IN 47408, United States
Funding: National Science Foundation (grant # SES 1156271) and the Seattle University Center for Environmental Justice and Sustainability
Stated_int: Payments for Ecosystem Services, Programa Socio Bosque, Programa Socio Paramo
Desired_out: "In 2008, the Ecuadorian government instated PSB with the dual goals of preventing the destruction and degradation of native ecosystems, and increasing income and human capital in the poorest communities of Ecuador." "...Payments are intended to act as an incentive or compensation for conservation behaviors; the payments are not based on calculated opportunity costs." In July 2009, a sector of PSB was designated to focus on the paramo, particularly areas that are threatened, provide ecosystem services, and located in the poorest regions.
Study_goal: "an exploratory study that examines how participation in an Ecuadorian payment for conservation program, Programa Socio Bosque (PSB), is associated with communal resource management. Specifically, we examine (i) the presence of communal land-use rules and assess the degree to which PES participation, particularly PES payment, corresponds with the development of these rules; (ii) the characteristics of the communities that are making rule changes to produce additional conservation benefits as compared to those that are paid to maintain the status quo; and (iii) the application of the rule systems."
Study_location: Ecuadorian Andes paramo ecosystems
Stated_outcomes: Yearly payment in relationship to change in grazing rules
Indicators: Yearly payments in relation to degree of grazing rule change and restrictiveness

Authors: Hayes T, Murtinho F, Wolff H
Title: An institutional analysis of Payment for Environmental Services on collectively managed lands in Ecuador

Stated_int: Payments for Ecosystem Services, Programa Socio Bosque, Programa Socio Paramo
Desired_out: "In 2008, the Ecuadorian government instated PSB with the dual goals of preventing the destruction and degradation of native ecosystems, and increasing income and human capital in the poorest communities of Ecuador." "...Payments are intended to act as an incentive or compensation for conservation behaviors; the payments are not based on calculated opportunity costs." In July 2009, a sector of PSB was designated to focus on the paramo, particularly areas that are threatened, provide ecosystem services, and located in the poorest regions.
Study_goal: "an exploratory study that examines how participation in an Ecuadorian payment for conservation program, Programa Socio Bosque (PSB), is associated with communal resource management. Specifically, we examine (i) the presence of communal land-use rules and assess the degree to which PES participation, particularly PES payment, corresponds with the development of these rules; (ii) the characteristics of the communities that are making rule changes to produce additional conservation benefits as compared to those that are paid to maintain the status quo; and (iii) the application of the rule systems."
Study_location: Ecuadorian Andes paramo ecosystems
Forest_type: Other non-forest environment with natural vegetation
Stated_outcomes: Yearly payment in relationship to change in grazing rules
Indicators: Yearly payments in relation to degree of grazing rule change and restrictiveness

Authors: HEGDE R, BULL G, WUNDER S, KOZAK R
Title: Household participation in a Payments for Environmental Services programme: the Nhambita Forest Carbon Project (Mozambique)
Author_affil: Horticulture Australia, Economic Analysis, 3 Sligo Place, Prestons, NSW 2170, Australia
Funding: Financial support is acknowledged from the Hampton Grant from the University of British Columbia, the World Bank administered Trust Fund for Environmentally and Socially Sustainable Development through the Center for International Forestry Research (CIFOR), and the International Development Research Centre (IDRC) through a Doctoral Research Fellowship.
Stated_int: PES Program: small-scale agro-forestry based carbon sequestration pilot programme, known as the Nhambita Carbon Livelihoods Project
Desired_out: The programme aims to conserve and regenerate the miombo woodlands by offering both conditional financial compensation (i.e., PES) and alternative livelihood options through a community development component.
Int_dur: Initiated in 2002; pilot phase 2002-2008; continued after 2008
Study_goal: Using econometric analysis, we determine socio-economic factors influencing household participation, focusing on self-selection bias in the participant sample.
Study_location: Chicale Regulado (Traditional Authority), located in the buffer zone of the Gorongosa National Park (GNP) in Sofala Province, Mozambique. The pilot phase was limited to the villages of Nhambita, Bue Maria and Munhanganha, and was later expanded to Mbalawa and Pungue.
Stated_outcomes: Factors influencing program participation
Indicators: Factors influencing program participation (Probit regression)
Outcome.direction_notes: The coefficients estimated for the independent variables differed in direction.

Authors: Hickey G, Pouliot M, Smith-Hall C, Wunder S, Nielsen M
Title: Quantifying the economic contribution of wild food harvests to rural livelihoods: A global-comparative analysis
Author_affil: Department of Natural Resource Sciences, McGill University, Canada
Funding: Gordon M. Hickey acknowledges the receipt of a fellowship from the OECD Co-operative Research Programme: Biological Resource Management for Sustainable Agricultural Systems in 2014.
Stated_int: Biodiversity in the form of wild foods
Desired_out: Increased food security for poor & rural households
Study_goal: This paper empirically quantifies and analyses (i) the economic contribution of wild foods to rural households, (ii) the household socio-economic, demographic, and geographical correlates of wild food income, and (iii) how wild foods can be better incorporated into integrative food security policies.
Study_location: 24 developing countries
Sample_size: 7975 households. The final data set included 24 countries, 58 sites, 333 villages, and 7975 households.
Stated_outcomes: Wild food income and determinants of wild food income
Portion_livelihood_amount: See Figure 2: varies by income type and region.
Indicators: Wild food income, wild food income as percentage of total income, determinants of wild food income
Outcome.direction_notes: Wild foods supply income to all regions but the amount varies by region. Wild food income as a proportion of total household income also varies by region. The determinants of wild food income also vary.
Stated_mech: Wild food resources are also known to act as important nutritional and livelihood safety nets during periods of shortage, shock or livelihood disruption (both foreseeable and unforeseen) (Arnold et al., 2011; Vinceti et al., 2013; Shumsky et al., 2015; Wunder et al., 2014a), especially amongst the poorer sections of society (Shackleton and Shackleton, 2004).

Authors: Hogarth NJ
Title: The link between smallholder bamboo shoot management, income, and livelihoods: A case study in southern China
Author_affil: Research Institute for the Environment and Livelihoods, Charles Darwin University, Darwin, Northern Territory, Australia; Center for International Forestry Research, Bogor, Indonesia
Funding: Center for International Forestry Research (CIFOR), the Australian Agency for International Development, and the Research Institute for the Environment and Livelihoods (formerly the School for Environmental Research) at Charles Darwin University in Australia
Stated_int: Liulong Farm Bamboo Migrant Project
Desired_out: "Partnership between county government and private company involved in bamboo shoot processing and marketing, and is part of a province and nationwide voluntary rural resettlement program associated with the nationês wider rural poverty alleviation strategy." Migrants relocated from areas of high poverty, low opportunity to area to grow bamboo as cash crops. Plantation with housing and amenities built, along with infrastructure. "Migrants entered into a contractual relationship with both the county government (for the land) and the company (for the bamboo shoots), whereby the migrants were allowed to use their land only for growing bamboo and were under contract to sell their bamboo shoots exclusively to the company (the end market for the shoots was mostly Japan or Taiwan)."
Study_goal: "The aim of this paper is to assess the links between smallholder bamboo management practices, shoot yield (productivity), income, and livelihoods in a poor and mountainous county in southern China."
Study_location: 12 villages (2 migrant, 10 local) in Tianlin County (24 _ 258N, 105 _ 1068E)
Stated_outcomes: changes in productivity, income sources, perceptions of change in income
Indicators: Perception of change in overall income
Outcome.direction_notes: Decreasing overall income since start of project, perceived to be aligned with decrease in bamboo shoot productivity

Authors: Huang L, Shao Q, Liu J
Title: Forest restoration to achieve both ecological and economic progress, Poyang Lake basin, China
Author_affil: The Institute of Geographical Sciences and Natural Resources Research, Chinese Academy of Sciences, 100101 Beijing, China
Funding: National Natural Science Foundation of China (40971281, 41001366) and the Ministry of Science and Technology 973 Program (2009CB421105)
Stated_int: Mountain-River-Lake Program, forest restoration, lake and river restoration, poverty alleviation
Desired_out: "The Mountain-River-Lake Program (MRL) was launched in Chinaês Poyang Lake basin in 1983, and focused on eco-restoration and poverty reduction."..."The MRL program provides access to technology, financial resources and information to farmers who directly manage the ecosystems. Since 1997, participatory methods were introduced that involve farmers in the entire process of problem analysing, project planning, decision making, implementing, monitoring and evaluating, and follow-up management." "To move farmers away from a form of forestry that was focused on harvesting wood for fuel, the government encouraged the con- struction of infrastructure to provide methane generation facilities for every household. To increase the net income of farmers, addi- tional farming activities such as planting fruit trees, and raising pigs and fishes, were encouraged." "The government encouraged the transfer of land ownership to residents who were willing to plant trees and prohibit tree felling"
Study_goal: "To assess the efficacy of such a huge program, when the whole community was involved in pursuing a well-articulated environ- mental restoration and poverty reduction strategy, we evaluated the programês impacts by rigorous before and after comparisons in Poyang Lake basin, and identify the potential links between environmental policy and sustainability development"
Study_location: Poyang Lake basin (181 representative villages)
Stated_outcomes: Ecological effectiveness (forest cover, carbon sequestration, soil and water conservation), change in net income, ratio of net income to net consumption expenditure, change in number of persons below poverty line
Indicators: Change in net income from forest, farming, livestock, aquaculture, fruit trees, employment in methane plants
Outcome.direction_notes: Depends on type of income

Authors: Huang L, Shao Q, Liu J

Author_affil: The Institute of Geographical Sciences and Natural Resources Research, Chinese Academy of Sciences, 100101 Beijing, China

Authors: Islam KK, Sato N
Title: Protected Sal Forest and Livelihoods of Ethnic Minorities: Experience From Bangladesh
Author_affil: Forest Policy Laboratory, Kyushu University, Fukuoka, Japan
Funding: –Fuji Xerox, the Setsutaro Kobayashi Memorial Fund” and –Kyushu University Interdisciplinary Programs in Education and Projects in Research Development,” Japan
Stated_int: Madhupur National Park
Desired_out: Protected sal forest habitat and associated biodiversity. Forest Department initiated projects aimed to rehabilitate forest-dependent people through different types of training and allocating small funds for each household. Initiation of participatory forest programs.
Study_goal: "This article explores the role of protected sal forestsãnamely, the Madhupur National Park (MNP) on the livelihoods of forest-dependent ethnic minorities, drawing empirical data from ethnic households"
Study_location: Madhupur National Park (23_ 50_ to 24_ 50_ N, 89_ 54_ to 90_ 50_ E)
Stated_outcomes: Changes in forest cover, perceived changes in natural capital, financial capital, human capital, social capital and physical capital
Indicators: Perceptions on: increase training related to forest management, increased literacy rate, improved education facilities, improved children's education facilities
Outcome.direction_notes: Perceived that MNP has brought more training on forest management

Authors: Ite U, Adams W
Title: EXPECTATIONS, IMPACTS AND ATTITUDES: CONSERVATION AND DEVELOPMENT IN CROSS RIVER NATIONAL PARK, NIGERIA
Author_affil: Department of Geography, Cambridge University, UK
Funding: University of Cambridge from the Cambridge Commonwealth Trust. Grants and awards were also received from the Philip Lake Fund II, Bartle Frere Exhibition, Smuts Memorial Fund, and Churchill College. Further financial assistance was provided by the Overseas Research Students (ORS) award, Sutasoma Charitable Trust, Sir Ernest Cassell Educational Trust and the Humanitarian Trust
Stated_int: Support Zone Development Programme (SZDP), Cross River National Park
Desired_out: "The CRNP could achieve both the conservation goal of maintaining a globally important ecological area intact, and the development goal of improving the economic and social welfare of local people (Caldecott et al., 1990). This entailed the application of `carrots' of public benefits and a `stick' of regulations and enforcement in the villages within and bordering the Park." "The primary intention of the Support Zone Development Program was therefore to create a bu er zone around the protected forest area in a bid to reduce the apparent threats to the Park from incursion, resource use and forest loss."
Study_goal: "In this paper, we review an attempt to develop an ICDP in association with a TMF national park, Cross River National Park (CRNP) in southeast Nigeria (Figure 1). In the light of the expectations of local participants, we consider resulting attitudes to the park and to the ICDP project"
Study_location: Abo Mkpang, Kanyang 2 and Bokalum villages, Okwangwo Division
Stated_outcomes: Perceived benefits and disadvantages of National Park to households
Indicators: Transport

Authors: Jagger P
Title: FOREST INCOMES AFTER UGANDAêS FOREST SECTOR REFORM: Are the Rural Poor Gaining?
Author_affil: Indiana University
Funding: The Center for International Forestry Research (CIFOR); the CGIAR Systemwide Program on Collective Action and Property Rights Initiative (CAPRi); the National Science Foundation (NSF, grant number DDIG 0622392); the Social Sciences and Humanities Research Council of Canada (SSHRC); the Social Science Research Council (SSRC); and the Sustainable Agriculture and Natural Resource Management Collaborative Research Support Program (SANREM CRSP, grant number EPP-A-00- 04-00013-00).
Stated_int: Major forest sector governance reform in Uganda (decentralization): The reform involved changes in the ownership and management of 85 percent of Ugandaês forested land. A new forest policy, a strategic forest sector plan, and new legislation were developed during the forest sector review process. The centralized Forest Department was dismantled, and the decentralized District Forestry Service (DFS) and the for-profit parastatal National Forestry Authority (NFA) were created.
Desired_out: More sustainable forest management; improved livelihoods.
Study_goal: The study aims to evaluate the effect of forest sector reforms on rural livelihoods
Study_location: 4 forest sites located in the northernmost section of the Albertine Rift; the area stretching between Lake Albert and Lake Edward: Rwenzori Mountains National Park, Bugoma Central Forest Reserve, Budongo Central Forest Reserve, Kasagala Central Forest Reserve were in the baseline; all but Kasagala Central Forest Reserve included in the follow-up.
Study_duration: Baseline: late 2003; follow-up: between October 2006 and August 2007
Stated_outcomes: Impacts on household income by Forest Site and Income Quartile for before and after intervention
Portion_livelihood_amount: Portion is provided by forest site and income group before and after intervention and varies for each. See Table 8 in paper.
Indicators: Adjusted household total income by forest site and income quartile
Outcome.direction_notes: With one exception, there have been increases in income across all forest sites and income quartiles. In all forest sites the largest increases in income are observed in the lowest income quartile. Absolute income from forests for the Bugoma forest site slightly decreased.

Authors: Jumbe C, Angelsen A
Title: Has Forest Co-management in Malawi Benefited the Poor?
Journal: Book: Political Institutions and Development: Failed Expectations and Renewed Hopes
Stated_int: Devolution of forest rights and management: Forest co-management in Malawi. 1996 National Forestry Policy & National Forestry Program. Specifically, In 1996 the World Bank and the British government, through the Department for International Development initiated a pilot forest co-management program in Malawi.
Desired_out: Sustainable management, improved livelihoods: The program was designed to promote local participation in forest management in exchange for the benefits of long-term sustainable management, such as continued access to fuel wood, poles and non-timber forest products
Study_goal: This chapter seeks to address the following questions: Do the poor benefit from participating in the forest co-management program as intended? Are there any biases in the distribution of forest income among different participants and, if so, what are the sources of inequality?
Study_location: Chimaliro and Liwonde forest reserves, in the North-Central and Southern regions of Malawi, respectively.
Sample_size: 404 randomly selected households: 205 households from 20 villages in Chimaliro and 199 households from 11 villages in Liwonde.
Stated_outcomes: Impacts of participation in the forest co-management program on household income
Portion_livelihood_amount: The average monthly forest incomes per household for low- and high-income households are estimated at MK237 ($3'.12) and MK620 ($8.15) respectively, which accounts for 8 per cent of their respective average monthly incomes.
Indicators: Average monthly forest income differentials between participants and non-participants for each study area, by household income level, and by gender. Matching estimates of income gains from forest co-management.
Outcome.direction_notes: Yes see Table 6.3 in paper (raw data). Table 6.4 shows the results of both selection-bias adjusted and unadjusted estimates of the average treatment effects on the treated (ATET).The table shows that selection-bias unadjusted estimates of ATET are consistently negative (except for the female subsample) and not statistically significant across subsamples. This suggests that the program does not increase the income of program participants. Table 6.6 shows male-female income decomposition; Table 6.8 shows high-low (household income category) income decomposition.  From the decomposition analyses, our empirical results show that statistical 'discrimination' is the source of income disparity between male and female participants, accounting for 100 per cent of the total income differential, while the income disparity between high- and low-income participants is mainly due to the differences in endowments. This is consistent with the descriptive data, where high-income households have better endowments than low-income households in terms of age, education and household assets (land, livestock and private woodlots) which affect forest income.

Authors: Jumbe C, Angelsen A
Title: Do the Poor Benefit from Devolution Policies? Evidence from Malawi's Forest Co-Management Program
Author_affil: Charles B. L. Jumbe was a research fellow in the Department of Economics and Resource Management, Norwegian University of Life Sciences and is now a research fellow at the Centre for Agricultural Research and Development, Bunda College of Agriculture, Lilongwe, Malawi.
Stated_int: Pilot forest co-management program in Malawi
Desired_out: In 1996, the World Bank (WB) and British Government through the Department for International Development (DFID) supported a pilot forest co-management program in Malawi whose primary objective was to promote local participation in forest management in exchange for various benefits resulting from the long-term sustainable management such as access to fuelwood, poles, and non-timber forest products.
Study_goal: Using household data from Chimaliro and Liwonde forest reserves under pilot forest co-management program in Malawi, this paper seeks to address the following questions: do the poor benefit from participating in the forest co management program as intended? Are there any biases in the distribution of forest income among different participants, and if so, what are the sources of inequality?
Study_location: Chimaliro and Liwonde forest reserves located in the central/northern and southern regions of Malawi.
Sample_size: The main survey covered 404 randomly selected households: 205 households from 20 villages in Chimaliro and 199 households from 11 villages in Liwonde
Stated_outcomes: Forest income: selection bias-adjusted estimates of the program impact on income across participants and non-participants
Portion_livelihood_amount: See Table 1 (Summary Statistics), which provides the monthly forest income and monthly total income for participations, non-participants, and by gender and poverty class.
Indicators: selection bias-adjusted estimates of forest income for participants vs. non-participants
Outcome.direction_notes: In Chimaliro program has minor positive impact on household income, at least in the short run. In contrast, estimates from all the four matching methods in Liwonde are consistently negative and highly significant, suggesting that forest co-management program has negative effects on income of participants. Results are also provided for low vs. high income households, and female vs. male headed households. In general, results from Table 4 suggest that the program generates positive income gains to female participants ranging from MK11 (US$0.14) to MK29 (US$0.39) per month per household, representing an increase in income of between 13% and 65% from what they would have earned had they not participated in the program. day selling of fuelwood along the main road. Similarly, empirical results from all the matching methods in the table indicate that low-income participants earn more forest income by participating in the program. We find that income gains to low income participants lie between MK13 (US$0.18) and MK26 (US$0.34) per month per household, an increase in forest income of between 35% and 98% from what they would have earned without participating in the program.

Authors: Kabubo-Mariara J
Title: Forest-poverty nexus: Exploring the contribution of foreststo rural livelihoods in Kenya
Author_affil: School of Economics, University ofNairobi, Kenya
Funding: Centre of EnvironmentalEconomics and Policy in Africa (CEEPA)
Desired_out: Intervention with history of crop areas reforested to an agroforestry type of system (shambas), reconverted into cultivation land. This was managed as a "non resident cultivation system" but led to widespread clearing of trees with little reforestation. NRC was stopped and only continued on a pilot basis in two areas where they started reforestation.
Study_goal: "First, it investigates the level of household dependence on forest environmental incomes by different forest user groups; second, it analyzes the distribution of forest environmental incomes between these groups; and third, it analyzes the role of user group and household heterogeneities in forest resource use and household welfare
Study_location: Seven villages in Bahati division, Nakuru district
Stated_outcomes: Income and income shares by source, dependence on forest products, determinants of resource extraction, determinants of forest dependence
Indicators: Income from forest crop farming, forest collection, crop farming, wages, self-employment, transfers, livestock products
Outcome.direction_notes: Varies between forest adjacent communities, NRCs without plot, and NRCs with plot

Authors: Karki ST
Title: Do protected areas and conservation incentives contribute to sustainable livelihoods? A case study of Bardia National Park, Nepal
Author_affil: School of Business Management and Economics, University of Sussex, Brighton BN1 9SL, UK
Funding: Rufford Small Grant programme, UK, the Royal Geographical Society, and the World Wildlife Fund, Nepal
Stated_int: Bardia National Park, compensatory and incentive-based programs (IBPs)
Desired_out: Bardia National Park declared to protect lowland Terai ecosystem. Incentive-based programs carried out by various NGOs in form of development projects that aim to support "both social and economic activities within the buffer zone area and wildlife conservation in the park. The IBPs include income generation activities, training, school development, infra- structure support, machine donation, toilet building, scholarship, livestock donation and agricultural support and have been implemented since the early 1990s through joint collaboration between park authorities and international donors"
Study_goal: "this paper uses the sustainable livelihoods approach to examine the livelihood impacts of protected area and conservation incentives at Bardia National Park"
Study_location: Thakurdwara, Shivapur, Suryapatuwa villages, near Bardia National Park
Stated_outcomes: Livelihood capitals (compared between villages), impact of conservation incentives on household livelihoods
Indicators: Perception that development programs provide support for livelihood diversification
Outcome.direction_notes: Smaller percentage of wealthy and poor classes (25%/20%) thought that programs support livelihood diversification than middle class (55%). Similarly, 40-50% of Tharu and higher caste classes thought that program support diversification while lower class did not (~20%)

Authors: Kaushal K, Melkani V, Kala J
Title: Sustainable poverty alleviation through a forestry project in Tamilnadu State of India
Journal: International Journal of Sustainable Development & World Ecology
Author_affil: Deputy Conservator of Forests, Chinnachokkikulum, Madurai, Tamilnadu, India
Funding: Funding for Allen Blackmanês participation was provided by the IDB and the National Space and Aeronautics Administration (NASA) through the Servir Applied Science Team.
Stated_int: Protected areas in the Peruvian Amazon
Desired_out: Biodiversity conservation
Int_dur: Peru's first protected area was created in 1961. As of 2012, Peru had 111 national protected areas and 70 regional or private protected areas.
Study_goal: Our study makes several contributions. To our knowledge, it provides the first rigorous evidenceãobtained by controlling for protected areasê nonrandom sitingãfor the Amazon on the effects of protected areas on both forest cover change and local communities. We bring to bear particularly rich data. We compare the effectiveness for both outcomes within the same time frame, thus minimizing potential for bias due to mismatched temporal data. We use detailed household-level data as measured by the Peruvian government, comparing expenditures with a predefined poverty line (rather than a proxy poverty index).
Study_location: Peruvian Amazon
Study_duration: 2007 Peruvian census for household data (household characteristics and expenditure from 2001 to 2006). Only protected areas established before 2000, the first year of our study period, are included in the analysis.
Stated_outcomes: Effect on deforestation. Effects on local communities: total expenditure per capita (in Peruvian soles), total income per capita (in Peruvian soles), poverty rate, and extreme poverty rate.
Indicators: Total expenditure per capita (in Peruvian soles), total income per capita (in Peruvian soles), poverty rate, and extreme poverty rate
Outcome.direction_notes: For households living in a 5-km buffer, protected areas exacerbate extreme poverty. However, protected areas do not have a statistically significant effect on the other three socioeconomic indicators. For households living within a 10-km buffer, the effect of protected areas on extreme poverty vanishes. The effect on expenditure is positive and weakly significant. Hence, there is some indication, but certainly not a strong one, that protected areas may have adverse socioeconomic effects on local communities.

Authors: KHATRI-CHHETRI A
Title: Local Institutions and Forest Products Extraction: Evidence from Forest Management in Nepal
Author_affil: Institute of Agriculture and Animal Science Chitwan, Nepal
Funding: This research received generous financial support from the South Asian Network for Development and Environmental Economics.
Stated_int: Decentralization of forest management in Nepal
Desired_out: Sustainable management of forest resources; improved livelihoods
Study_goal: This study seeks to understand the implications of local institutions on forest products extraction and benefit distribution among the users. It examines NTFPs extraction in two communities: one, a government-sponsored formal forest user group and the other, a self-initiated informal forest user group. The key questions addressed in this paper are the following: (i) what are the rules and regulations of NTFP collection in the two types of forest management systems? (ii) how and to what extent does NTFP use differ among the households? (iii) what socio-economic and institutional factors are correlated with differences in NTFP collection?
Study_location: 2 villages: Chuja with government-sponsored formal FUG, and Gobanpani with self-initiated community forest management in Pyuthan district of Nepal, which is located in the middle mountain region
Stated_outcomes: Impact of different programs on household income: Contribution of NTFPs extracted from common property to total household gross income based on wealth group; Effect of income level on total NTFPs extraction and dependence on NTFPs; socio-economic determinants of forest dependency
Portion_livelihood_amount: Table 4 shows annual average income from private forests for the formal FUG & informal FUG groups. Table 7 shows Contribution of NTFPs extracted from common property to total household gross income based on wealth group.
Indicators: Contribution of NTFPs extracted from common property to total household gross income based on wealth group; Effect of income level on total NTFPs extraction and dependence on NTFPs; socio-economic determinants of forest dependency
Outcome.direction_notes: Table 7 shows the average share of gross NTFP income from community forest to total income (agriculture + livestock + off farm wages + private forest land) of the households. Forest resource dependence decreases with increase in wealth. Table 6 and Table 7 indicate that the rich households are not all that dependent on common property resources although they use more natural resources in terms of quantity. Table 8 presents the regression results of the effect of income level on total NTFPs extraction and dependence on NTFPs. Regression of NTFPs income to total income and income squared shows that within a range of household income NTFPs extraction increases and then falls with the increase in total income. The second regression of ratio of NTFPs income to total income indicates that a householdês dependence decreases gradually with a higher income level. But the positive sign with income squared indicates that NTFPs dependence on forest decreases at an increasing rate. This means that very rich households seldom go to the forest for NTFPs collection. In the regression analysis, only familysize, landholding, and distance from the forest have statisticallysignificant effects on NTFPs extraction in the informal FUG village and these effects are fairly large.

Authors: Kibria ASMG, Jashimuddin M, Makoto I
Title: Effects of participatory forest management on livelihood capitals of the community in Cox's Bazar, Bangladesh
Author_affil: Laboratory of Global Forest Environmental Studies, Department of Global Agricultural Sciences, Graduate School of Global Agriculture and Life Sciences, The University of Tokyo
Funding: University Grants Commission of Bangladesh
Stated_int: Participatory forest management
Desired_out: "The projects studied were aimed at poor forest-dependent people in engaging in PF to improve their livelihoods and consequently to reduce the forest destruction." "The Forest Department in Coxês Bazar followed the interval of 2 m 9 2 m for planting trees in PF project areas. Each participant was allotted a 1- or 2-ha plantation under the PF program based on land availability. Rotation of the plantation was fixed as 10 years by the Forest Department. After the final harvest, each participant will receive 45 % of the total return of their allotted plantation. The Forest Department will receive 45 % of the final return as the cost of management of the plantation. And the remaining part of the return (i.e., 10 %) will be deposited in a tree farming fund (TFF) for the next term of plantations. But other returns such as fuel wood, litter, or products from intermediate tending operations were enjoyed solely by the participants"
Study_goal: "this research was attempted to analyze the effects of PF on the livelihood capital of the participants in Coxês Bazar."
Study_location: 21ç350 000 N and 92ç010 000 E (Dulahazara Beat of Fashiakhali Range and Fulchari Beat of Fulchari Range in Coxês Bazar North Forest Division, and Panerchar Beat of Panerchara Range and Khuniapalong Beat of Khuniap- along Range in Coxês Bazar South Forest Division - Cox's Bazar district)
Stated_outcomes: Income sources, human capital, physical capital, financial capital, natural capital, social capital
Indicators: Income from home garden and agriculture
Outcome.direction_notes: Increase for agriculture after, decreased for home garden after. Also compared to non-participants

Authors: Kohlin G, Amacher GS
Title: Welfare Implications of Community Forest Plantations in Developing Countries: The Orissa Social Forestry Project
Author_affil: Environmental Economics Unit, Department of Economics, Goteborg University, Box 640, SE 405 30 Goteborg, Sweden
Stated_int: Orissa Social Forestry Project, reforestation
Desired_out: "During 1983-1995, [Swedish International Development Agency] supported the Orissa Social Forestry Project, which involved planting more than 100,000 ha of [community forest]. Both leaf matter and twigs have become an important source of fuel in these forests"
Study_goal: "Our purpose in this article is to examine the effect of Orissa's social forestry project on both collection time costs and welfare of rural poor who rely on forests for fuel."
Study_location: Villages in and around Dhani Forest, Orissa
Stated_outcomes: Probability of collection of fuelwood from forest, time to collect fueldwood
Indicators: Fuelwood collection - determining factors

Authors: Korhonen K, Rahkonen O, Hemminki E
Title: Implications of integrated nature conservation for human reproductive health: a case study from Ranomafana National Park, Madagascar
Author_affil: Department of Social Policy, University of Helsinki
Funding: Academy of Finland (projects 02-530-001 and 45664)
Stated_int: Ranomafana National Park, integrated conservation and development project (ICDP), health interventions
Desired_out: Protect lemur habitat. Linked projects to establish ecotourism and economic rural development, improve health, conservation education and conduct biodiversity research. Health care interventions intended to provide treatment of basic illnesses, health education, preventive care (vaccines, family planning, sanitation, health centers)
Study_goal: The main objective of the study is to examine the possible change in reproductive health, as measured by the onset of reproductive life, fertility, modern contraceptive use, birth conditions, prenatal health care and infant mortality. We evaluate whether the villages in the park area, according to reproductive indicators, differ from those outside and if so, whether the reason is the ICDP. Using a comparative approach, the impact of the ICDP can be estimated
Study_location: Villages inside and outside of Ranomafana National Park
Stated_outcomes: Number of girls in school, age of first sexual activity and first child, use of contraceptives, number of prenatal visits, infant mortality
Indicators: Percentage of girls in school at primary and third grade

Authors: Korhonen K, Rahkonen O, Hemminki E
Title: Implications of integrated nature conservation for human reproductive health: a case study from Ranomafana National Park, Madagascar
Author_affil: Department of Social Policy, University of Helsinki
Funding: Academy of Finland (projects 02-530-001 and 45664)
Stated_int: Ranomafana National Park, integrated conservation and development project (ICDP), health interventions
Desired_out: Protect lemur habitat. Linked projects to establish ecotourism and economic rural development, improve health, conservation education and conduct biodiversity research. Health care interventions intended to provide treatment of basic illnesses, health education, preventive care (vaccines, family planning, sanitation, health centers)
Study_goal: The main objective of the study is to examine the possible change in reproductive health, as measured by the onset of reproductive life, fertility, modern contraceptive use, birth conditions, prenatal health care and infant mortality. We evaluate whether the villages in the park area, according to reproductive indicators, differ from those outside and if so, whether the reason is the ICDP. Using a comparative approach, the impact of the ICDP can be estimated
Study_location: Villages inside and outside of Ranomafana National Park
Stated_outcomes: Number of girls in school, age of first sexual activity and first child, use of contraceptives, number of prenatal visits, infant mortality
Indicators: Age of first sexual activity, age of having first child, use of contraceptives, access to prenatal health care, infant mortality

Authors: Kumar S
Title: Does ••Participationêê in Common Pool Resource Management Help the Poor? A Social Cost_Benefit Analysis of Joint Forest Management in Jharkhand, India
Author_affil: University of Cambridge, UK
Funding: Society for Promotion of Wastelands Development, New Delhi
Stated_int: Joint Forest Management (JFM), Village Forest Committee (VFC)
Desired_out: "In a follow-up document issued in 1990, Central government issued guidelines to all State governments to implement ••joint forest management systems in order to regenerate forests and reduce rural poverty.... These guidelines suggested that the State governments may devolve everyday forest protection, management and development responsibilities to local community institutions (co-operative or committee-based) at the village or panchayat levels, 8 and prescribe benefit-sharing arrangements following regeneration"
Study_goal: "The paper begins with a description of Indiaês forest problems and policies, and a more specific account of the assumptions about ••communityêê and ••rural povertyêê that inform the agendas of Joint Forest Management (Section 2). Section 3 describes the patterns of community stratification and forest use in the study area, and in Section 4 the assumptions that underpin the social cost_benefit model are reviewed. Section 5 presents the main findings. It concludes that nonpoor members of VFCs determine the social time preference of JFM. It also shows how the management regimes for JFM forests that are put into place by VFCs must discriminate against the poor, often to a debilitating extent. Section 6 highlights the need for a more comprehensive SCBA that would take into account the value of local ecological services from JFM forests."
Study_location: Sarsa, Kelende, Bisa, Sadma, Banadag, Saheda, Tengariya, Bargainbanda villages - Ranchi District, Jharkhand State
Stated_outcomes: Change in costs and benefits to households from forests under JFM versus those not under JFM, Number of trees
Indicators: Change in monetary value of net benefits to households from forests under JFM regime over forests not under JFM
Outcome.direction_notes: Differs based on socio-economic class (landless, marginal farmer, small farmer, medium farmer, large farmer)

Authors: Lambini CK, Nguyen TT
Title: A comparative analysis of the effects of institutional property rights on forest livelihoods and forest conditions: Evidence from Ghana and Vietnam
Author_affil: BayCEER, Bayreuth University, Universitaetstr. 30, 95440 Bayreuth, Germany
Stated_int: Forest institutional property rights
Desired_out: "Effective and robust forest institutional property rights are increasingly becoming an important part on the allocation of scarce forest resources and a solution to the –tragedy of the commons”"
Study_goal: "The main motivation of this study is our need to understand the role of institutions, property rights on livelihoods in a forestry context and examine the connectivity of these three concepts. This need has a theoretical offset hence our attempt to operationalise using a broad framework for conceptualisation. This is addressed by answering the following explicit three questions: (1) what is the –state of the art” literature on institutional property rights in re- source management? This helps in the decomposition of property rights linkages on livelihoods and forest conditions; (2) how to comparatively evaluate these property rights effects on livelihoods and forest conditions as outcomes in an empirical micro level?; and (3) how to integrate these findings into building models for sustainable future design of forest insti- tutional property rights arrangements?"
Study_location: Vietnam, Ghana
Stated_outcomes: Change in livelihoods, change in forest conditions, change in access
Indicators: Change in livelihoods
Outcome.direction_notes: Not improved in Ghana, improved in Vietnam

Authors: Le HD, Smith C, Herbohn J
Title: What drives the success of reforestation projects in tropical developing countries? The case of the Philippines
Author_affil: School of Agriculture and Food Sciences, The University of Queensland, St. Lucia, Brisbane, QLD 4072, Australia; Economics and Business Management Faculty, Vietnam Forestry University, Xuan Mai, Chuong My, Hanoi, Viet Nam
Stated_int: Reforestation
Desired_out: Restore forest cover, provide environmental services, supply timber, contribute to livelihoods. Includes community-based forest management agreements, non-community-based forest management agreement, rainforestation farms, socialised industrial forest management agreement, integrated forest management agreement, individual private reforestation
Study_goal: "The aim of this paper is to gain a deeper understanding of these relationships by investigating the drivers that have determined reforestation success in the Philippines. We do this by surveying 43 reforestation projects on Leyte Island, covering 98 potential drivers and 12 success indicators."
Study_location: Leyte Island
Stated_outcomes: Change in forest cover, change in soil erosion, change in jobs, market access, food security
Indicators: Employment in reforestation and fencing

Authors: Leclercq, B.
Title: Links Between Conservation/Development Projects and International Conventions and Programs : The Southeastern Rainforest of Madagascar
Stated_int: ICDP, UNESCO World Heritage Conservation, Midongy-Befotaka National Park
Desired_out: Build development and human capital around Midongy-Befotaka National Park
Study_goal: The aim of the study was to evaluate the factors impacting the effectiveness of Integrated Conservation and Development Projects (ICDPs), both in terms of benefits to people living near protected areas and the attenuation of pressures exerted on the environment
Study_location: Midongy-Befotaka National Park
Stated_outcomes: Health (disease, immunizations, health centers, childhood mortality, drinking water), Education (literacy, education obtained),
Indicators: education obtained, literacy

Authors: Lewark S, George L, Karmann M
Title: Study of gender equality in community based forest certification programmes in Nepal
Author_affil: Faculty of Forest and Environmental Science, University of D-79085 Freiburg, Germany, M and E Program FSC International, D-53113 Bonn, Germany
Funding: The pilot certification project was technically and financially supported through a broad multinational Private Public Alliance (PPA), coordinated by ANSAB. Partners of the PPA were community forest user groups, the Federation of Community Forestry Users of Nepal (FECOFUN), environmental non-governmental organizations (NGO) from the United States (US) of America (The Rainforest Alliance, (RA)) and from Nepal, representatives of the Nepali government, private companies dealing in environmental products (e.g. Aveda(TM) and Nepali companies), and donor organizations (The Ford Foundation, the Netherlands Development Organization (SNV) and the US Agency for International Development (USAID).
Stated_int: Forest Stewardship Council certification, community-based forest management (community forest user groups)
Desired_out: FECOFUNês programme focuses on improving the social and economic conditions of community forest user groups (CFUG), particularly focusing on the least privileged groups, in introducing CFUGs to the concepts of sustainable management, enterprise development, effective market access through forest certification, and helping them set up cooperatives/ community based companies and using the proper marketing information systems
Study_goal: _ Are men and women involved in different activities related to use of forests? _ What are the forest products gathered by men and women _ before and after certification? _ What is the participation of men and women in committees and subcommittees? _ How do men and women perceive the forest manage- ment practices, forest conditions and their living conditions after implementation of certification requirements?
Study_location: Sushpa CFUG, Bhitteri Phaka CFUG (Dolakha district)
Stated_outcomes: Forest products gathered before and after certification by men and women, perception of living conditions after certification
Indicators: Forest products collected before and after certification
Outcome.direction_notes: men and women

Authors: Li J, Feldman MW, Li S, Daily GC
Title: Rural household income and inequality under the Sloping Land Conversion Program in western China
Journal: Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences
Author_affil: Institute of Population and Development Studies, School of Public Policy and Administration, Xian Jiaotong University, Xiêan, Shaanxi Province 710049, China
Funding: China National Natural Science Fund (70773094), the Program for Changjiang Scholars and Innovative Research Team in University (PCSIRT 0855), the Natural Capital Project (a partnership among Stanford University, The Nature Conservancy, the World Wildlife Fund, and the University of Minnesota), and the Morrison Institute for Population and Resource Studies at Stanford University
Stated_int: Sloping Land Conversion Program, Payments for Ecosystem Services
Desired_out: "The SLCP provides farmers with grain and cash subsidies in exchange for converting cropland on steep slopes to much less erodible forest and grassland." "The Chinese government aims to reduce the loss of soil, improve water retention, and generally protect bio- diversity and ecosystems in the west of the country for flood control, hydropower production efficiency, and ecotourism. In addition, it wants to change the economic structure in mountainous areas to increase local household income while simultaneously making local householdsê patterns of land utilization and agricultural production more sustainable"
Study_goal: "This paper focuses on a remote rural area in western China where the SLCP has been enforced since 2000. We first introduce the study area, the sampling method, the analytical framework, and methods and then assess the impacts of SLCP on rural household incomes, and inequality among these households, us- ing data and information from interviews and a survey."
Study_location: 15 vilages in Zhouzhi County, Xi'an Shaanxi Province
Stated_outcomes: Income levels from different sources, income inequality
Indicators: Income from different sources between participating and non-participating households
Outcome.direction_notes: See figure 1

Authors: Liang Y, Li S, Feldman MW, Daily GC
Title: Does household composition matter? The impact of the Grain for Green Program on rural livelihoods in China
Author_affil: Center for conservation Biology, Department of Biology, Stanford University, Stanford, CA 94305, USA; Institute for Population and Development Studies, School of Public Policy and Administration, Xi'an Jiaotong University, Xi'an, Shaanxi Province 710049, China
Funding: Programs for Changjiang Scholars and Innovative Research Team (IRT0855) in Universities of the Ministry of Education of China, the 985-3 Project of Xi'an Jiaotong University, the National Natural Science Foundation of China (70773094), the Natural Capital Project (a partnership among TNC, WWF, and Stanford University), and the Morrison Institute for Population and Resource Studies at Stanford University
Stated_int: Grain for Green Program, payments for ecosystem services, reforestation
Desired_out: Households enrolled in the program did not cultivate sloping cropland but planted mainly –economic trees” instead, including Cornus, walnuts, and pepper.
Study_goal: "Our main objective in this study is to address different impacts of the policy on rural households' livelihoods, depending on the households' demographic characteristics, and our particular focus is on household composition."
Study_location: 4 towns in Zhouzhi County, Shaanxi Province
Stated_outcomes: Key assets, time allocation, income
Indicators: Aggregated assets compared between participants and non-participants
Outcome.direction_notes: Depends on household composition (children, adults, elderly)

Authors: Liu C, Lu J, Yin R
Title: An Estimation of the Effects of Chinaês Priority Forestry Programs on Farmersê Income
Author_affil: China National Forestry Economics and Development Research Center, State Forestry Administration, East Heping Street No. 18, Beijing, Peopleês Republic of China
Funding: Technical Assistance (TA-4307) of Asian Development Bank, Ministry of Finance of Peoplesê Republic of China, and the U.S. National Science Foundation
Stated_int: Natural Forest Protection Program, Sloping Land Conversion Program (Grain for Green), Wildlife Conservation and Nature Reserve Development Program, Shelterbelt Development Program, Desertification Combating around Beijing and Tianjing, Industrial Timber Plantation Development Program
Desired_out: "To enhance the income of its rural residents as well as to improve its environmental and resource conditions, the Chinese government initiated some new programs and consolidated other existing ones of ecological restoration and resource development in its forest sector in the late 1990s, and renamed them as ••Priority Forestry Programsêê or PFPs"
Study_goal: "The analytic focus of this article is the impacts of the PFPs on farmersê income."
Study_location: Hebei province (Zhangbei, Pingquan), Jiangxi province (Xiushui, Suichuan county), Shaanxi province (Yanchang, Zhenan county), Sichuan county (Mabian, Nanbu, Nanjiang county)
Stated_outcomes: Impact of programs on income
Indicators: Reported income

Authors: Lund JF, Baral K, Bhandari NS, Chhetri BBK, Larsen HO, Nielsen OJ, Puri L, Rutt RL, Treue T
Title: Who benefits from taxation of forest products in Nepal's community forests?
Author_affil: Department of Food and Resource Economics, Faculty of Science, University of Copenhagen, Rolighedsvej 25, DK-1958 Frederiksberg C, Denmark
Funding: Consultative Research Committee at the Danish Ministry of Foreign Affairs (grant no. 104.Dan.8.L.716), The Danish Council for Independent Research-Social Sciences (j.no. 09-063842)
Stated_int: Community forest user groups, community forestry
Desired_out: "improve the efficiency of natural resources management and/or induce a more equitable distribution accruing from such resources"
Study_goal: "The objectives of the study are two-fold; to document who benefits from community forestry user groups' (CFUG) financing of investments in public services and infrastructure and pro-poor initiatives and to explore whether biases against certain groups in investments coincide with biases in their participation in decision-making."
Study_location: Baglung, Gorkha and Kaski districts
Stated_outcomes: average annual CFUG income, average CFUG annual expenditures, membership distribution of CFUG executive committee, access to public services, perception of benefit from public infrastructure
Indicators: Monetary value of income distribution through sale of wood and non-wood products, user costs, support from donors and NGOs, and other income - compared between income groups
Outcome.direction_notes: Table 1

Study_location: Baglung, Gorkha and Kaski districts

Indicators: Annual expenditures for CFUGs - forest management, public services and infrastructure, office administration and other expenses
Outcome.direction_notes: Higher expenditures for wealthier CFUGs

Authors: Lund JF, Treue T
Title: Are We Getting There? Evidence of Decentralized Forest Management from the Tanzanian Miombo Woodlands
Author_affil: University of Copenhagen, Frederiksberg, Denmark
Funding: The Danish Council for Development Research, O.H.F. and A.J.-E. Heilmanns Fond, and Oticon Fonden
Stated_int: Decentralized forest management, MEMA projects
Desired_out: Transferring rights to and powers over forest resources to locally democratically elected bodies. Danida-funded MEMA Projects - villages "received support to initiate awareness campaigns in the village, delineate and demarcate its village land and forest reserve boundaries, formulate a forest management plan, and begin managing its village land forest reserve (VLFR). While delimitating the VLFR, open access to other woodland areas, where the majority of villagers gather firewood, was deliberately maintained."
Int_dur: Policies enacted 1995-2003, national program from 2003 onwards
Study_goal: "Drawing on several months of field work over four years in Mfyome village, South-western Tanzania, we will present the outcomes of a recent forest decentralization process. First, we present the case study context and methods. Second, the current outcome of decentralized forest man- agement is presented in terms of effects on (i) resource conservation, (ii) rural livelihoods, and (iii) good governance."
Study_location: Matembo and Msosa sub-village in Mfyome village
Stated_outcomes: Difference in forest income between wealth quartiles, access to markets, access to land
Indicators: Total household income per adult split between cash and non-cash income from different sources
Outcome.direction_notes: See table 2

Authors: Ly N
Title: Evaluating the Pilot Implementation of Payment for Forest Environmental Services in Lam Dong, Vietnam
Author_affil: Department of Environmental and Natural Resource Economics, Faculty of Economics, University of Agriculture and Forestry (UAF), Linh Trung Ward, Thu Duc District, Ho Chi Minh City, Vietnam
Funding: The Economy and Environment Program for Southeast Asia (EEPSEA)
Stated_int: Pilot payment for forest environmental services (PFES) policy in Lam Dong Province, Vietnam. In April 2008, the Vietnam government issued Decision no. 380/Q_-TTg to implement payment for forest environmental services nationwide. The policy aims to make PFES compulsory in Vietnam, but it was first piloted for a two-year period in Lam Dong and Son La provinces. Experiences and lessons learned in the Vietnamese context were used to build a national policy (2011 onwards).
Desired_out: Ecosystem conservation, livelihood improvements
Study_goal: This study aims to assess the performance and the short-term impacts of the payment for forest environmental services (PFES) policy in Lam Dong Province, Vietnam. Economic and environmental impacts were evaluated by estimating the changes in local income, forest area, amount of illegal logging, and forest density/quality since the program was implemented.
Study_location: Study focuses on the implementation of the policy in four piloted zones: three districts _ Lac Duong, Don Duong, Duc Trong _ and Da Lat City.
Sample_size: 749 households were interviewed, broken down into 366 participants and 383 nonparticipants. The 366 participant households were from Da Lat City (46) and the districts of Don Duong (56), Lac Duong (129), and Duc Trong (123)
Study_duration: Households had participated in the PES up to December 2010
Stated_outcomes: Effect of participating in the PFES pilot on various economic and environmental variables.
Indicators: effect of participating in the PFES pilot on annual household income
Outcome.direction_notes: Findings show a VND 3.95 million positive impact of program participation on annual household income. Although the T-value has increased to 1.34, the result is not significant at the 10% level of significance. This means that PFES participation did not have a significant impact on annual household income during the pilot period if we consider the difference in annual income between participants and non-participants. However, after iterations for PS matching techniques and the DID method, the results show that participation in the PFES program during the pilot period has approximately a positive impact of VND 3.9 million on household annual income, and this impact is significant at the 5% level. It was not significant at the 10% level though.

Authors: Lybbert T, Aboudrare A, Chaloud D, Magnan N, Nash M
Title: Booming markets for Moroccan argan oil appear to benefit some rural households while threatening the endemic argan forest
Author_affil: Agricultural and Resource Economics, University of California, Davis, CA 95616
Stated_int: Moroccoês argan oil is now the most expensive edible oil in the world. High-value argan markets have sparked a bonanza of argan activity.
Desired_out: Nongovernmental organizations, international and domestic development agencies, and argan oil cooperatives aggressively promote the win_win aim of simultaneously benefiting local people and the health of the argan forest.
Int_dur: Since 1999, rapidly appreciating prices in high-value markets have sparked a bonanza of argan activity.
Study_goal: Win_win claims of poverty alleviation and biodiversity conservation now appear on virtually every argan product label and have been showcased by media outlets worldwide. Using a combination of household- and landscape-level analyses, we evaluate these now common argan claims.
Study_location: Essaouira Province
Study_duration: Survey conducted in 1999 and again in 2007
Stated_outcomes: Three types of household welfare outcomes: consumption (spending at market), assets (livestock holdings), and childrenês education
Indicators: consumption (spending at market), assets (livestock holdings)
Outcome.direction_notes: we find that households with access to more fruit enjoyed a slightly higher increase in household consumption relative to other households. Second, benefiting households accumulated more assets in the form of goats (but not other livestock)
Stated_mech: Forest products often function as an important safety net by helping vulnerable households cope with hard times and thereby, may prevent households from slipping farther into poverty, but it may be difficult for such households to leverage forest products as a means of accumulating the assets needed to shift to higher-return pursuits. Furthermore, even the safety net benefit can be compromised if commercialization depletes forest resources, leaving vulnerable households more susceptible to adverse shocks that can drive them deeper into poverty.

Authors: Lybbert T, Aboudrare A, Chaloud D, Magnan N, Nash M
Title: Booming markets for Moroccan argan oil appear to benefit some rural households while threatening the endemic argan forest
Author_affil: Agricultural and Resource Economics, University of California, Davis, CA 95616
Stated_int: Moroccoês argan oil is now the most expensive edible oil in the world. High-value argan markets have sparked a bonanza of argan activity.
Desired_out: Nongovernmental organizations, international and domestic development agencies, and argan oil cooperatives aggressively promote the win_win aim of simultaneously benefiting local people and the health of the argan forest.
Int_dur: Since 1999, rapidly appreciating prices in high-value markets have sparked a bonanza of argan activity.
Study_goal: Win_win claims of poverty alleviation and biodiversity conservation now appear on virtually every argan product label and have been showcased by media outlets worldwide. Using a combination of household- and landscape-level analyses, we evaluate these now common argan claims.
Study_location: Essaouira Province
Study_duration: Survey conducted in 1999 and again in 2007
Stated_outcomes: Three types of household welfare outcomes: consumption (spending at market), assets (livestock holdings), and childrenês education
Indicators: Education attainment of children in household
Outcome.direction_notes: girls from households that stood to benefit from booming argan prices were significantly more likely to make the transition from primary to secondary school than girls from other households, but no such result is apparent for boys
Stated_mech: Forest products often function as an important safety net by helping vulnerable households cope with hard times and thereby, may prevent households from slipping farther into poverty, but it may be difficult for such households to leverage forest products as a means of accumulating the assets needed to shift to higher-return pursuits. Furthermore, even the safety net benefit can be compromised if commercialization depletes forest resources, leaving vulnerable households more susceptible to adverse shocks that can drive them deeper into poverty.

Authors: Mahapatra AK, Shackleton CM
Title: Exploring the relationships between trade in natural products, cash income and livelihoods in tropical forest regions of Eastern India
Author_affil: Regional Plant Resources Centre, Forest and Environment Department, Bhubaneswar 751015, Orissa, India
Stated_int: Trade in NTFPs
Desired_out: Declining trend in timber production, rising trade in NTFPs
Study_goal: "we sought to contribute to the environment-poverty discourse by addressing the following key questions in this paper, (a) Do householdersê socio-economic features influence NTFP trade and income? (b) what is the magnitude and significance of NTFP trade income to household cash income? and (c) how does this affect local poverty profiles within the tropical dry forest of eastern India?"
Study_location: 24 villages in four districts of Orissa (17ç 31  E to 22ç 29  N) and Jharkhand (23ç 45  N to 85ç 30  E)
Stated_outcomes: Cash income sources by wealth class quartiles
Indicators: Off-farm income, forest income, agricultural income, non-farm income
Outcome.direction_notes: Differs by wealth class

Authors: Maharjan MR, Dhakal TR, Thapa SK, Schreckenberg K, Luttrell C
Title: Improving the bene ts to the poor from community forestry in the Churia region of Nepal
Author_affil: CARE Nepal, Krishna Galli, Patan, P.O. Box 1661, Kathmandu, Nepal
Funding: Output from an action research project conducted by CARE Nepal with support of CARE International, CARE Austria, CARE Denmark, the Overseas Development Institute (ODI) and Ford Foundation.
Stated_int: Community forestry, community forest user groups
Desired_out: "Introduce programmes specially designed to increase the wellbeing of the poor, vulnerable and socially excluded people living in these areas"
Study_goal: "The Nepal research was conducted in 2006-7 by CARE Nepal to understand and improve the livelihood impacts of community forestry in the Churia, Bhawar and Terai regions. The research was designed to answer several basic questions: 1. Can community forestry contribute to poverty reduction or livelihood improvement by providing rural people with a sustainable stream of net benefits greater than those obtained under a non-community forestry situation? 2. How significant are the benefits of community forestry for different wellbeing groups? What are the key negative impacts of community forestry and on whom do they fall? 3. What characteristics of community forestry determine its impacts (both positive and negative) on poverty and equity?"
Study_location: Central region (Sarlahi district - Ramjanaki, Pasupati; Mahotari district- Musahar, Ratu Mahila, Phuljour), Mid-western region (Bardia district - Sati, Srijana Mahila; Banke district - Srijana, Jharana, Gabar)
Stated_outcomes: Financial capital, physical capital, human capital, natural capital, social capital, political capital
Indicators: Chnage in per capita income, change in % income from forests, % annual per capital income derived from community forestry
Outcome.direction_notes: Differs between well-being groups

Authors: Martini E, Roshetko JM, van Noordwijk M, Rahmanulloh A, Mulyoutami E, Joshi L, Budidarsono S
Title: Sugar palm (Arenga pinnata (Wurmb) Merr.) for livelihoods and biodiversity conservation in the orangutan habitat of Batang Toru, North Sumatra, Indonesia: mixed prospects for domestication
Author_affil: World Agroforestry Centre (ICRAF), Jl. CIFOR Situ Gede, Sindang Barang, Bogor, West Java, Indonesia
Funding: Trees in Multi-use Landscapes in Southeast Asia (TULSEA) project funded by the Federal Ministry of Economic Cooperation and Development (BMZ) and Deutsche Gesellschaft fur Technische Zusammenarbeit (GTZ). Initial work was conducted through the Development of Sustainable Economic Alternatives component of the USAID-funded Development of Collaborative Orangutan Habitat Protection in Batang Toru Watershed, North Sumatra, project.
Stated_int: Aren (Arenga pinnata, sugar palm) domestication and agroforestry
Desired_out: Collection of wild aren seedlings for cultivation and planting as form of income generation
Study_goal: "this study was conducted to document the current practices in aren utilization and domestication in the Batang Toru area, to investigate farmersê motivations in aren domestication, and to assess contribution of aren utilization and domestication for livelihoods and biodiversity conservation"
Study_location: Lumban Lobu, Pagaran Tulason (Arse subdistrict), Paran Julu (Sipirok subdistrict, South Tapanuli), Hutagurgur village (Sibabangun subdistrict, Central Tapanuli) - Batang Toru forest, North Sumatra
Stated_outcomes: Contribution to gross income, return to labour
Portion_livelihood_amount: Varies by tree/plant type - see figure 3
Indicators: net present value, return to labour per hectare between aren production plots and wild plots

Authors: Maskey V, Gebremedhin TG, Dalton TJ
Title: Social and cultural determinants of collective management of community forest in Nepal
Author_affil: West Virginia University, USA
Stated_int: Community forestry, community forest user groups (CFUGs), Ludhi-Damgade community forest user group, participation
Desired_out: "Community forestry approaches often devolve decision-making rights and the benefits of participation to rural populations, along with the responsibilities for forest management." "Transferring control of the forest benefits to local user groups mobilizes local labor into forest management, which secures the benefit from forest products to the user groups"
Study_goal: "This study will determine whether there are socio- cultural factors that affect participation in community forest management and whether these factors affect the distribution of benefits derived from the forest."
Study_location: Ludhi-Damgade forest, Gorkha district
Stated_outcomes: Forest benefits (fodder quantity, fuelwood quantity, timber quantity), level of participation
Indicators: Participation in decision-making
Outcome.direction_notes: Women more than men, higher caste more than lower caste, wealthy (more landholding) more than poor

Authors: Maskey V, Gebremedhin TG, Dalton TJ

"Transferring control of the forest benefits to local user groups mobilizes local labor into forest management, which secures the benefit from forest products to the user groups"
Study_goal: "This study will determine whether there are socio- cultural factors that affect participation in community forest management and whether these factors affect the distribution of benefits derived from the forest."
Study_location: Ludhi-Damgade forest, Gorkha district
Stated_outcomes: Forest benefits (fodder quantity, fuelwood quantity, timber quantity), level of participation
Indicators: Timber consumption

Authors: Matiku P, Caleb M, Callistus O
Title: The Impact of Participatory Forest Management on Local Community Livelihoods in the Arabuko_Sokoke Forest, Kenya
Author_affil: Nature Kenya, Nairobi, Kenya
Funding: Royal Society for the Protection of Birds (RSPB)
Stated_int: Participatory forest management, community forestry, butterfly farming, Arabuko-Sokeke community forest
Desired_out: "The main objective of the butterfly farming project was to reduce pre-colonial and post-colonial negativity among the local people by providing incentives for local communities to support forest conservation objectives"
Study_goal: "This study assesses the impact of participatory forest management on the household livelihoods of residents near the Arabuko-Sokoke forest and answers the following questions: 1) does forest conservation result in net benefits to local communities living adjacent to the forest?; 2) does participatory forest management (PFM) enhance net incomes to forest-adjacent households in the Arabuko-Sokoke forest?; and 3) are household benefits uniformly distributed within the 5 km intervention zone? The hypotheses tested by the study are: 1) forest conservation benefits exceed forest conservation costs; 2) PFM areas have higher benefits compared to areas without PFM; and 3) benefits and costs reduce with distance from forest edge."
Study_location: Arabuko-Sokoke forest
Stated_outcomes: Conservation costs (livestock predation, livestock loss, crop damage), forest benefits (firewood extraction, herbal medicine, building materials, NTFPs, employment)
Indicators: Net household benefits or costs compared between PFM and non-PFM sites, and over distance
Outcome.direction_notes: Generally, non-PFM had net costs

Authors: McDougall C, Jiggins J, Pandit BH, Rana SKTM, Leeuwis C
Title: Does Adaptive Collaborative Forest Governance Affect Poverty? Participatory Action Research in Nepalês Community Forests
Author_affil: Department of Communication and Innovation Studies, Wageningen University, Wageningen, The Netherlands
Funding: the Asian Development Bank and Canadaês International Development Research Centre (IDRC), and the complementary funders, Center for International Forestry Research, the Consultative Group on International Agricultural Researchês System wide Programme on Participatory Research and Gender Analysis, the International Institute for Rural Reconstruction, and Local Initiatives for Biodiversity, Research and Development, Nepal
Stated_int: Community forestry
Desired_out: "Nepalês Community Forestry Program has been widely implemented since its inception in the late 1980s. It was established out of concern regarding deforestation and environmental degradation." "...two of the programês key second-generation challenges are to increase the level of livelihood benefits and their distributional equity"
Study_goal: "To what extent do CFUGs prioritize and meet the needs of women and the poor? What is the influence of adaptive collaborative governance of community forests on the generation and distribution of subsistence and income-related benefits, especially for women and the poor? How do the various elements of an adaptive collaborative approach have such an influence? And, in broader terms, what insights does the research suggest in terms of the conceptualization of poverty alleviation, including the significance of internal power relations?"
Study_location: Kaski district (Bamdibhir, Deurali Bagedanda), Sankhuwasabha district (Andheribhajana, Manakamana, Pathivara), Palpa district (Kajipauwa), Nawalparasi (Chautari), Lalitpur district (Patle), Dhankuta district (Handikharka, Khanuyubas Salleri), Morang district (Chautari)
Stated_outcomes: Changes in CFUG rules affecting distributional equity, changes income generation activities and loans, employment
Indicators: Access to and sale of community forest products

Authors: Meshack CK, Adhikari B, Doggart N, Lovett JC
Title: Transaction costs of community-based forest management: empirical evidence from Tanzania
Author_affil: Tanzania Forest Conservation Group, PO Box 23410, Dar es Salaam, Tanzania
Funding: CARE _ Norway through the Misitu Yetu Project, a partnership project between Tanzania Forest Conservation Group (TFCG), CARE _ Tanzania and Wildlife Conservation of Tanzania (WCST)
Stated_int: Community-based forest management
Desired_out: "Through joint forest management with communities, the district government and the Ambangulu Tea Estate, the Tanzania Forest Conservation Group (TFCG) is leading the process to protect this important site... The key management activities carried out include monitoring through patrolling, provision of extension services, alternative sources of forest resources and facilitation of forest management plans and by-law development."
Study_goal: "To explore this issue further, a study was carried out to assess transaction costs and to obtain estimates of net benefits of CBFM in four communities adjacent to a single area of forest. The study had three objectives. First, to identify costs and benefits of community forest management to the rich, middle and poor groups of users. Second, to quantify costs and benefits for these subgroups based on prevailing economic conditions. Third, to assess the comparative flow of benefits and costs for each income group. The overall aim of the study was to contribute to the understanding of transaction costs in CBFM and make suggestions for more equitable community forest management practices in Tanzania."
Study_location: Ambangulu forest, West Usambara mountains (5ç09'S, 38ç45'E)
Stated_outcomes: Transaction costs incurred from PFM, forest benefits from CBFM, food security, perception of impact of PFM
Indicators: Net costs/benefits from PFM - transaction cost days related to forest management (attendance, monitoring), benefits (fuelwood, NTFP income and consumption)
Outcome.direction_notes: Rich tend to have higher net benefit than middle, which is higher than poor income groups

Title: Transaction costs of community-based forest management: empirical evidence from Tanzania
Author_affil: Tanzania Forest Conservation Group, PO Box 23410, Dar es Salaam, Tanzania
Funding: CARE _ Norway through the Misitu Yetu Project, a partnership project between Tanzania Forest Conservation Group (TFCG), CARE _ Tanzania and Wildlife Conservation of Tanzania (WCST)
Stated_int: Community-based forest management
Desired_out: "Through joint forest management with communities, the district government and the Ambangulu Tea Estate, the Tanzania Forest Conservation Group (TFCG) is leading the process to protect this important site... The key management activities carried out include monitoring through patrolling, provision of extension services, alternative sources of forest resources and facilitation of forest management plans and by-law development."
Study_goal: "To explore this issue further, a study was carried out to assess transaction costs and to obtain estimates of net benefits of CBFM in four communities adjacent to a single area of forest. The study had three objectives. First, to identify costs and benefits of community forest management to the rich, middle and poor groups of users. Second, to quantify costs and benefits for these subgroups based on prevailing economic conditions. Third, to assess the comparative flow of benefits and costs for each income group. The overall aim of the study was to contribute to the understanding of transaction costs in CBFM and make suggestions for more equitable community forest management practices in Tanzania."
Study_location: Ambangulu forest, West Usambara mountains (5ç09'S, 38ç45'E)
Stated_outcomes: Transaction costs incurred from PFM, forest benefits from CBFM, food security, perception of impact of PFM
Indicators: Net costs/benefits from PFM - transaction cost days related to forest management (attendance, monitoring), benefits (fuelwood, NTFP income and consumption)
Outcome.direction_notes: Rich tend to have higher net benefit than middle, which is higher than poor income groups

Authors: Miah MD, Ahmed FU
Title: Conservation of a Tropical Wet Semi-evergreen Forest Ecosystem by an Indigenous Community in the Bandarban Hill District of Bangladesh: The Role of Intervention
Author_affil: Institute of Forestry and Environmental Sciences, University of Chittagong, Chittagong 4331, Bangladesh
Funding: Arannayk Foundation, Dhaka; the Humanitarian Foundation, Bandarban
Stated_int: •Indigenous community based sustainable management of Chimbuk Hill forest in Bandarban hill districtê, Village Community Forests,
Desired_out: "The project entitled •Indigenous community based sustainable management of Chimbuk Hill forest in Bandarban hill districtê has promoted organizational strengthening of the communities living in and around the VCF, improving the technical skill of VCF management and providing alternative livelihood support to reduce their dependence on forests."
Study_goal: "The present study examines the outcomes of the intervention on capacity building of the indigenous community to restore the forest resources"
Study_location: Kapropara, Korangpara village - Chittagong Hill Tracts
Stated_outcomes: Training received, ability to draw loans, average income per household before and after project from forest vs. jhum agriculture, restoration of forest resources
Indicators: Percent of income from VCF vs. jhum
