Authors: Mohammed AJ, Inoue M
Title: Drawbacks of decentralized natural resource management: experience from Chilimo Participatory Forest Management project, Ethiopia
Author_affil: Graduate School of Agricultural and Life Sciences, The University of Tokyo, 1-1-1 Yayoi, Bunkyo, Tokyo 113-8657, Japan
Stated_int: The Chilimo Participatory Forest Management (PFM) project, community-based natural resource management (CBNRM)
Desired_out: "mitigate natural resource degradation and its effects on the livelihood of people"
Study_goal: "this paper aims to investigate the negative aspects of decentralization, based on its impact on the forests and the livelihood of the rural poor in Chilimo Forest Area, Ethiopia."
Study_location: Chilimo forest, Dendi District, West Showa Zone, Oromoia Regional State
Forest_type: Other non-forest environment with planted trees, trees on farms, or tree farms
Stated_outcomes: Satisfaction on benefit-sharing between classes
Indicators: Perception of income from plantation and fuelwood

Authors: Mohammed AJ, Inoue M
Title: Forest-dependent communitiesê livelihood in decentralized forest governance policy epoch: case study from West Shoa zone, Ethiopia
Journal: Journal of Natural Resources Policy Research
Author_affil: Graduate School of Agricultural and Life Sciences, The University of Tokyo 1-1-1 Yayoi, Bunkyo, Tokyo 113-8657, Japan
Funding: Grants-in-Aid for Scientific Research (A) from the Government of Japan (No. 19208014, project leader: Makoto Inoue)
Stated_int: Decentralized forest governance, devolution form of decentralization, delegation form of decentralization, peasant associations
Desired_out: "Devolution and delegation are among the major forms of decentralization that are currently being undertaken in the forestry sector of the country. Under delegation, all forest governance decision-making power, that is, that for forest management, protection, and utilization, is delegated to the Forest and Wildlife Enterprise. On the other hand, under devolution, the decision-making power to manage and protect the forest is devolved to forest user groups (which later became cooperatives)."
Study_goal: "By examining communities in or near forests that are managed by the delegation and the devolution forms of decentralization, this paper aims to fill the aforementioned research gap with the following two objectives: to identify important types of capital for local peoplesê livelihood as a coping mechanism from vulnerabilities and as a source of income and to investigate the impact of delegation and devolution forms of forest governance on the capital."
Study_location: Jibat forest (Tutu peasant's association), Chilimo forest (Gare Arera peasant association)
Study_duration: September and October 2011 and January and February 2012
Stated_outcomes: Change in forest-based capital, non-forest based capital, and human capital
Indicators: Plantation sale dividends
Outcome.direction_notes: Increased after decentralization

Authors: Motiur RM, Furukawa Y, Kawata I, Rahman MM, Alam M
Title: Role of homestead forests in household economy and factors affecting forest production: a case study in southwest Bangladesh
Author_affil: United Graduate School of Agricultural Sciences, Ehime University, Matsuyama, Japan; Forest Management Laboratory, Faculty of Agriculture, Kochi University, B 200 Monobe, Nankoku 783-8502, Japan
Stated_int: Homestead forestry
Desired_out: " Homestead forests are a major source of forest products that play an important role in the economic life of the country by supplying the bulk of wood and other forest products in the market "
Study_goal: "The objectives of this study were to assess the role of homestead forests in the household economy, examine if forest production varies across different landholding size classes, explore the relationships of species richness, education level, and household size as causal factors for homestead forest production, explore the relationship between forest income and family occupation, and investigate attitudes of homestead forest owners toward key forest management issues"
Study_location: Ran Bijoypur, Sundarghona, and Bagmara covering two unions, Shatgumbuj and Bagmara of Bagerhat sadar upazila (subdistrict), located between 22ç35_ and 22ç50_ N and between 89ç38_ and 89ç53_ E
Forest_type: Other non-forest environment with planted trees, trees on farms, or tree farms
Stated_outcomes: Homestead forest income, self-use of homestead forest products, employment
Indicators: Income from sale of forest goods
Outcome.direction_notes: Yes, depending on landholder type

Authors: MUHAMMED N, HAQUE F, KOIKE M
Title: THE ROLE OF PARTICIPATORY SOCIAL FORESTRY IN THE ENHANCEMENT OF THE SOCIO-ECONOMIC CONDITION OF THE RURAL POOR: A CASE STUDY OF DHAKA FOREST DIVISION IN BANGLADESH
Author_affil: Forest Policy Laboratory, Department of Forest Science, Faculty of Agriculture, Shinshu University, 8304 Minamiminowa - mura, 399 - 4598 Nagano - ken, Japan.
Funding: The authors also acknowledge JSPS authority of Japan for sponsoring the research fund.
Stated_int: Social forestry program in Bangladesh
Desired_out: Social forestry is an umbrella term broadly associated with practicing forestry activities involving local people and other relevant stakeholders as active partner under a legal frame work of benefit sharing in order to improve the forests, micro -environment and socio-economic condition of the local poor. In this type of participatory forestry programme, the local people as programme beneficiaries provide their off-farm family labour. All other management inputs and technical supports are provided by the government. Here the main objectives are to integrate the people in this programme to ensure better plantation protection and to help them to find an alternative source of income to eradicate their poverty. At the same time, the local people who used to be treated as encroacher of forests and forest resources, are motivated to stop their destruction of the forest. As a result of their off farm family labour they are active beneficiaries of the programme. Generally three types of short rotation plantation are being raised under the social forestry programme viz. woodlot plantations, agroforestry plantings, and strip plantations. The Forestry Department aimed to raise the benefits from woodlots and strip planting above those of the agroforestry plots.
Int_dur: Participatory social forestry was introduced in Bangladesh in early 1980s
Study_goal: This explorative research, based on case study analysis, was conducted to assess the role of participatory social forestry on enhancement of socio-economic condition of the grass root level people in Bangladesh.
Study_location: Dhaka Forest Division, which lies to three civil districts viz. Dhaka, Gazipur, and Narayanganj.
Sample_size: 15 respondents from woodlot plantations (about 6% of the beneficiaries of this category), 15 respondents from agroforestry plantings (about 4 7% of the beneficiaries of this category) and 18 respondents from strip plantations (about 39% of the beneficiaries of this category) were selected at random and interviewed.
Study_duration: A randomly selected subset of beneficiaries who raised woodlots, agroforestry plantations and strip plantations in 1992 and felled them in 2004 were included in the analysis.
Stated_outcomes: Financial gains (income) of program participants
Indicators: Average annual return from forestry activity for participants
Outcome.direction_notes: The average annual return varies however by the type of plantation.

Authors: Mukul SA, Manzoor Rashid AZM, Quazi SA,Uddin MB, Fox J
Title: Local peoples' responses to co-management regime in protected areas: A case study from Satchari National Park, Bangladesh
Author_affil: School of Agriculture and Food Sciences, Faculty of Science, The University of Queensland, Brisbane, QLD 4072, Australia
Funding: USAID under a joint fellowship programme of East-West Center and Nishorgo Support Project
Stated_int: Nishorgo Support Project, Integrated Protected Area Co-management” (IPAC)
Desired_out: Co-management of joint management of forest resources around and in protected areas
Study_goal: "As an initial step for assessing the progress of this new approach to conservation in Bangladesh, we collected both qualitative and quantitative data to explore the changing trends in forest uses, local livelihoods, and finally peopleês attitudes toward comanagement over a one-year period at one of the northeastern pilot sites. Our objective was to demonstrate the strength and weakness of this approach and provide –lessons learned” for use by others."
Study_location: Villages around Satchari National Park, Chunarughat Upazila, Habiganj District
Stated_outcomes: Shift in income source, shift in forest dependency
Indicators: Contribution of forest products to household income
Outcome.direction_notes: Differs based on income group and by year

Authors: Mullan K, Kontoleon A, Swanson T, Zhang S
Title: Evaluation of the Impact of the Natural Forest Protection Program on Rural Household Livelihoods
Author_affil: Department of Land Economy, University of Cambridge, 19 Silver Street, CB3 9EP Cambridge, UK
Funding: We acknowledge financial support from the China Council for International Cooperation on Environment and Development as well as assistance from the School of Environmental Sciences of Beijing University in implementing the survey used in this article.
Stated_int: Natural Forest Protection Program (NFPP) in China, the largest logging-ban program in the world
Desired_out: To protect watersheds and conserve natural forests
Int_dur: The NFPP was piloted in 1998, then expanded during the next 2 years across 17 provinces and autonomous regions in the upper reaches of the Yangtze River and the upper and middle reaches of the Yellow River.
Study_goal: In this study, we focused on evaluating the impacts of the NFPP on two important facets of livelihoods in the affected areas: household income and employment opportunities.
Study_location: Qiandongnan region of Guizhou Province
Study_duration: Data are from 2005, looks at variables in 1997 and 2004 (before/after)
Stated_outcomes: Impacts of the NFPP on Incomes; Impacts of the NFPP on Off-Farm Employment
Portion_livelihood_amount: See Table 4 of report.
Indicators: Household income
Outcome.direction_notes: We found that the NFPP has had a negative impact on incomes from timber harvesting. It has also had a positive impact on total household incomes from all sources.

Authors: Mullan K, Kontoleon A, Swanson T, Zhang S
Title: Evaluation of the Impact of the Natural Forest Protection Program on Rural Household Livelihoods
Author_affil: Department of Land Economy, University of Cambridge, 19 Silver Street, CB3 9EP Cambridge, UK
Funding: We acknowledge financial support from the China Council for International Cooperation on Environment and Development as well as assistance from the School of Environmental Sciences of Beijing University in implementing the survey used in this article.
Stated_int: Natural Forest Protection Program (NFPP) in China, the largest logging-ban program in the world
Desired_out: To protect watersheds and conserve natural forests
Int_dur: The NFPP was piloted in 1998, then expanded during the next 2 years across 17 provinces and autonomous regions in the upper reaches of the Yangtze River and the upper and middle reaches of the Yellow River.
Study_goal: In this study, we focused on evaluating the impacts of the NFPP on two important facets of livelihoods in the affected areas: household income and employment opportunities.
Study_location: Qiandongnan region of Guizhou Province
Study_duration: Data are from 2005, looks at variables in 1997 and 2004 (before/after)
Stated_outcomes: Impacts of the NFPP on Incomes; Impacts of the NFPP on Off-Farm Employment
Indicators: Impact of program on income from off-farm employment
Outcome.direction_notes: We found that although overall employment rates have not been affected by the program, employment outside the village has increased more rapidly in NFPP than in non-NFPP areas. We noted that increased total household income might not correspond to increased household welfare because if that were the case, non-NFPP households would be expected to in the off-farm labor market to a greater extent as well.

Authors: Nath TK, Inoue M
Title: The upland settlement project of Bangladesh as a means of reducing land degradation and improving rural livelihoods
Author_affil: Institute of Forestry and Environmental Sciences, The University of Chittagong, Chittagong, Bangladesh
Funding: 21st Century Centre of Excellence (COE) program of the University of Tokyo, headed by Professor Washitani Izumi
Stated_int: Social forestry, upland resettlement project (USP)
Desired_out: Participatory forest management in the form of a social forestry project in degraded forest areas to support the livelihood of forest-dependent people and increase forest areas.
Study_goal: "This paper reports an empirical study of the Upland Settlement Project (USP) of Bangladesh which was undertaken to prevent land degradation and enhance the standard of living of the people." "Impacts of the project on reduction of land degradation and on plantersê livelihoods are then examined"
Study_location: Chemi-1 project village in Bandarban district
Stated_outcomes: Human capital, natural capital, physical capital, social capital, financial capital
Indicators: Literacy, attendance in school, forestry skills learned

Authors: Nath TK, Inoue M,
Title: Forest-based settlement project and its impacts on community livelihood in the chittagong hill tracts, Bangladesh
Author_affil: Institute of Forestry and Environmental Sciences, University of Chittagong , Chittagong; Department of Global Agricultural Sciences, Graduate School of Agricultural and Life Sciences, The University of Tokyo
Stated_int: Upland Settlement Project (participatory forestry)
Desired_out: A participatory forestry (PF) project known as the Upland Settlement Project (USP) initiated in the the early 1980s in degraded forest areas of the Chittangong Hill Tracts. The USP has rehabilitated landless jhumias, through a number of agroforestry and social development functions including capacity-building and infrastructure development.
Study_goal: "The present study was a comprehensive livelihood analyses based on a sustainable livelihood (SL) framework and examined five types of livelihood capitals - namely human, physical, natural, financial, and social capital - of the participants, as well as the factors that underlay success or failure of the settlement project in achieving targeted project's objectives and livelihood diversification strategies."
Study_location: Bandarban District, Chittagong Hill Tracts
Stated_outcomes: Human capital, physical capital, natural capital, financial capital, groups and networks, trust and solidarity
Indicators: Level of education received, training in techniques
Outcome.direction_notes: Successful villages said they did receive or saw improvements

Title: Forest-based settlement project and its impacts on community livelihood in the chittagong hill tracts, Bangladesh
Author_affil: Institute of Forestry and Environmental Sciences, University of Chittagong , Chittagong; Department of Global Agricultural Sciences, Graduate School of Agricultural and Life Sciences, The University of Tokyo
Stated_int: Upland Settlement Project (participatory forestry)
Desired_out: A participatory forestry (PF) project known as the Upland Settlement Project (USP) initiated in the the early 1980s in degraded forest areas of the Chittangong Hill Tracts. The USP has rehabilitated landless jhumias, through a number of agroforestry and social development functions including capacity-building and infrastructure development.
Study_goal: "The present study was a comprehensive livelihood analyses based on a sustainable livelihood (SL) framework and examined five types of livelihood capitals - namely human, physical, natural, financial, and social capital - of the participants, as well as the factors that underlay success or failure of the settlement project in achieving targeted project's objectives and livelihood diversification strategies."
Study_location: Bandarban District, Chittagong Hill Tracts
Stated_outcomes: Human capital, physical capital, natural capital, financial capital, groups and networks, trust and solidarity
Indicators: groups and networks, trust and solidarity

Authors: Naughton-Treves L, Alix-Garcia J, Chapman CA
Title: Lessons about parks and poverty from a decade of forest loss and economic growth around Kibale National Park, Uganda
Journal: Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences
Author_affil: Department of Geography, University of Wisconsin, Madison, WI 53706;
Funding: Grant 98-10144 from the Geography and Regional Science Division of the National Science Foundation, grants from Princeton University and the University of Wisconsin at Madison, Conservation International, Fulbright, the Canada Research Chairs Program, the Natural Sciences and Engineering Research Council of Canada, and US Agency for International Development Translinks Agreement EPP-A-00-06-00014-00
Stated_int: Kibale National Park
Desired_out: "After Kibale became a park in 1993..." focusing on biodiversity conservation. ...."timber extraction, hunting, charcoal production, and agriculture were curtailed, although local people have continued to draw nontimber forest products (NTFPs) from the park"
Study_goal: "This paper examines the relationship between forest use, biodiversity loss, and poverty. In particular, it considers whether park restrictions on forest use induce a poverty trap..." "We test whether proximity to a forest park is a key geographic characteristic promoting the emergence or continuation of a poverty trap. In addition, we compare local citizensê use of forest in KNP vs. adjacent communal forest patches where commercial extraction is allowed. We also compare forest use by the poorest households with that of their more affluent counterparts."
Study_location: 8 villages around Kibale National Park
Stated_outcomes: Forest use and cover change, household welfare change over time, wealth outcomes over groups, time, and distance
Indicators: Obtain drinking water, durable roofs, hire laborers
Outcome.direction_notes: Overtime, households were more likely to increase in welfare

Authors: Naughton-Treves L, Alix-Garcia J, Chapman CA
Title: Lessons about parks and poverty from a decade of forest loss and economic growth around Kibale National Park, Uganda
Journal: Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences
Author_affil: Department of Geography, University of Wisconsin, Madison, WI 53706;
Funding: Grant 98-10144 from the Geography and Regional Science Division of the National Science Foundation, grants from Princeton University and the University of Wisconsin at Madison, Conservation International, Fulbright, the Canada Research Chairs Program, the Natural Sciences and Engineering Research Council of Canada, and US Agency for International Development Translinks Agreement EPP-A-00-06-00014-00
Stated_int: Kibale National Park
Desired_out: "After Kibale became a park in 1993..." focusing on biodiversity conservation. ...."timber extraction, hunting, charcoal production, and agriculture were curtailed, although local people have continued to draw nontimber forest products (NTFPs) from the park"
Study_goal: "This paper examines the relationship between forest use, biodiversity loss, and poverty. In particular, it considers whether park restrictions on forest use induce a poverty trap..." "We test whether proximity to a forest park is a key geographic characteristic promoting the emergence or continuation of a poverty trap. In addition, we compare local citizensê use of forest in KNP vs. adjacent communal forest patches where commercial extraction is allowed. We also compare forest use by the poorest households with that of their more affluent counterparts."
Study_location: 8 villages around Kibale National Park
Stated_outcomes: Forest use and cover change, household welfare change over time, wealth outcomes over groups, time, and distance
Indicators: livestock owned, owning eucalyptus woodlots (productive assets)
Outcome.direction_notes: Wealthy tended to accumulate wealth faster, but also had higher levels of land abandonment. However, deforestation was also closely associated with higher levels of land abandonment and poverty. Poor living closer to the park versus those farther away did not have as extreme impacts on poverty, suggesting park plays a safety net role.

Authors: Niesenbaum RA, Salazar ME, Diop AM
Title: Community forestry in, the Mayan Biosphere Reserve in Guatemala. Journal of Sustainable Forestry, 19(4): and 11-28.
Author_affil: Muhlenberg College, Allentown, PA 18104-5586 USA
Funding: USAID, the Moriah Fund, and The Rodale Institute
Stated_int: Bethel cooperative in buffer zone of Mayan Biosphere Reserve (a Man and Biosphere site). Managed under polycyclic felling system. Ecotourism, locally production, and NTFP collection and sales.
Desired_out: Establishment of reserve in 1990 to protect forest ecosystems and facilitate coexistence between communities and ecosystems (under Man and Biosphere). Bethel cooperative established in 1994 as part of effort to sustainably harvest timber from around reserve area for economic development and support conservation agenda. Bethel cooperative forest is managed under polycyclic felling system with other techniques designed to encourage regeneration. Locally mill timber and produce furniture, establish ecotourism, income from non-timber sources.
Study_goal: "In this paper, we provide an early assessment of a forestry program in the Bethel cooperative in Northern Guatemala that is located in the buffer zone of the Mayan Biosphere Reserve (MBR), a MAB site. Our objectives are to assess the initial impact of harvest on forest structure and natural regeneration, and to predict the potential for sustained timber production under current harvest practice. We also provide some data to indicate whether increased community regulated forestry resulted in increased income for the current population"
Stated_outcomes: Income from community forest management, income from NTFPs, Income from furniture making, ecotourism
Indicators: Non timber forest product sale

Authors: Ogar AM, Enete AA
Title: Performance of forest management committees in Cross River state, Nigeria
Author_affil: Department of Agricultural Economics, University of Nigeria, Nsukka, Nigeria
Stated_int: Forest management committee (FMC) or community forest initiative
Desired_out: Direct management of forest resources by local communities that own them. Special mandate to manage reserve areas with particular attention to timber exploitation
Study_goal: "The purpose of this paper, therefore, is to provide a basic assessment of the performance of these FMCs in the management of community forests in the study area. The paper, based on primary data collected in September 2008, will describe the forest management committee structure and composition; compare the intensity of forest management practices in communities with FMCs and those without FMCs; compare household income from forestry in communities with FMCs and those without FMCs, and determine the factors influencing the perception of the local people as regards the use of FMCs."
Study_location: Cross River State (4 38'-6 55' N, 7 50'-9 28' E) - Boki, Obudu and Akamkpa local government areas
Stated_outcomes: intensity of forest management practices, income from forest sources
Indicators: Income derived from timber and non-wood forest products
Outcome.direction_notes: Those in FMCs derived less income (in value) from forest sources. For those who did, most was from NWFPs, while in non FMCs, most was from timber

Authors: Osorio C
Title: The effects of markets on the use of forest for the livelihood of indigenous households in the Colombian Amazon
Author_affil: OMACHA Foundation; Centre for Biological and Cultural Conservation. Leticia, Amazonas, Colombia.
Funding: This work was carried out with the aid of a research grant from the Latin American and Caribbean Environmental Economics Program (LACEEP, www.laceep.org).
Stated_int: Expansion of markets/difference in geographical access to markets?
Desired_out: It is not clear
Int_dur: Paper discusses various changes over the past 20 years: Over the past 20 years, the region has faced several social and economical transformations. Traditional people have changed their livelihood strategies. Economic activities including rubber extraction, cattle ranching, and cocaine processing have had a major impact in the region (Hammond et al., 1995). Development programs and rural extension programs have introduced cash crops suitable for export and have encouraged people to increase agricultural production. In more recent years, the indigenous population has broadly increased its interaction with external markets, adopting alternative forms of production and resource management oriented towards the generation of cash income.
Study_goal: This paper presents results from research conducted in the Colombian Amazon. We report findings from two main issues: First, the use of forest for income generation among indigenous societies, and second, the associations between total household income and the use of forest products for livelihood purposes.
Study_location: The research was conducted in the Colombian Amazonian district (Figure 1). The region is located at the left-hand side of the map below, along the stretch of the Amazon River between Iquitos (Peru) and Tabatinga (Brazil). The territory includes 48 indigenous villages from different ethnic groups settled along 117 km on the bank of the Amazon river (3ç4 S, 69_3 W, 70_ 4 E).
Sample_size: 100 households from four villages in the district of Leticia and three villages in the zone of Puerto Nari_o, Colombia.
Stated_outcomes: Use of forest for cash and subsistence; Dependence on environmental incomes
Portion_livelihood_amount: Forest and agroforestry together provide 60% of total household income and 50% of cash earnings.
Indicators: The use of forest for cash generation; the use of forest for subsistence production (in-kind income)
Outcome.direction_notes: We observe that the amount of cash incomes obtained from environmental goods increases with the householdês total income. We observe that the value of extraction for household subsistence increases with the householdês total income. However the share of subsistence production on total income decreases when household income rises. Furthermore, we observe a broad differential in consumption between poorest and richest households.

Authors: Osorio C
Title: The effects of markets on the use of forest for the livelihood of indigenous households in the Colombian Amazon
Author_affil: OMACHA Foundation; Centre for Biological and Cultural Conservation. Leticia, Amazonas, Colombia.
Funding: This work was carried out with the aid of a research grant from the Latin American and Caribbean Environmental Economics Program (LACEEP, www.laceep.org).
Stated_int: Expansion of markets/difference in geographical access to markets?
Desired_out: It is not clear
Int_dur: Paper discusses various changes over the past 20 years: Over the past 20 years, the region has faced several social and economical transformations. Traditional people have changed their livelihood strategies. Economic activities including rubber extraction, cattle ranching, and cocaine processing have had a major impact in the region (Hammond et al., 1995). Development programs and rural extension programs have introduced cash crops suitable for export and have encouraged people to increase agricultural production. In more recent years, the indigenous population has broadly increased its interaction with external markets, adopting alternative forms of production and resource management oriented towards the generation of cash income.
Study_goal: This paper presents results from research conducted in the Colombian Amazon. Stated_outcomes: Use of forest for cash and subsistence; Dependence on environmental incomes
Indicators: dependency on environmental incomes
Outcome.direction_notes: Results point out that household dependency on environmental incomes decreases with the rise in a householdês total income, and as shown above, the total value extracted from forest land also increases along income levels.

Authors: Oyono P, Biyong M, Samba S
Title: Beyond the Decade of Policy and Community Euphoria: The State of Livelihoods Under New Local Rights to Forest in Rural Cameroon
Author_affil: Africa Program, Rights and Resources Initiative, Washington, DC
Funding: This research benefited from funding from the International Development Research Centre, and the Ford Foundation.
Linked_refs: This paper is derived from a strategic study conducted by the Center for International Forestry Research in Cameroon in 2007 and 2008 (see Larson and Dahal This issue)
Stated_int: Allocation of new community rights to local forests, forest resources, and benefits associated with their commercial exploitation in Cameroon
Desired_out: Preservation of the resource base/improved livelihoods
Int_dur: Since 1993/1994: The provisional Zoning Plan of the forested Cameroon, developed in 1993, and the Forestry Legislation of 1994 are the founding legal instruments for the reorganisation of the structure of the bundle of community rights to forests and resources.
Study_goal: This study seeks to assess the effects of the allocation of new community rights to local forests, forest resources, and benefits associated with their commercial exploitation. The Cameroon research upon which this paper is based was guided by the following hypotheses: 'securing community rights to forests ensures the security of the resource base'; 'the transfer of community tenure rights is synonymous with improved livelihoods'; 'securing and improving livelihoods increases monetary income and contributes to poverty reduction'; and 'securing community tenure rights leads to forest sustainability'.
Study_location: Four research sites located in the forested Cameroon were selected for this research, namely, Lomi_/Dja area (east region), Ocean area (south region), Mount Cameroon area (southwest region) and Mount Oku area (northwest region).
Study_duration: The assessment is conducted over a period of 10 years-i.e., from the end of the 1990s to the end of the 2000s
Stated_outcomes: Access to schools/health facilities before and after reforms. Community income before and after reforms.
Indicators: Access to schools/health facilities before/after reforms.

Authors: Persha L, Meshack C
Title: A triple win? The impact of Tanzaniaês Joint Forest Management programme on livelihoods, governance and forests
Author_affil: University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill, US Department of Geography and Curriculum for Ecology and the Environment
Funding: Funding for this impact evaluation was provided by 3ieês donors, which include UK aid, the Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation, Hewlett Foundation and 12 other 3ie members that provide institutional support. A complete listing is provided on the 3ie website at http://www.3ieimpact.org/en/about/3ie-affiliates/3ie-members/
Stated_int: Joint Forest Management
Desired_out: Core objectives are: (1) restoring forests, (2) improving livelihoods, and (3) strengthening local governance
Study_goal: The overarching goals of this impact evaluation of Tanzaniaês JFM are to: (1) determine JFMês average impacts on its stated goals of improved village governance, household livelihoods, and forest conditions; (2) understand if and how JFM impacts poorer villages and the poorest households within villages differently from other villages and households; and (3) draw on our study findings to generate policy-relevant recommendations for how JFM might be modified or better targeted to meet its goals more effectively.
Study_location: 7 regions of eastern Tanzania: Kilimanjaro, Tanga, Pwani, Lindi, Morogoro, Iringa, Mbeya
Sample_size: Our study uses a quasi-experimental research design across 110 decentralized and matched control sites in eastern Tanzania, collecting data from some 3,360 households, 110 villages and all adjacent forests, and implementing agency staff from 22 districts, to evaluate decentralization impacts across forest conservation, household livelihoods, and local governance outcomes.
Stated_outcomes: Overall household income, forest-derived income, asset-based measures of well-being
Indicators: Household income, forest-based income, number of forest products harvested
Outcome.direction_notes: There is no evidence that JFM results in a significant difference in overall household income, forest-derived income, or asset-based measures of wellbeing. JFM does result in a small but statistically significant increase in the number of forest products households harvest from forest reserves, which may benefit household subsistence needs.

Authors: Pinyopusarerk K, Tran TTH, Tran VD
Title: Making community forest management work in northern Vietnam by pioneering participatory action
Author_affil: CSIRO Plant Industry, GPO Box 1600, Canberra, ACT 2601, Australia
Funding: Australian Agency for International Development (AusAID) under a special program Collaboration for Agriculture and Rural Development (CARD) in Vietnam
Stated_int: Community forestry, Forest User Group (FUG) with Community Forest Management Boards
Desired_out: Using bottom-up participatory approach, form forest user groups with elected management boards to develop and implement forest management plans in compliance regulations from government. All four villages put a strong emphasis on (i) forest protection by strict control on harvest of timber and non-timber forest products, (ii) development of degraded forest caused by shifting cultivation by enrichment planting and plantation establishment, (iii) establishment of a community development fund (CDF), and (iv) benefit sharing.
Study_goal: "This paper describes the processes by which, for the first time in Vietnam, forest villagers secured joint ownership of community forest land for exclusive-use rights, and developed plans for its sustainable management and benefit sharing."
Study_location: Na Muc, Khuoi Lieng (Van Minh commune); To Dooc, Ban Sang (Lang San commune) - Na Ri district, Bac Kan province
Stated_outcomes: Perceptions on change in income, equity and benefit sharing, water supply quality
Indicators: perceptions/reports of change in household income
Outcome.direction_notes: Perceived to have dropped in 2010 (first collection point) due to drop in illegal timber harvest and shifting cultivation, then perceived to rise in 2012 due to agricultural production through loans from community development funds

Authors: Rahut D, Ali A, Behera B
Title: Household participation and effects of community forest management on income and poverty levels: Empirical evidence from Bhutan
Author_affil: Socioeconomics Program, International Maize and Wheat Improvement Center (CIMMYT), 10 Km. 45, Carretera Mex-Veracruz, El Batan, Mexico
Stated_int: Community-based forest management
Desired_out: Sustainable resource management, improved livelihoods
Int_dur: Initially, the CF was started cautiously with the establishment of the first CFs in Eastern Bhutan in the late 1990s
Study_goal: The objectives of the present study are to (1) identify and analyze the factors influencing household participation in community forest management programs, and (2) assess the effects of community participation in forest management on household income and poverty levels in Bhutan.
Study_location: Across the whole country
Sample_size: This paper uses data collected by the National Statistical Bureau under the Bhutan Living Standard Survey 2012. The study is based on a comprehensive dataset of 4173 rural households from all the agro-ecological regions of Bhutan.
Stated_outcomes: Determinants of household participation in community forest management; Impact of community forest management on income, household food security and poverty levels
Indicators: Determinants of participation in community forestry
Outcome.direction_notes: See Table 2 for results: The land holding coefficient is positive and significant at the 5% level of significance signifying that the higher the land holding the higher the likelihood of households participating in a community forestry program, meaning that richer households are more likely to participate in a community forest program than their poorer counterparts. Higher participation of males as compared to females.

Authors: Rahut D, Ali A, Behera B
Title: Household participation and effects of community forest management on income and poverty levels: Empirical evidence from Bhutan
Author_affil: Socioeconomics Program, International Maize and Wheat Improvement Center (CIMMYT), 10 Km. 45, Carretera Mex-Veracruz, El Batan, Mexico
Stated_int: Community-based forest management
Desired_out: Sustainable resource management, improved livelihoods
Int_dur: Initially, the CF was started cautiously with the establishment of the first CFs in Eastern Bhutan in the late 1990s
Study_goal: The objectives of the present study are to (1) identify and analyze the factors influencing household participation in community forest management programs, and (2) assess the effects of community participation in forest management on household income and poverty levels in Bhutan.
Study_location: Across the whole country
Sample_size: This paper uses data collected by the National Statistical Bureau under the Bhutan Living Standard Survey 2012. The study is based on a comprehensive dataset of 4173 rural households from all the agro-ecological regions of Bhutan.
Stated_outcomes: Determinants of household participation in community forest management; Impact of community forest management on income, household food security and poverty levels
Indicators: The outcomevariables are 1) food security; 2) the household income in Bhutanese Ngultrum; 3) food poverty.
Outcome.direction_notes: The average treatment affect for the treated (ATT) are Ngultrum 2605_3169 higher for the participating households as compared to non-participating households.  The results for food poverty indicate that households participating in the community forest program have lower poverty levels in the range of 5_12 percentage points than those who do not participate. From the empirical results, it can be concluded that community participation in forest management can help to increase the household income and can also help to reduce poverty in the range of 5_12 percentage points. The food security levels were high in the range of 12%_19% because, the communities were deriving a number of benefits such as fruit, vegetables and nuts, etc., from the program.

Authors: Rasul G, Choudhary D, Pandit BH, Kollmair M
Title: Poverty and livelihood impacts of a medicinal and aromatic plants project in India and Nepal: An assessment
Author_affil: International Centre for Integrated Mountain Development (ICIMOD), P.O. Box 3226, Kathmandu, Nepal
Funding: CGMFPF, CECI and CSKHPAU
Stated_int: Medicinal and Aromatic Plant sustainable community-based management
Desired_out: "The International Centre for Integrated Mountain Development (ICIMOD) has undertaken a number of projects for the sustainable use and management of locally available and commercially valuable natural resources, including NTFPs, to enhance the livelihood options of the rural poor in the HKH region. One of these projects focused on the communitybased management and sustainable use of MAPs and was implemented at 3 project sites in Nepal and India by national partners from 2005 to 2009. The objective of this project was to enhance livelihood options and reduce poverty in poor rural communities."
Study_goal: #NAME?
Study_location: Darchula and Baitidi districts, Far Western Development Region (Nepal); Chhattisgarh state and Himachal Pradesh State (India)
Stated_outcomes: Change in management practices, production and productivity of MAPs, marketing and prices of MAPs, household income
Indicators: Change and adoption of new management practices, skills and knowledge

Authors: Rizek MB, Morsello C
Title: Impacts of Trade in Non-timber Forest Products on Cooperation among Caboclo Households of the Brazilian Amazon
Author_affil: Programa de P„s-gradua†o em Cincia Ambiental, Universidade de S†o Paulo
Funding: Kleinhans Award (Rainforest Alliance), scholarship from FAPESP (Brazil) to Rizek (Processo: 2007/06844-5)
Stated_int: Trade agreement between communities and companies
Desired_out: The trade agreement involved the two companies (Natura and Cognis) and CODAEMJ, for participating residents to collect and sell NTFPs to companies. Participation involved paying an annual fee, which guaranteed access to a share of the profits. Community members received payments for NTFP gathering and selling to the cooperative, participation in purchasing trips, local transportation of seeds to the processing plant, seed breaking and selection, temporary employment in the processing plant, and permanent employment for managing the processing plant and the relationship with the companies.
Study_goal: To evaluate the effects of involvement in the NTFP market on cooperation among households
Study_location: Roque, Pupuai in Medio Jurua Extractive Reserve, Carauari town, Amazonas State
Stated_outcomes: Obtaining goods and income via cooperation
Indicators: Level of cooperation and association with income and goods consumed
Outcome.direction_notes: Participation in trade agreements resulted in lower cooperation and less benefits accrued through cooperation

Authors: Rodriguez LG, Perez MR, Yang X, Geriletu, Belcher B, Zhou B, Li Z
Title: Maintaining the contract responsibility system of forest land distribution in China: Evidence from a novel financial compensation scheme in Daxi Village of Anji County, Zhejiang
Author_affil: Department of Ecology, Autonomous University of Madrid, Darwin Street 2, Cantoblanco 28049, Madrid, Spain
Funding: AECI (Spanish International Cooperation Agency) and Mutua Madrilena de Seguros
Stated_int: Inter-household Forest Compensation Scheme
Desired_out: "This compensation scheme revolves around an equal-per-capita land access principle which, being the cornerstone of the HRS and CRS across Rural China, shaped householdsê forest endowments at the onset of post-78 reforms in our study area. At its core, the scheme brings up the new notion of redistributing a certain amount of the communityês forest production, compensating those households with increased family size but without curtailing private forest entrepreneurship."
Study_goal: "We analyze the evolution of the Inter-household Forest Compensation Scheme, its impact in local and household economies, and farmersê attitudes and opin- ions about the effectiveness and fairness of the system. Our aim is to better understand the interactions that occur between land rightsê institutions and forest management, as a contribution to the literature on rural land reform and particularly focused on forest redistributive practices in China."
Study_location: Anji County, Daxi Village
Stated_outcomes: Percent compensation, per capita income, perceptions of compensation benefits
Indicators: change in percentage compensation, change in household income
Outcome.direction_notes: Differs by demographic group

Authors: Rodriguez LG, Perez MR, Yang X, Geriletu, Belcher B, Zhou B, Li Z
Title: Maintaining the contract responsibility system of forest land distribution in China: Evidence from a novel financial compensation scheme in Daxi Village of Anji County, Zhejiang
Author_affil: Department of Ecology, Autonomous University of Madrid, Darwin Street 2, Cantoblanco 28049, Madrid, Spain
Funding: AECI (Spanish International Cooperation Agency) and Mutua Madrilena de Seguros
Stated_int: Inter-household Forest Compensation Scheme
Desired_out: "This compensation scheme revolves around an equal-per-capita land access principle which, being the cornerstone of the HRS and CRS across Rural China, shaped householdsê forest endowments at the onset of post-78 reforms in our study area. At its core, the scheme brings up the new notion of redistributing a certain amount of the communityês forest production, compensating those households with increased family size but without curtailing private forest entrepreneurship."
Study_goal: "We analyze the evolution of the Inter-household Forest Compensation Scheme, its impact in local and household economies, and farmersê attitudes and opin- ions about the effectiveness and fairness of the system. Our aim is to better understand the interactions that occur between land rightsê institutions and forest management, as a contribution to the literature on rural land reform and particularly focused on forest redistributive practices in China."
Study_location: Anji County, Daxi Village
Stated_outcomes: Percent compensation, per capita income, perceptions of compensation benefits
Indicators: change in percentage compensation, change in household income
Outcome.direction_notes: Differs by demographic group

Authors: Sanginga PC, Abenakyo A, Kamugisha R, Martin AM, Muzira R
Title: Tracking outcomes of social capital and institutional innovations in natural resources management: Methodological issues and empirical evidence from participatory bylaw reform in Uganda
Author_affil: International Development Research Centre , Nairobi, Kenya
Stated_int: Participatory learning and action research (PLAR) project, natural resource management
Desired_out: "A 5-year (2000_2004) participatory learning and action research (PLAR) project that aimed at strengthening social capital for improved policies and decision making in natural resource management." "The main thrust of the project was that rural communities and local stakeholders would be more likely to implement policies and bylaws if they had participated in their formulation. The projectês strategy was to build on existing social capital and to strengthen it through the facilitation of participatory social learning and policy dialogue processes aimed at building ••adaptive manager communities,êê communities that are empowered to deal with policies and other drivers of change and possess institutions for social learning"
Study_goal: "In this article we use empirical evidence from a tracking study to investigate the outcomes and potential impacts of a 5-year participatory learning and action research (PLAR) project that aimed at strengthening the capacity of local communities to formulate and implement bylaws for sustainable NRM. This tracking study was undertaken one year after the end of the PLAR project to investigate and document the specific outcomes, potential impacts, and conditions for sustainability of strengthened social capital for improving policies and decision making in NRM."
Study_location: Kabale district
Stated_outcomes: Conflict between households/wildlife, female participation, cooperation between households, cohesion between community
Indicators: Perceptions of conflicts between different user groups, homes, wildlife

Authors: Shoo RA, Songorwa AN
Title: Contribution of eco-tourism to nature conservation and improvement of livelihoods around Amani nature reserve, Tanzania
Author_affil: Wildlife Division, Ministry of Natural Resources and Tourism, Dar es Salaam, United Republic of Tanzania
Stated_int: Amani Nature Reserve, eco-tourism
Desired_out: "advocating eco-tourism as a means of enhancing conservation of its protected areas and, assisting in efforts to promote the economy and livelihoods of local people"
Study_goal: "We, therefore, assess whether eco-tourism is an effective tool for providing sufficient economic incentives and development opportunities for local people to value and protect biodiversity around ANR. Also, we examine how economic benefits from eco-tourism are distributed and shared among the local communities."
Study_location: Amani Nature Reserve (5 05_S and 5 14_S, 38 40_E and 38 32_E), East Usambara Mountains
Stated_outcomes: Perception of received benefits from eco-tourism, income generated from ecotourism distributed to community
Indicators: Perception of benefits received from ecotourism activities

Authors: Sikor T, Nguyen TQ
Title: Why May Forest Devolution Not Benefit the Rural Poor Forest Entitlements in Vietnamês Central Highlands
Author_affil: University of East Anglia, Norwich, UK
Funding: The Tropical Ecology Support Program of the German Agency for Technical Cooperation and the Emmy Noether-Program of Deutsche Forschungsgeme- inschaft
Stated_int: Forest devolution, forestland allocation
Desired_out: "The provincial authorities in- tended forestland allocation to serve two primary objectives: halt deforestation and enhance ethnic minority livelihoods."
Study_goal: "First, how do the statutory rights accorded in the course of forest devolution create contributions to local livelihoods in poor areas, that is, translate into forest endowments and entitlements for poor title holders? And second, how are forest endowments and entitlements differentiated among local peopleãtitle holders or notãwith what consequences for the livelihoods of the ••poorest of the poor?êê
Study_location: Cham B, Diet villages - Dak Lak
Stated_outcomes: Change in forest recipient's tree entitlements versus agricultural expansion, benefits and distribution from agricultural harvest, benefits and distribution from timber harvest
Indicators: Timber harvest
Outcome.direction_notes: Differs by income group

Authors: Sills E, Saha S
Title: Subsidies for Rubber: Conserving Rainforests While Sustaining Livelihoods in the Amazon?
Author_affil: Department of Forestry and Environmental Resources, North Carolina State University, Raleigh, North Carolina, USA
Funding: the Ford Foundation, IMAZON, and North Carolina State University
Stated_int: Rubber subsidies, Rubber program (Programa de Desenvolvimento da Cadeia Produtiva da Borracha), extractive reserves
Desired_out: "The immediate goal of the subsidy is to improve the living standards of rubber tappers, which in turn is expected to reduce deforestation both by encouraging rubber tappers to stay in the forest, thus preventing invasion by ranchers and farmers; and by encouraging rubber tappers to focus on rubber, rather than expanding into agriculture and cattle"
Study_goal: "We use these data to describe the distribution of the subsidy, including which associations and rubber tappers participated in the program and how payments were distributed across rubber tappers, associations, and municipalities."
Study_location: Acre state
Stated_outcomes: Number of families benefiting from rubber subsidy, sale of cattle
Indicators: Families benefiting from subsidies and inequality index
Outcome.direction_notes: Over time

Authors: Sims K, Alix-Garcia J
Title: Parks versus PES: Evaluating direct and incentive-based land conservation in Mexico
Journal: Journal of Environmental Economics and Management
Author_affil: Department of Economics, Amherst College, AC2201, P.O.Box 5000, Amherst, MA 01002, United States
Funding: We thank NSF Grant #1061852, the International Initiative for Impact Evaluation (3ie), the Carnegie Corporation of NY, and our institutions for funding support.
Linked_refs: See other papers on Mexico by Alix-Garcia (listed in references section of this paper)
Stated_int: Direct vs. incentive-based land conservation policies to combat forest loss: parks vs. payments for ecosystem services
Desired_out: Sustainable resource management, including reducing deforestation, and improved livelihoods
Int_dur: Earliest PA in Mexico was 1876; PES implemented in the country since 2003
Study_goal: We estimate the impacts of PAs and PES on forest conservation, poverty reduction, and population change at the locality level in Mexico in the 2000s.
Study_location: Across Mexico - localities with different shares of land protected
Sample_size: 59,535 localities total, which had some forest cover in 2000
Study_duration: The decade of the 2000s; poverty date is from 2000-2010
Stated_outcomes: Changes in the locality level poverty alleviation index from 2000_2010
Indicators: Change in the poverty alleviation index: based on area-weighted means of the locality marginality index from 1990 and 2000
Outcome.direction_notes: With respect to development goals, the data show that PES led to small but statistically significant poverty alleviation - a 10-12% increase in the local poverty alleviation index. Parks as a group had no effect on locality poverty trends, although strict protected areas showed significantly less poverty alleviation than the counterfactual trend. Importantly, none of the park types or PES increased poverty according to absolute measures: localities with conservation policies showed improvements on average across all basic poverty indicators.

Authors: Spiteri A, Nepal SK
Title: Distributing conservation incentives in the buffer zone of Chitwan National Park, Nepal
Author_affil: Alberta Tourism, Parks, Recreation and Culture, PO Box 280, Exshaw, Alberta, Canada T0L 2C0; 26-640 Upper Lakeview Road, Invermere, BC Canada, V0A 1K3
Funding: the Social Sciences and Humanities Research Council of Canada (Grant No. 410-2003-0136), research support from Damodar Khadka, Jeremy Mackenzie, Ray Chipeniuk and Gail Fondhal
Stated_int: Incentive-based programs, Chitwan National Park, buffer zone management incl. ecotourism and community forestry
Desired_out: "The buffer zone was established in 1996 in response to the need for landscape-scale conservation and to address the conflicts between communities and the Park ... The DNPWC and its non-government partners have since initiated programmes to support conservation within and around CNP and improve the economic conditions for local people. Buffer zone projects have included capacity building through training, Park infrastructure improvements, revenue sharing and community forestry."
Study_goal: "This paper examines the IBPs applied in the buffer zone of CNP based on local residentsê perceptions of IBP benefits. The main objectives are to (1) examine local residentsê perceived costs due to PA management, and perceived benefits from IBPs around the CNP and (2) evaluate the CNPês ability to focus the distribution of benefits on those most affected by the Parkês conservation efforts"
Study_location: Chitwan National Park
Stated_outcomes: Perceived benefits from ecotourism to economy, employment, social development, conservation, mitigation and participation
Indicators: Direct employment from tourism
Outcome.direction_notes: Higher in gateway villages with ecotourism

The main objectives are to (1) examine local residentsê perceived costs due to PA management, and perceived benefits from IBPs around the CNP and (2) evaluate the CNPês ability to focus the distribution of benefits on those most affected by the Parkês conservation efforts"
Study_location: Chitwan National Park
Stated_outcomes: Perceived benefits from ecotourism to economy, employment, social development, conservation, mitigation and participation
Indicators: Direct employment from tourism
Outcome.direction_notes: Higher in gateway villages with ecotourism

Authors: Sreedharan C.K., Matta J
Title: Poverty alleviation as a pathway to sustainable forest management
Author_affil: Tamil Nadu Forest Department, 1- Jeenis Road, Chennai 600015, India
Funding: The study forms part of the first authorês PhD dissertation work.
Stated_int: Tamil Nadu Afforestation Project (TAP)
Desired_out: TAP focused on poverty alleviation as the principal means to achieve sustainable forest management. TAP placed emphasis on providing alternative livelihood opportunities, encouraging micro-finance institutions through self-help groups, and promoting capacity building through systematic institutional development
Int_dur: TAP initiated in the state in 1997.
Study_goal: This study endeavours to provide insights into the effectiveness of the TAPês strategy of ensuring sustainable forest management through poverty alleviation and community development. An in-depth analysis of information on selected ecological and socio-economic indicators provides the basis for drawing conclusions. Elaborating on the opportunities and challenges entailed in the TAP strategy, the paper also discusses the role of developing appropriate institutional mechanisms to integrate conservation and development efforts from practitionersê perspective, to enable participatory forest management to succeed.
Study_location: Tamil Nadu: three TAP sites namely TN Pudukudi, Jothinagar, and Kannamoochi representing Western Ghats, Eastern Ghats, and a transition zone, respectively
Sample_size: 44 TAP villages out of the total 1,367 programme villages representing all bio-climate regions of Tamil Nadu were randomly selected
Stated_outcomes: Changes in selected indicators of socio-economic development
Indicators: Specific variables on which data collected include measure of social progress (literacy); occupational structure; economic progress (proportion of households below poverty line, proportion of households living in thatched houses, and proportion of landless households); dependence on forest (grazing, fuel wood, and other needs); pressure on forests (number of goats and quantity of fuel wood collected), and types of energy sources used.
Stated_mech: ...forests act as poor peopleês means to meet contingencies and reduce their vulnerability to risks...An estimated 41% of Indiaês forest cover has been degraded to some degree in the past and average forest productivity is about one-third of the potential. Rapid deterioration of forests thus deeply undermines the poor peopleês daily struggle to maintain living standards. The adverse effects of natural resources degradation reflect in reduced productivity, which ends up in enhanced poverty and misery.

Authors: Suparat B, Singseewo A, Pinyoanuntapong B, Thamaseananupap P
Title: A study and development on knowledge, attitude and practice in forest conservation and reforestration of youth in Ban Khao Phra community Nakhon Nayok Province
Author_affil: Faculty of Environment and Resource Studies, Mahasarakham University, 44000 Mahasarakham, Thailand
Funding: Research Budget for the Development of Graduate Students (Doctoral degree), the income budget year of 2010, Mahasarakham University
Stated_int: Training for forest management, participatory learning
Desired_out: Raise awareness and build knowledge around forest conservation measures
Study_goal: Develop and study effects of a training package in forest conservation and revival of youths in Khao Phra community, Nakhon Nayok province - specifically effects on the knowledge, the attitude and the behavioural practice to conserve and revive the forest of male and female youths
Study_location: Khao Phra, Nakhon Nayok province
Stated_outcomes: Knowledge, attitude and behavioral practice in forest conservation and revival
Indicators: Knowledge, attitude and behavioral practice in forest conservation and revival before and after receiving training
Outcome.direction_notes: Compared males and females

Authors: Thanichanon P, Schmidt-Vogt D, Messerli P, Heinimann A, Epprecht M
Title: Secondary Forests and Local Livelihoods along a Gradient of Accessibility: A Case Study in Northern Laos
Author_affil: Centre for Development and Environment, University of Bern, Bern, Switzerland
Funding: Sincere thanks to all the officers of the National Agriculture and Forestry Research Institute (NAFRI) and District Office of Forestry in Phonxay district who generously offered valuable help, support, and resources to facilitate the research. Financial support was received from the National Centre of Competence in Research (NCCR) North_South and from the Asian Institute of Technology (AIT).
Stated_int: Impact of increased accessibility on forests and forest livelihoods. Accessibility, in this study, refers mainly to physical or transportation accessibility, for example, better road condition.
Desired_out: By opening new market opportunities, accessibility improvement can reduce poverty and increase food security. However, resource degradation is also possible, such as where increased trade in NTFPs, leads to resource depletion.
Int_dur: N/A: Accessbility is an issue internationally for various time periods.
Study_goal: Focusing on forest condition and local livelihoods, this article leads to better understanding of the benefits and threats of improved accessibility, and of how internal factors such as forest dependency and external factors such as government influence and market accessibility interact with each other to produce these effects.
Study_location: We compare the conditions of secondary forests and local livelihoods of the villages of Nambor (village 1), Huay Lung Theung (village 2), and Na Ngiw (village 3) located along the secondary road leading from Luang Prabang to western Phonxay district in Luang Prabang province. Village 1 is 45 km from the provincial center, village 265 km, and village 3,115 km.
Study_duration: Field research was conducted from October to December 2007.
Stated_outcomes: Condition of secondary forests; impact of accessibility on local livelihoods (income earned from collecting NTFPs; PCA biplot analysis on differences across villages for livelihoods)
Portion_livelihood_amount: Study provides % of income from NTFPs/household for each village. This value ranges from 7.1% to 15% across the three villages.
Indicators: income earned from collecting NTFPs; PCA biplot analysis on differences across villages for livelihoods
Outcome.direction_notes: Income from NTFPs: Table 3 shows that though the amount of money earned is higher, the percentage of income from NTFPs in village 1 is less than that of village 3. This shows that the level of commercial forest dependency increases with decreasing accessibility.  Boxplot analysis showed that income is a strong factor differentiating the livelihood of households in village 1, and percentage of NTFP income in village 3. Village 2 is intermediate with respect to many variables. Income and land availability have significant correlation to each other but not with income from NTFPs and percentage of NTFP income.

Authors: Thoms CA
Title: Community control of resources and the challenge of improving local livelihoods: A critical examination of community forestry in Nepal
Author_affil: Environmental Studies Program and Department of Sociology, Whitman College, 345 Boyer Avenue, Maxey Hall, Walla Walla, WA 99362, USA
Funding: US/ED Fulbright-Hays Doctoral Disserta- tion Research Abroad program and the Social Science Re- search Councilês International Dissertation Research Fellowship
Stated_int: Community forests, community forest user groups
Desired_out: Community forestry as a model for participatory, community-based forest management to improve forest resource availability and flow of resources to local households, particularly those who are most dependent on them.
Study_goal: "In this paper I explore the livelihoods potential of community forestry and argue that community forestry in Nepal is more successful at forest conservation than improving livelihoods."
Study_location: West Area districts (Myagdi, Baglung, Parbat), East Area districts (Sankhuwasabha, Bhojpur, Dhankuta, Terathum)
Stated_outcomes: Use/consumption of fuelwood from community forests and other types of managed forests between castes and income groups, differences in decision making power as indicated by leadership positions within CFUGs
Indicators: Household mean fuelwood use compared between asset categories and caste status
Outcome.direction_notes: Very poor and poor derive higher percentage of fuelwood from community forest

Authors: Ting Z, Shivakoti GP, Haiyun C, Maddox D
Title: A survey-based evaluation of community-based co-management of forest resources: a case study of Baishuijiang National Natural Reserve in China
Author_affil: School of Environment, Resources and Development, Asian Institute of Technology, P.O. Box 4, Klong Luang Pathumthani, Bangkok 12120, Thailand
Funding: Asian Institution of Technology for doctoral student research
Stated_int: Community-based co-management, Baishujiang National Nature Reserve
Desired_out: "With the help of government officials and institution researchers, a group of development project applications with the aim of livelihood diversity and resource use substitution have been accepted by government agency or NGOs. These projects include firewood- saving cooking stoves, application of marsh gas pools, planting diverse species of trees or crops and providing a variety of agro-technical trainings."
Study_goal: "In this paper, we focus on how local villagers perceive the process and products of CBCM projects on their livelihood and identify changes in income and consumption that support the perceived impacts. Our goal is to reveal a more comprehensive and objective understanding about current CBCM mechanisms, to identify problem and to propose ways to improve them."
Study_location: Yangashan, Diebuzhai, Caoheba and Liziba CBCM Committees (villages of Shuigoubian, Qingyan- guan, Qingshuzhi, Majiaqiao and Wangjiaping were all under the lead of Liziba CBCM Committee) - Baishuijiang National Nature Reserve
Stated_outcomes: Ecological efficiency, Economic efficiency, social equity, institutional sustainability
Indicators: Economic efficiency (household income)
Outcome.direction_notes: Increased between 2006 and 2010 and increased more for participants versus non-participants

Authors: Ting Z, Shivakoti GP, Haiyun C, Maddox D
Title: A survey-based evaluation of community-based co-management of forest resources: a case study of Baishuijiang National Natural Reserve in China

Study_location: Yangashan, Diebuzhai, Caoheba and Liziba CBCM Committees (villages of Shuigoubian, Qingyan- guan, Qingshuzhi, Majiaqiao and Wangjiaping were all under the lead of Liziba CBCM Committee) - Baishuijiang National Nature Reserve
Stated_outcomes: Ecological efficiency, Economic efficiency, social equity, institutional sustainability
Indicators: Ecological efficiency (firewood consumption, NTFP value, livestock value)
Outcome.direction_notes: Firewood consumption dropped in 2010, Nonparticipators consumed more. NTFP value dropped in 2010, and non-participators received significantly more income from NTFPs.

Authors: Ting Z, Shivakoti GP, Haiyun C, Maddox D
Title: A survey-based evaluation of community-based co-management of forest resources: a case study of Baishuijiang National Natural Reserve in China
Author_affil: School of Environment, Resources and Development, Asian Institute of Technology, P.O. Box 4, Klong Luang Pathumthani, Bangkok 12120, Thailand

Stated_outcomes: Ecological efficiency, Economic efficiency, social equity, institutional sustainability
Indicators: Social equity (Gender equality, participation proportion of minority, information-obtaining approach, equity of project participation, competition of project participation, satisfaction of project participation)
Outcome.direction_notes: "Men have a much higher rate of project participation than women, and the percentage of Han participants is more than twice that of minority participants." "In fact, based on our survey, over 80% of households have equitable decision-making, husbands and wives jointly deciding whether and how to join CBCM projects."

Title: Livelihood Strategies and Land Use Changes in Response to Conservation: Pitfalls of Community-Based Forest Management in Madagascar
Author_affil: Institut de Recherche pour le De_veloppement (IRD), Antananarivo, Madagascar
Stated_int: Gestion contractualisee des Forets, community-based forest management
Desired_out: "Given the low success of the national forest service in regulating forest access, international and national environmental agencies decided to transfer forest management to local populations."
Study_goal: "This article focuses on household livelihood strategies and land use changes in response to changing forest access rules arising from community- based approaches." ... "In this analysis, we test a hypothesis that available land use options and livelihood strategies condition farmerês adaptation capacities."
Study_location: Fokontany of Iambara
Stated_outcomes: Change in land use, change in income, change in livelihood strategy
Indicators: Income from forest products

Title: Contribution of tourism development to protected area management: local stakeholder perspectives
Journal: International Journal of Sustainable Development & World Ecology

Funding: Grants 40801220 and 40621061 from the National Natural Science Foundation of China

Authors: YEMIRU T, ROOS A, CAMPBELL B, BOHLIN F
Title: Forest incomes and poverty alleviation under participatory forest management in the Bale Highlands, Southern Ethiopia
Author_affil: Department of Forest Products, Swedish university of Agricultural sciences, P.O.Box 7060, SE-750-07, Vallv_gen 9A, Uppsala, Sweden
Funding: The scholarship that financed this research is funded by the Swedish International Development Agency.
Stated_int: Participatory forest management in Ethiopia: The participatory forest management (PFM) project in the Dodola forest was started as a pilot project with the major goal of organizing the local community in to a Forest Dwellers Association (WAJIB).
Desired_out: Improved livelihoods
Study_goal: This study aims at evaluating and explaining the contribution of forest resources to the livelihoods of local households in the context of participatory forest management arrangement in Ethiopia. It employs the sustainable livelihoods framework. The following are the main questions addressed in the study: « What is the contribution of forests to the rural livelihood in the study area and what are the most important forest products? « Are there patterns and seasonal variation in forest use, forest dependence, and forest product preference among income groups? « Are socio-economic characteristics of households important in explaining such patterns?
Study_location: Dodola woreda (district) which is located in the Bale zone of the Oromia regional state.
Stated_outcomes: Forest income by household income classes, Gini coefficient
Portion_livelihood_amount: forest products constitute an important part of the household income portfolio contributing 34% of total per capita income
Indicators: Forest income by household income class, Gini Coefficient
Outcome.direction_notes: Households in the top quintile class earn 4 times as much forest income as the lowest income class whereas their dependence on forest income is less than half (0.46) of the lowest quintile class. Gini coefficient for forest income is .50.

Authors: Yuan J, Dai L, Wang Q
Title: State-Led Ecotourism Development and Nature Conservation: a Case Study of the Changbai Mountain Biosphere Reserve, China
Author_affil: Institute of Applied Ecology, Chinese Academy of Sciences
Funding: National Key Technologies R&D Program of China (2006BAD03A09), National Natural Science Foundation of China (NSFC40873067&30871958), and the 863 Program (2006AA10Z251)
Stated_int: Changbaishan Mountain Biosphere Reserve, ecotourism
Desired_out: "Ecotourism is thought to be an inevitable way for Chinese nature reserves to achieve sustainable development"
Study_goal: "The specific objectives of our study included: (1) to learn if local people had benefited from ecotourism; (2) to examine the extent to which ecotourism had influenced local attitudes; (3) to discuss factors that can influence local attitudes; and (4) to inform and improve nature reserve management in light of ecotourism development and associated impacts."
Study_location: Erdao Township, Changbai Mountain Biosphere Reserve (CMBR), located in Jilin Province of northeastern China [41ç41ê49”_42ç25ê18”N, 127ç42ê55”_128ç 16ê48”E]
Stated_outcomes: Have you received benefits from conservation, have you perceived loss due to conservation, attitudes towards conservation
Indicators: Perceived gain or loss of income due to conservation and tourism at Changbai Mountain Biosphere Reserve - compared between income groups

Authors: Zambrano AMA, Broadbent EN, Durham WH
Title: Social and environmental effects of ecotourism in the Osa Peninsula of Costa Rica: the Lapa Rios case
Author_affil: Department of Anthropology, Stanford University, Stanford, CA, USA; Carnegie Institution for Science, Department of Global Ecology, Stanford University, Stanford, CA, USA; Center for Responsible Travel, Stanford University, Stanford, CA, USA
Funding: Center for Latin American Studies at Stanford University
Stated_int: Certification for Sustainable Tourism, Lapa Rios Eco-lodge
Desired_out: Sustainable eco-tourism for ecological and human well-being benefits
Study_goal: "Our specific research questions are: 1) What have been the main social, economic, and environmental impacts _ positive and negative _ of ecotourism at Lapa Rios (LR)? (2) Have conservation efforts at the lodge been of sufficient magnitude and duration to alter deforestation trends in the property and surrounding areas as compared with the Osa Peninsula in general? (3) Has LR had an identifiable impact on local environmental awareness, and specifically, has it contributed to the spread of a conservation ethic among local residents?"
Study_location: Lapa-Rios Eco-lodge, Puerto Jimenez, Canaza, Palo Seco, La Palma - Osa Peninsula
Stated_outcomes: Household expenditure, income stability, knowledge, perception of impact
Indicators: Income stability
